column1: docker.bintray.io/jfrog/nginx-artifactory-pro does not manage nginx logs
column39: docker.bintray.io/jfrog/nginx-artifactory-pro does not include a solution to manage nginx logs in the Docker container.  Please modify the image to include logrotate and a corresponding cronjob.

column1: Misleading error message while trying to pull the docker image tag which doesn't exists in the repository
column39:
Message is 'Unsupported docker v1 repository request for <repo name>'. Expected something like: 'Image <image name> doesn't exist in the repository'.

 

Example:

 

docker pull asdrepo.isus.emc.com:8085/emcecs/service/sc-devkit:latest

16:23:32 latest: Pulling from emcecs/service/sc-devkit

16:23:32 faf64224e9ab: Pulling fs layer

.....

16:23:34 cd50779f6210: Download complete

16:25:11 faf64224e9ab: Verifying Checksum

16:25:11 Pulling repository asdrepo.isus.emc.com:8085/emcecs/service/sc-devkit

16:25:11 Error: Status 400 trying to pull repository emcecs/service/sc-devkit: "\{\n  \"errors\" : [ {\n    \"status\" : 400,\n    \"message\" : \"Unsupported docker v1 repository request for 'ecs-registry'\"\n  } ]\n}"

 

Issue was discussed in support.jfrog.com ticket #137730.

column1: make non-ui authentication cache requirement on client IP configurable
column39:
Problem Description:

Currently, the non-ui authentication cache is based off of request type/origin (hashed header) and client IP. This logic may not work well if a user has a "farm" with many dynamic client IPs. There should be a way to remove the requirement to cache authentication requests based on client IP.

Requested Behavior:

Have some flag to disable caching based on client IP, and only cache based on request type.

column1: Improve the log being printed when Xray is unavailable
column39:
In case Xray is unavailable or down (if it's due to upgrade or any other reason), Artifactory still checks if Xray is up and in case it doesn't and in case there is an LB or RP in front of Xray, ugly messages will be printed:

[WARN ] (o.j.x.c.h.XrayHeartbeatImpl:176) - Cannot retrieve xray server status due to: Failed to parse Xray Error message: Unexpected character ('<' (code 60)): expected a valid value (number, String, array, object, 'true', 'false' or 'null')

 at [Source: (org.apache.http.conn.EofSensorInputStream); line: 1, column: 2]

This jira is a request to improve this log message, since it's hard to understand and gives no real information to debug issues in case you are not familiar with the problem.

column1: Artifactory generates the rpm's primary.xml with file time which is not according to rpm spec and is generated with milliseconds unlike the build time
column39:
*Problem description:* Artifactory generates rpm primary.xml with a file time including the milliseconds (regular epoch). The general rpm spec and also the file and build time in all the remote source will not include the file timestamp with milliseconds.

Example primary.xml content for the same rpm file.
{code:java}
<time file="1584039332" build="1545089469"/> -- in the upstream repo
 <time file="1595585473000" build="1456953869"/> - generated in Artifactory local repo observe the file time
{code}
*What is the expected behavior?*  primary.xml file time should be normal Unix time with no milliseconds similar to the build time

*Steps to reproduce:* 
 # Download an rpm file from the remote repo and observe the primary.xml content from the source
 # Push the same rpm file to the local Artifactory repo and observe the file time in the primary.xml generated by Artifactory.

column1: Enhance artifactory healthcheck endpoint
column39:
Currently, artifactory health check(/api/system/ping) only monitors DB connection and the ability of the node to read and write from the file system.

In our HA setup, we use [aws s3 sdk binary provider|https://www.jfrog.com/confluence/display/JFROG/Configuring+the+Filestore#ConfiguringtheFilestore-AmazonS3SDKClusterBinaryProvider], where the node's ability to talk to its peers is critical for it to work properly. We recently had a similar issue with [RTFACT-19775|https://www.jfrog.com/jira/browse/RTFACT-19775] that the connection pool of the node is in shutting down status. As a result, the node could not retrieve artifact from its peers or shard an artifact to another node. Since we have {{<lenientLimit>2</lenientLimit>}} specified in binarystore.xml, All upload requests to the node failed.

Please enhance healthchek to verify the connection pool status in this type of artifactory setup so load balancer won't send traffic to the problematic node.

Cheers,

column1: Need more logging on the maintenance port 8091
column39: One of the customers ran into an issue after an upgrade to Artifactory version 7.6.1. Artifactory was not starting up and we were not able to see anything in the logs, even with the debug loggers for router enabled. After checking the health check for router we were able to see that they had another service running on the port 8091. More logging on the port being unable to be accessed would have helped speed up the troubleshooting.

column1: Non UI Authentication cache should work for all docker requests
column39:
*Problem description:*
The non UI auth cache (https://www.jfrog.com/confluence/display/JFROG/LDAP#LDAP-Non-UIAuthenticationCache) doesn't work for docker requests when using basic auth. 

The issue occurs for all docker requests, whether it be for the manifest or the layers. This is due to caching being enabled only with requests that are based off a docker token. The docker client (or a smart remote repo with token based auth enabled) always goes to v2/token as a first request, upon every command (pull,push,etc) and then uses the retrieved token for all subsequent requests to artifactory for the same purpose (i.e all layers pulled by the same docker pull request).

*What is the expected behavior?*
-all docker API authentication requests are cached all the time

*Steps to reproduce:*
-enable ldap debug logs

-try to resolve the manifest/layer via curl multiple times:
curl -u admin:password1 http://mill.jfrog.info:12507/artifactory/api/docker/docker-local/v2/busybox/manifests/latest 
curl -u tuser:password http://mill.jfrog.info:12507/artifactory/api/docker/docker-local/v2/busybox/blobs/sha256:91f30d776fb27944b3febb64600db83a880fb4af3f55442f3ad5ee1a786295bf -O

-notice in ldap debug logs that there is a cached key entry, yet it still reaches out to ldap. Behavior occurs for both internal and LDAP users

{code:java}
2020-07-09 18:07:38,971 [http-nio-8081-exec-8] [DEBUG] (o.a.w.s.AccessFilter:329) - Cached key has been found for request: '/artifactory/api/docker/docker-local/v2/busybox/blobs/sha256:91f30d776fb27944b3febb64600db83a880fb4af3f55442f3ad5ee1a786295bf' with method: 'GET'
2020-07-09 18:07:38,972 [http-nio-8081-exec-8] [DEBUG] (o.a.s.l.ArtifactoryLdapAuthenticationProvider:148) - Trying to authenticate user: 'admin' via ldap.
2020-07-09 18:07:38,977 [http-nio-8081-exec-8] [DEBUG] (o.a.s.l.ArtifactoryBindAuthenticator:153) - Searching for user: '[ searchFilter: '(uid={0})', searchBase: 'ou=users', scope: subtree, searchTimeLimit: 0, derefLinkFlag: false ]' failed for admin: The user: 'admin' not found in directory.
2020-07-09 18:07:38,977 [http-nio-8081-exec-8] [DEBUG] (o.a.s.l.ArtifactoryBindAuthenticator:170) - The user: 'admin' can't be found in LDAP search


2020-07-09 18:08:17,172 [http-nio-8081-exec-4] [DEBUG] (o.a.w.s.AccessFilter:329) - Cached key has been found for request: '/artifactory/api/docker/docker-local/v2/busybox/blobs/sha256:91f30d776fb27944b3febb64600db83a880fb4af3f55442f3ad5ee1a786295bf' with method: 'GET'
2020-07-09 18:08:17,174 [http-nio-8081-exec-4] [DEBUG] (o.a.s.l.ArtifactoryLdapAuthenticationProvider:148) - Trying to authenticate user: 'tuser' via ldap.
2020-07-09 18:08:17,187 [http-nio-8081-exec-4] [DEBUG] (o.a.s.l.ArtifactoryBindAuthenticator:187) - Attempting to bind as cn=tuser,ou=users,dc=example,dc=org
2020-07-09 18:08:17,188 [http-nio-8081-exec-4] [DEBUG] (o.s.s.l.DefaultSpringSecurityContextSource:100) - Removing pooling flag for user cn=tuser,ou=users,dc=example,dc=org
2020-07-09 18:08:17,194 [http-nio-8081-exec-4] [DEBUG] (o.a.s.l.ArtifactoryBindAuthenticator:222) - Retrieving attributes...
2020-07-09 18:08:17,196 [http-nio-8081-exec-4] [DEBUG] (o.a.s.l.ArtifactoryLdapAuthenticationProvider:185) - 'tuser' authenticated successfully by ldap server.

{code}

column1: Changing NuGet indexing log entry from DEBUG to INFO level
column39:
+Feature description+: This request is to change the below log entry from DEBUG to INFO level, which will print while indexing a NuGet package.

_2020-06-24 10:56:10,024 [http-nio-8081-exec-1101] [DEBUG] (o.a.a.n.NuGetServiceImpl:274) - Added NuPkg path 'nuget-local-site1/path/to/package/package.1.0.0.nupkg ' with id of 'package' and version '1.0.0' to cache._


 Below is the complete log entry which will be logged in Artifactory log while indexing a NuGet package:
 2020-06-30 08:53:58,323 [art-exec-4251] [INFO ] (o.j.r.n.NuGetWorkContext:68) - Indexing NuGet metadata for repo 'nuget-remote-cache' on path 'HtmlSanitizer.5.0.331.nupkg'
 2020-06-30 08:53:58,331 [art-exec-4251] [INFO ] (o.j.r.n.NuGetWorkContext:88) - Finished writing Nuget metadata for repo nuget-remote-cache on path 'HtmlSanitizer.5.0.331.nupkg' at 1593507238331 ms
 _2020-06-30 08:53:58,338 [art-exec-4251] [DEBUG] (o.a.a.n.NuGetServiceImpl:274) - Added NuPkg path 'nuget-remote-cache/HtmlSanitizer.5.0.331.nupkg ' with id of 'HtmlSanitizer' and version '5.0.331' to cache._
  

+What is the expected behavior+: Without enabling NuGet debug loggers Artifactory should print the below log entry in the Artifactory log.
 _2020-06-24 10:56:10,024 [http-nio-8081-exec-1101] [DEBUG] (o.a.a.n.NuGetServiceImpl:274) - Added NuPkg path 'nuget-local-site1/path/to/package/package.1.0.0.nupkg ' with id of 'package' and version '1.0.0' to cache._

column252:
15/Jul/20 11:27 AM;joe.henshaw;For context, the DEBUG level message is the one that tells us that the package is ready to actually consume (i.e. become searchable and can be installed by a NuGet client). The current INFO level messages are therefore somewhat misleading - you'd expect to be able to do this after seeing "Finished writing Nuget metadata for repo x on path y" but this isn't the case.

Surfacing the DEBUG message at INFO level instead also allows us to easier get timings on the asynchronous metadata calculation without having noisy debug level messages to wade through.

column1: filelist gets progressively slower the larger a repository gets
column39:
Problem statement and Impact
When a customer uses any kind of replication, the replication process will some how involve the filelist; e.g. event based pull and push fall back on a CRON schedule. the CRON relies on the file list method, which (basically linearly) scales with size/folder complexity of a repository, even if the actual diff of the folders is small.

Steps to reproduce
create a repository with many files and folders; I did ~2.3m artifacts (each file in its own folder) on an artifactory with a total of ~4m artifacts, and run, against localhost:
time curl -u <creds> "localhost:8081/artifactory/api/storage/<large repo here>/?list&deep=1&listFolders=1&mdTimestamps=1&statsTimestamps=1&includeRootPath=1" -O

For my size, it takes 59 minutes to retrieve the filelist - this is against artifactory 6.20 that is doing nothing else with a external mysql DB. In comparison, a customer with a busier artifactory saw this filelist take about 3-5 hours to complete.

Workarounds
N/A

customer impact
 As this filelist makes many calls against the DB to retrieve this information, any customer who has sufficient number of repositories (100+) will see spikes in their DB whenever CRON replication is triggered. Whilst this is expected, and we generally recommend spreading out replication CRON schedules for large repositories to reduce the overall spike - the time of this filelist does not appear to be majorly affected by concurrency, and it reduces the effectiveness of having the CRON as a back up if the filelist takes hours to complete, and it may even overlap its CRON period depending on duration.

column1: Create Unauthenticated Call Home endpoint for integrations
column39:
Create Unauthenticated Call Home endpoint for integrations to invoke without the user having to supply authentication in our various integrations for call home to work properly.

 

In general users will not supply auth unless they have to for some valid reason.

 

An example is the log analytics integration which does not require a user to login to simply tail a log file. However call home will not work unless anon access or credentials are supplied. Users won't supply credentials and anon access may or may not be turned on which will break our call home integration.

 

Current endpoint: /api/system/usage 

Auth required

column1: Support for Julia Package Server
column39:
Julia programming language [https://julialang.org/] uses it's own Package Protocol [https://github.com/JuliaLang/Pkg.jl/issues/1377] to distribute packages and binary dependencies. It would be great if artifactory supported this and it would implement the Package Server and Storage Server.
For corporate usage, it would be great if it supported both General registry and also private registry inside the organization, and if list of registries could be somehow specified in configuration.
Currently there are some implementations of the Package server with support of multiple registries and storages, e.g. the referential implementation [https://github.com/JuliaPackaging/PkgServer.jl] or [https://github.com/GunnarFarneback/LocalPackageServer.jl] 
Julia Storage server has also public implementation [https://github.com/johnnychen94/StorageServer.jl]

column1: Clients wants users to see Xray errors in docker client output.
column39:
*Problem description*


 As Artifactory is not synchronized with the Docker client, we may receive the "manifest unknown" and "Forbidden" error messages.
 This confuses the developers using Docker repositories with Artifactory, as they are not aware what causes the "manifest unknown" and it is difficult for them to troubleshoot it and associate it with the Block Download policy that was configured.
 It will be good for the customers to have a descriptive error message that specifies the root cause of the failed Docker pull request.

*Steps to reproduce*


 Set up a policy with "Block Download" and "Block Unscanned Artifacts" in Policy and set it on the Watch that manages the Docker repositories.
 Attempt to pull a Docker image with violations - for example "node:lts"

column1: Add CIDR restriction to issued JWTs
column39:
CI systems are often issued an access token that they used to perform their various tasks. Almost always, this access token has heightened abilities over developers and some operators.

It would be great if during the creation of the access token if a CIDR block could be specified and enforced when using the REST API, or when fetching / uploading artifacts in any repository.

Even if this feature was initially only available through the REST API during token creation, it would a great start.

column1: Allow stopping/pausing an active replication task
column39:
As part off the replication monitoring it would be good to have the ability to "kill" or to pause a working replication task. 

The reason behind it is that in some cases replication takes a lot of time and possibly resources and it is not always possible to have a dedicated instance for the replication.

In some cases - it needs to be managed during weekends, slow-times, etc. 

 

Expected behavior:

The "stopped" replication task should only kick back in on the next scheduling (assuming it is still active)

The "paused" replication task should pick-up from where it stopped once resumed.

 

Possible workarounds:
 * take down the instance
 *

column1: Request for Artifactory to serve the latest published file in case of same name and version number
column39:
We tried testing the artifactory.request.searchLatestReleaseByDateCreated=true property on v6.11.6, but weren't seeing the expected results of the latest published file being served.

*Our setup:*

 Site A:

 - "Virtual Repo A"

    - "Local Repo A" with event-driven push replication to "Local Repo with Data Replicated from Site A"

    - "Local Repo with Data Replicated from Site B" 

 Site B:

 - "Virtual Repo B"

    - "Local Repo B" with event-driven push replication to "Local Repo with Data Replicated from Site B"

    - "Local Repo with Data Replicated from Site A"

 
*Our test*:
 # Upload myrepo-1-1.x86_64.rpm to Virtual Repo A (stored in Local Repo A and pushed replicated to "Local Repo with Data Replicated from Site A" in Virtual Repo B)
 # Modify myrepo-1-1.x86_64.rpm
 # Upload modified myrepo-1-1.x86_64.rpm to Virtual Repo B (stored in Local Repo B and pushed replicated to "Local Repo with Data Replicated from Site B" in Virtual Repo A)
 # Pull from Site A
 # We get the unmodified version (the old version from step 1) instead of the expected modified version from step 3 

Our Enterprise Solution Architect, Pradnya, was also able to independently confirm our results. 

*Our ask:*

We would like to have a property (somewhat similar to artifactory.request.searchLatestReleaseByDateCreated) or some other functionality that would allow us to guarantee to our users the latest published version of the file no matter the package type will be served on the occasion where two teams/users who are working in parallel inadvertently upload files that may have different contents but exactly the same name and version number. 

We do recognize that npm, docker, and maven each have mechanisms that already allow for this type of behavior , we just want it for all other package types too.

column1: Artifactory shows 500 error when we click on the Test button by adding http://download.newrelic.com/infrastructure_agent/linux/yum/el/7/x86_64/  URL in the remote repository
column39:
Artifcatory shows a 500 error when we create a new rpm remote repository and add the URL:
[http://download.newrelic.com/infrastructure_agent/linux/yum/el/7/x86_64/] and click on Test Button.

If we save without testing, then it works fine and packages can be pulled successfully.
Please go through this screen recording: [https://recordit.co/gR51CuvjQa]
Request.log
2020-05-28T21:40:52.974Z|60d673bf6865a8a5|52.8.67.255|santhosh|POST|/api/admin/repositories/testremote|500|1185|0|1020|Mozilla/5.0 (Macintosh; Intel Mac OS X 10_15_3) AppleWebKit/537.36 (KHTML, like Gecko) Chrome/83.0.4103.61 Safari/537.36

Artifactory server.log:-
2020-05-28T21:40:52.973Z [jfrt ] [ERROR] [60d673bf6865a8a5] [c.e.m.GlobalExceptionMapper:48] [ttp-nio-8081-exec-10] - null
java.lang.NullPointerException: null

 

Remote repository test connection sends a HEAD request to remote URL. The path http://download.newrelic.com/infrastructure_agent/linux/yum/el/7/x86_64/ is not supported the HEAD request.

You can verify it with

curl http://download.newrelic.com/infrastructure_agent/linux/yum/el/7/x86_64/

vs

curl -I http://download.newrelic.com/infrastructure_agent/linux/yum/el/7/x86_64/ (that returns 404).

Finally, instead of Null pointer exception, when we click on test connectivity of remote repository, it should call a GET request in case HEAD request is failed and returns an informative error to the user.

column39: Cisco DBAs have moved all Artifactory indexes to another table space for performance purposes. column1: System/Repository Import shows 'null'
column39:
When running an import with on a directory with invalid permissions (read/execute and/or ownership), the UI shows 'null'.

An example of a more informative UI error if nothing is found at the directory: "No files or folders found. Please make sure the path is correct and the files can be accessed by Artifactory."

 

Steps to reproduce:
Run Artifactory not as root user. Get system export, remove read and execute or change ownership to non-Artifactory user. Attempt to import (will need to specify path and not use navigation in UI). 'null' appears when clicking Import.

column1: Remove SEVERE level memory leak messages on shutdown
column39:
When shutting down Artifactory, catalina logs will often output messages like the below:
SEVERE: The web application [access] created a ThreadLocal with key of type [org.jfrog.access.server.service.auth.AuthenticationServiceImpl$1] (value [org.jfrog.access.server.service.auth.AuthenticationServiceImpl$1@47d83a89]) and a value of type [org.jfrog.access.server.service.auth.model.AnonymousPrincipal] (value [anonymous]) but failed to remove it when the web application was stopped. Threads are going to be renewed over time to try and avoid a probable memory leak.

SEVERE: The web application [artifactory] created a ThreadLocal with key of type [java.lang.ThreadLocal] (value [java.lang.ThreadLocal@6dde7e88]) and a value of type [org.springframework.security.core.context.SecurityContextImpl] (value [org.springframework.security.core.context.SecurityContextImpl@ffffffff: Null authentication]) but failed to remove it when the web application was stopped. Threads are going to be renewed over time to try and avoid a probable memory leak.

Although these messages are not a cause of concern since Tomcat is completely shutdown when the application is undeployed (during the shutdown process) andthe "leak" has no implications since the process shuts down completely, these messages should be mitigated or removed as it could cause confusion.

column1: Naming convention in Artifactory configuration descriptor for OAuth settings
column39:
*+Feature description+*:  Artifactory configuration descriptor nests element with the same tag name i.e. oauthProvidersSettings. This behavior will be observed when Artifactory is configured with multiple OAuth providers.

*+Steps to reproduce+*:
 -> Navigate to Admin -> OAuth SSO
 -> Create/configure Artifactory with multiple OAuth Providers
 -> Trigger the [https://www.jfrog.com/confluence/display/RTF6X/Artifactory+REST+API#ArtifactoryRESTAPI-GeneralConfiguration] REST API which retrieves configuration descriptor
 [http://Artifactory-URL/artifactory/api/system/configuration|http://artifactory-url/artifactory/api/system/configuration]
 -> From the configuration, we see that under oauthProvidersSettings tag there is another oauthProvidersSettings tag(with the same name) which will have all the OAuth provider configuration.

I have attached the screenshots for reference.

*+Expected behavior+*:
 oauthProvidersSettings tag should contain oauthProvidersSetting tag and this will have the configuration of OAuth provider

column1: Support Bundle Capturing Data Older than 24 Hours
column39:
While creating a support bundle from Artifactory, even though the date span has been selected as "Last 24 hours", the files older than 24 hours are being captured in the support bundle. "*Date Span*" considers the files according to the *time stamp* present in the file name and not by its contents. However, even though filenames has got the time stamp and mentioned below, they are being captured in the support bundle:

*-rw-r--r-- 1 xxxxxx xxxxxx 70214 May 19 20:29 catalina.out-20191214*

Also, the files which do not have a timestamp on the file name is also being captured in the support bundle. The support bundle has been captured on May 19, 2020. The old logs are captured as well.

Jan 22 10:33 xray_traffic.1579669432143.log
 Jan 22 10:33 traffic.1579669432140.log
 Jan 22 10:33 sha256_migration.log
 Jan 22 10:33 request_trace.log
 Jan 22 10:33 path_checksum_migration.log
 Jan 22 10:33 import.export.log
 Jan 22 10:33 build_info_migration.log
 Jan 22 10:33 binarystore.log
 Jan 22 10:34 conan_v2_migration.log
 Mar 18 12:47 jdbc.log
 Apr 3 15:49 user-plugin.log
 Apr 14 23:57 server.key
 Apr 15 00:00 key.pem
 Apr 15 00:00 certificate.pem
 Apr 24 20:50 requestTime.py
 May 6 17:16 http.13.log
 May 6 17:16 http.12.log
 May 6 17:16 http.11.log
 May 6 17:16 http.10.log
 May 6 17:16 http.9.log
 May 7 19:55 http.8.log
 May 11 12:50 http.7.log
 May 11 20:15 http.6.log
 May 13 21:39 http.5.log
 May 14 23:13 http.4.log
 May 14 23:16 http.3.log
 May 16 13:26 http.2.log
 May 16 22:06 http.1.log

*Expected Behaviour:* The support bundle should capture the files which are only 24 hours old if "*Last 24 hours*" is selected. Instead of capturing the files using the names which have a timestamp, it should be captured using the timestamp on the server.

*Severity Level*: ** 4 (Whenever the customer wants to share the latest logs, the support bundle is including the old logs increasing the size of the files, which are not expected and which is limiting the security measures for the customer as irrelevant and old data is being sent to the vendor.)

Whereas if in the search page, it says there are 1800+ versions.

And it there a way we can increase the 500 hundred limit in a way that doesn't affect performance?

column1: MFA - Add 2 fields on the internal user
column39:
In order to support MFA (Multi Factor Authentication), there is a need to save 2 additional fields on the internal user (non transiant).

See additional tech spec:

[https://docs.google.com/document/d/1spmF1eaw4IV_OLcdxoYQktDyw25ngSbLlKc8UU-rVjQ/edit?usp=sharing]

[https://docs.google.com/document/d/1sYTfIPBPtzxTpw7SdotOat171UKtILsNw_OBxxeKMMA/edit#]

[https://docs.google.com/document/d/1O-_WJpLwy8O4sTtceV-KcXZuU5Dnn4EOep_TzFPlK-I/edit#]

 

Add 2 fields on the user (possibly on getCurrentUser)
mfaEnabled - Boolean
nextMfaVerify - Date
These fields should be saved persistently on internal users, and the front end server should be able to set and get them.

column1: Hybrid Checksum policy
column39:
The checksum policies in Artifactory are either verify against client or trust server checksum. If "verify against client" is used and the client does not publish a checksum you will have to manually fix the checksum from the UI for a 404 error will be encountered when trying to download the artifact.

The requirement is a new policy, that will verify the checksum against client if it was provided. In case client did not provide one, the checksum calculated by Artifactory will be trusted, allowing the file to be downloaded without manual intervention.

column1: X-Ray IDE improvements (Eclipse/VSC plugins)
column39:
Our use case is very simple:
 * X-Ray/Artifactory web views
 ** We define Policies and Watches on custom artifact/package repositories (npm and maven)
 ** Security folks review list of vulnerabilities/findings and choose to "Ignore" if acceptable
 *** Maybe the 3rd party developers haven't fixed yet (i.e. open bug)
 *** Maybe the attack vector and blast radius don't touch our software
 *** Maybe we just don't mind the risk
 * Developers
 ** Using Eclipse and Visual Studio Code plugins, we proactively monitor the X-Ray health of software applications while developing
 *** Re-scan on new modules/components
 *** Double check that we didn't introduce something new
 ** Developers can then make updates (e.g. version upgrade) to see if it mitigates a vulnerability

 

Improvement/request:
 * It would be nice if we could bind our local source code to a watch policy
 * If a finding (e.g. npm module or maven JAR dependency) was flagged as "High" but later ignored under the policy, the IDE should reflect that status based on the policy that the local project is bound to.
 * If unbounded, it'll always show the raw results of scans (i.e. not interrupted by an X-Ray user or policy)

 

Without this feature, I'm afraid these plugins have little use for us in proactive monitoring as we sometimes have to just "ignore"  Highs.  They do have some use when we're trying to resolve a dependency so we can continue to work with these tools.

column1: Re-enable last API activity timestamp in GetUserDetails
column39:
Hi Team,

Previously the Artifactory API allowed admins to determine the latest timestamp of when a given user interacted with Artifactory via the API. Apparently this changed to just be the latest timestamp of when a given user interacted with Artifactory through the UI. 

We would argue that the vast majority of Artifactory interactions comes from the backend due to automation and command line interfacing. We also see value in being able to track when a user logs into the UI. We would like to request that the [https://www.jfrog.com/confluence/display/JFROG/Artifactory+REST+API#ArtifactoryRESTAPI-GetUserDetails] call would return both values i.e. the timestamp of when a user last accessed API and UI presumably via authentication events. 

This would be vital to our efforts of being able to accurately determine our active user base as well as cull inactive accounts. Many of our users never interact with the UI so this is why API interaction timestamps would enable us to be more precise in maintaining our instance and its analytics.

column1: Add Log Scrubbing Option to UI Support Zone 'Create Access Bundle' Action
column39: We recently received a demonstration from Ariel Seftel of a script he developed that scrubs classified data (IP addresses & hostnames) from the logs/files in the JFrog Support Bundle prior to their upload to supportlogs.jfrog.com.  This script is designed to be run after Support Log bundle generation requiring OS level access to the server running the Artifactory instance or access to a native Linux/UNIX shell environment.  Most of our technicians do not enjoy OS level access to production servers.  Moreover, our technician's standard technical workstation runs the Windows OS without sufficient support for Linux/UNIX shells.  Therefore, we'd like to request that the capability provided by this script be embedded within the JFrog Artifactory application itself.  Meaning, when a technician uses the Support Zone 'Create Support Bundle' action they would be offered the option (checkbox?) to request that the logs/files be sanitized as part of the Support Bundle generation process itself.  This would remove the need for our technicians to have access to a specific operating environment (with sufficient access rights) to perform what is currently a post-Support Bundle generation atomic action.

column1: Improved Storage Quota control
column39:
As it stands today, Artifactorys Storage Quota control is a blunt instrument to make sure that we don't run out of disk space.

The upper limit of when it starts blocking uploads is when the disk is 99% used. For a disk of 30TB there are still 300GB free space which translates to quite a lot of artifacts.

Also, there are no checks for available inodes which can run out before the available space does.

 

The Storage Quota setting should be improved by changing from % to actual bytes. And it should be expanded to check inodes as well. Number of free inodes should also be specified in numbers and not as a % value.

I would suggest that you support a format where one could specify the following strings.

1000000000

1000000k

1000M

1G

etc.

column1: Optimize NPM Virtual Metadata Caching and Aggregation
column39:
Currently NPM merges virtual metadata on the fly as every call to get package metadata on a virtual repository has to perform the merge and serialize the JSON.
There's no optimization for caching the intermediate metadata it seems, causing these repositories to be significantly less efficient than other virtuals of different package types.

column1: Integrate Mission Control import/export
column39:
The work for import/export is done on mission control. It needs to be integrated into mothership import/export of all services when MC is part of it (see epic link).

Export :
 * API : 
 ** URL /api/v1/system/backup/export
 ** Method : PUT
 ** No parameter
 ** Synchronous
 ** Code 204 if ok, 500 if error
 * File created : JFHOME/var/backup/mc/export.json 
 ** Not valid json as it's encrypted with masterkey

Import
 * API
 ** URL /api/v1/system/backup/import
 ** Method : PUT
 ** No parameter
 ** Synchronous
 ** Code 204 if ok, 400 if file in bad format, 500 if other error
 * File input is expected at JFHOME/var/backup/mc/import.json 
 ** This should be in the same format as export (encrypted with masterkey)

column1: Allow to configure the retry mechanism for database connectivity during Artifactory startup
column39:
If the remote configured database is unreachable by Artifactory during startup, it will fail with a connection failed error and Artifactory dies

Artifactory attempts to connect to the DB for max 3 times, with 2 seconds between each connection. Hence, the total time for retires is 6 Sec. 

According support team, number of retry and delay between retry are harcoded, 

it should be nice to have it configurable   to avoid unresponsive artifactory.

column1: Skip authentication and allow authorization for ldap users
column39:
Customer is using SAML for Authentication, and the permission target is using ldap groups for authorization.

The user-group mapping are checked on ldap for authorization permissions, and there is no requirement for ldap authentication.

This request is created to skip ldap authentication if the user is already authenticated.

column252:
09/Mar/20 4:49 PM;joshuah;*WORK-AROUND IN GIT CLIENT at Cisco*

I can confirm that we are having this issue with multiple GitLFS clients. There is no option for the users to re-authenticate because all of this activity is happening within a git clone. We are able to remediate the issue on a case by case basis by having users set lfstokentimeout to 1800 seconds e.g.

 

git config --global lfs.defaulttokenttl 1800

 

This forces the git-lfs component of the git client to refresh the token before it expires. Thank you for adding the feature request. *Being able to manage this on behalf of our users will be ideal and limit cases coming in to our support.*

column1: defaultDeploymentRepo attributes for Virtual Repo
column39:
I, as a use of artifactory virtual repository, would like to get the `defaultDeploymentRepo` information that has been set for a virtual repository, so that I can use the docker image promote process to move the image from one docker repository to another.

The limitation for the automation of the above procedure is that, the knowledge of only the virtual repository is provided to the automation to have a generalized approach that can be provided to multiple project member for use in their project.

More Information regarding the current procedure:

Using the ReST API command: 
 ```

GET /api/repositories/\{repoKey}

```
 Refer [Get Repository Configuration]([https://www.jfrog.com/confluence/display/JFROG/Artifactory+REST+API#ArtifactoryRESTAPI-RepositoryConfiguration])

Is there as reason why this is not provided by default?

Alternatively, is there a way to request this information?

 

Environment: 

Jenkins as a quality gate based image promotion automation.

Artifactory with a local development repository and a local release repository each with their own virtual repository for reference.

Refer [link]([https://jfrog.com/blog/docker-registry-to-production/]) and [image]([https://www.jfrog.com/wp-content/uploads/2017/11/virtualrepo_FTW1.png).]

The difference being the jenkins only know about the virtual repos and not the local ones.

column1: Filter Api-Key into settings.xml
column39:
When I download a filtered settings.xml from artifactory, being logged in under my own account, my username and password are filtered in when using placeholders like {{${security.getCurrentUsername()}}} or {{${security.getEncryptedPassword()}}}.

column1: Extend CRON for Garbage Collection
column39:
From Artifactory 6.12.0, a new Garbage Collection strategy was introduced: RTFACT-19192.

This is a request to allow the CRON scheduling of the "Trashcan GC" and the "Full GC" separately for a more predictable and stable Garbage Collection process. 

This will allow us to cover (and schedule) the case when a manual and massive cleanup of a trashcan was made. Which is still a resource-intensive process.

For now, we have to wait for up to 20 GC iterations or invoke the GC manually for "Full GC" to run.

column1: Support Docker virtual manifest deletion
column39:
When [Docker Registry|https://www.jfrog.com/confluence/display/JFROG/Docker+Registry] is deployed, you commonly configure a _virtual_ repository +to have a unique registry endpoint+ which support:
- Publishing images (in _local_ repository)
- Pulling images (from _remote_ repository)

Some CI tools integration can provide some *cleanup process*, to delete images published during a build (ex: [TeamCity Docker Support|https://www.jetbrains.com/help/teamcity/2019.2/docker-support.html] > _Clean-up of images_).

This kind of feature is not usable because *deleting an image manifest is currently not supported* in Docker virtual repository.

In this case, *http 400 bad request* with error message "{{Unable to delete a manifest from a virtual repository}}" in logs, and the detail of http request (TeamCity problem detail: [TW-64777|https://youtrack.jetbrains.com/issue/TW-64777]):

{code}
DELETE|/api/docker/docker-virtual/v2/orga-test/docker-test/manifests/sha256:92c7f9c92844bbbb5d0a101b22f7c2a7949e40f8ea90c8b3bc396879d95e899a|HTTP/1.1|400|0
{code}

If the deletion is done on an image path includeded in a local Docker repository, it would be nice to accept it (if user/token has permissions).

column1: JFrog CLI - support for podman or buildah
column39:
Currently JFrog CLI only support docker commands, and only docker client version higher than 17. RedHat Enterprise systems only supports docker (free edition) version 13 so we cannot use it with JFrog CLI. In the future, RedHat might only support podman and/or buildah instead of docker.

We would like to see CLI support for podman/buildah.

(also CLI should have been supported docker older versions).

column1: Allow for configuration propagation in HA clusters to be disabled
column39:
Many of Artifactory’s operational design decisions: replicated configuration files, hostnames being used as unique identifiers and expected to remain stable, are based on an mutable deployment model, where upgrades occur in place and hardware infrequently changes. 

Artifactory’s configuration file replication in particular leads to a few gotchas. For example:
 * Two stable environment failures due to plugin jar files being corrupted by this feature and deletion of jar files not being replicated. (RTFACT-20895)
 * Persistence issues with other truncated files when failed to part (see comments in above JIRA) 
 * Non-traffic node changes to the file store will also update traffic-facing nodes

Attempted to make the etc directory read-only to mitigate the plugin issue, but the application expects to be able to write to that location. 

With the binarystore changes the expectation was that the configuration on the file system at startup would win, but that’s not the case. The on-disk configuration is not necessarily the one that’s running. If we’d fallen back to making as many files as we could read-only we could have avoided this completely, but the other configuration files weren’t our concern at the time.

column1: improve DB query for recursive CLI searches/downloads
column39:
Currently, if you set --recursive to true for CLI downloads, the request may take a long time if there are a lot of artifacts in the repo. 
 "repoKey" : "rdc-build-local",
    "repoType" : "LOCAL",
    "foldersCount" : 297980,
    "filesCount" : 2936929,
    "usedSpace" : "824.17 GB",
    "itemsCount" : 3234909,
    "packageType" : "Generic",
    "percentage" : "1.74%"

The recursive CLI download is using the following query:

'select distinct  n.repo as itemRepo,n.bin_length as itemSize,n.modified as itemModified,n.node_name as itemName,np.prop_key as propertyKey,np.prop_value as propertyValue,np.node_id as propertyItemId,n.sha1_actual as itemActualSha1,n.node_path as itemPath,n.node_id as itemId,n.node_type as itemType,np.prop_id as propertyId,n.created as itemCreated,n.md5_actual as itemActualMd5  from  nodes n left outer join node_props np on np.node_id = n.node_id  where (n.node_path != '.' or n.node_path is null) and(( n.repo = 'rdc-build-local' and n.node_path = 'malta/jenkins_inference/default_inference_set' and n.node_name like '%') or( n.repo = 'rdc-build-local' and n.node_path like 'malta/jenkins^_inference/default^_inference^_set/%' escape '^' and n.node_name like '%')) and n.node_type = 1  order by itemId ASC '

The explain analyze for the above query is:
 Unique  (cost=3101399.49..3101412.78 rows=409 width=335) (actual time=226466.320..226466.351 rows=25 loops=1)
   ->  Sort  (cost=3101399.49..3101400.51 rows=409 width=335) (actual time=226466.313..226466.316 rows=25 loops=1)
         Sort Key: n.node_id, n.bin_length, n.modified, n.node_name, np.prop_key, np.prop_value, np.node_id, n.sha1_actual, n.node_path, np.prop_id, n.created, n.md5_actual
         Sort Method: quicksort  Memory: 31kB
         ->  Gather  (cost=1000.69..3101381.74 rows=409 width=335) (actual time=84328.174..226471.475 rows=25 loops=1)
               Workers Planned: 2
               Workers Launched: 2
               ->  Nested Loop Left Join  (cost=0.69..3100340.84 rows=170 width=335) (actual time=84324.195..226462.102 rows=8 loops=3)
                     ->  Parallel Seq Scan on nodes n  (cost=0.00..3031680.69 rows=146 width=278) (actual time=84308.618..226446.485 rows=8 loops=3)
                           Filter: ((((node_path)::text <> '.'::text) OR (node_path IS NULL)) AND ((node_name)::text ~~ '%'::text) AND ((repo)::text = 'rdc-build-local'::text) AND (node_type = 1) AND (((node_path)::text = 'malta/jenkins_inference/default_inference_set'::text) OR ((node_path)::text ~~ 'malta/jenkins\_inference/default\_inference\_set/%'::text)))
                           Rows Removed by Filter: 8964886
                     ->  Index Scan using node_props_node_prop_value_idx on node_props np  (cost=0.69..468.54 rows=174 width=57) (actual time=1.871..1.871 rows=0 loops=25)
                           Index Cond: (node_id = n.node_id)
 Planning time: 0.845 ms
 Execution time: 226471.674 ms

Dumps of the node and node_props tables can be found at:
https://supportlogs.jfrog.com/dropbox/logs/125138/

column1: Change the Maven Metadata Implementation
column39:
For remote repositories, Artifactory treats Maven metadata as a cache-able item with a cache expiry.

Problem:
- as soon as the cached metadata expires, Artifactory must go out to the remote repository to retrieve it as soon as someone makes a request to Artifactory for an artifact in this remote repository
-- this cache setting is configured through: Metadata Retrieval Cache Period
- this creates a performance problem for the first person trying to hit this remote repository that has this expired metadata, this performance bottleneck is especially visible with Virtual Repositories that have remote repository members

Solution:
- don't treat the Maven metadata as an expirable cacheable item, instead just create a setting to "refresh" the metadata at a configurable frequency (that fires off a background task that retrieves the latest metadata) and the item does not expire, it only gets replaced on the next "refresh"

The benefits of changing this implementation is that nobody ever has to experience a crippling slow Maven metadata retrieval when it "expires", instead the metadata should never expire and only be updated in the background periodically (through some configurable value).

column252:
26/Feb/20 9:38 PM;patrickr;I believe this request is asking for a background task that will periodically update remote metadata that has already been cached. 

Such behavior would likely require a list of cached Maven metadata files, and the system would need to ping the remote site to see if there is a change on the package. It may improve performance of an initial build run that pulls the same package metadata.

There are two headers that may support such a task, they cause the remote site to return a "304 not modified" reply if the checksum or timestamp matches:

If-None-Match: dbd1cf09a5fcaf34ea85dadf26e68d3c84698fb1

If-Modified-Since: Mon, 18 Mar 2019 18:08:25 GMT

column1: Integration of keycloak also for user authorization
column39:
Currently we use keycloak with OIDC to authenticate users in artifactory. But it would be great to use keycloak also for authorization, keycloak supports the scope roles where you can also request all roles for a user. This roles could be used to match them with permissions in artifactory.

For example:

There is a private generic repository: P012345

And two permissions P012345_reader (read access) and P012345_author (write access) attached to this repository.

In keycloak we have two users Gonzo who has the role P012345_reader and Kermit who has the roles P012345_reader and P012345_author. If Kermit logs in these roles could be matched to the permissions in artifactory and kermit would get write access to the P012345 repository.

Also possible as naming convention for keycloak to prevent unwanted access the roles could be named: artifactory_P012345_reader and artifactory_P012345_author artifactory would then just match all roles with the artifactory_ prefix.

Br

Arthur

column1: Do not duplicate log messages by default
column39:
During research on  "How to configure debug logging?" I've read about [Artifactory Log Files - Configuring Log Verbosity|https://www.jfrog.com/confluence/display/RTF/Artifactory+Log+Files#ArtifactoryLogFiles-ConfiguringLogVerbosity] and noticed that according [Artifactory Log Files - Minimizing Output to Catalina.out|https://www.jfrog.com/confluence/display/RTF/Artifactory+Log+Files#ArtifactoryLogFiles-MinimizingOutputtocatalina.ou] the logging into  

/var/opt/jfrog/artifactory/logs/catalina/catalina.out

duplicates a lot of messages from 

/var/opt/jfrog/artifactory/logs/artifactory.log

Since you are already recommend to change the configuration of

<appender name="CONSOLE" class="ch.qos.logback.core.ConsoleAppender">

I think this should be default setting in the package and be available and set right after installation.

column1: Regex to accommodate optional fields
column39:
Regex in the repository layout should allow optional fields to accommodate different kind of artifacts which has different file format, while resolving the artifact path patterns.

+Please find below for example:+

+whl:+ certifi-2019.11.28-py2.py3-none-any.whl

+pip:+ cairocffi-1.0.2.tar.gz

+optional layout:+ [orgPath]/[module]-[baseRev](-[pythonTag<py\d*.*>])(-[abiTag<.*>])(-[platformTag<.*>]).[ext]

+Mandatory layout:+  [orgPath]/[module]-[baseRev]-[pythonTag<py\d*.*>]-[abiTag<.*>]-[platformTag<.*>].[ext]

Files with *tar.gz* extensions can resolve with the above optional layout mentioned but does not work with whl package types. 

So Artifactory should be able to resolve both kind of file formats (whl and tar.gz )with the same regex by allowing additional optional fields which are not happening currently.

Also as a side note, for artifacts with *.whl* extensions, we can able resolve using the Mandatory layout mentioned above.

column1: We should have a warning message indication when replicating Maven snapshot repositories and the 'Maven snapshot version behavior' is different between the source and target instances
column39:
When creating push replication between Maven snapshot artifacts and the snapshot policy is unique on the source and none-unique on the target Artifactory will not provide a clear message of why artifacts are not deployed.
You will be able to see HTTP status code 200 on the PUT requests but snapshot artifacts with timestamp will not be replicated.

It will be helpful if we can provide a warning message when beginning the replication that will indicate the repository's unique snapshot policy differences and will save time for debugging such cases when artifacts are not replicated.

column1: Allow users with "annotate" permission the ability to regenerate repo metadata
column39:
The current rest API calls for recalculating metadata require a user with the manage permission. This permission allows them to change users and groups that have access to the repo. I propose that we use the proper permission level (annotate) to allow you to give users the ability to regenerate metadata on demand without having to give them control over users and groups.
Annotate as it is already billed as the following in the documentation (https://www.jfrog.com/confluence/display/RTF/Managing+Permissions):
"Allows annotating artifacts and folders with metadata and properties."

For instance: https://www.jfrog.com/confluence/display/RTF/Artifactory+REST+API#ArtifactoryRESTAPI-CalculateNuGetRepositoryMetadata this should be under annotate or a new permission level for recalculate, not manage.

Additionally the rest API endpoints should be consistent and all require the same permission level. For instance, these two require an admin user: https://www.jfrog.com/confluence/display/RTF/Artifactory+REST+API#ArtifactoryRESTAPI-CalculateCondaRepositoryMetadata
https://www.jfrog.com/confluence/display/RTF/Artifactory+REST+API#ArtifactoryRESTAPI-CalculateConanRepositoryMetadata

column1: Case Insensitive LDAP Group Resolution
column39:
Our Active Directory does not enforce case sensitivity when AD groups are created or authenticated.  Meaning, a member of AD group trying to authenticate against 'AD_GROUP_ONE', 'ad_group_one' or AD_group_ONE' would be successfully authenticated in all three cases.

Apparently, Artifactory seems to care about case sensitivity when looking up LDAP/AD groups which is annoying and introduces additional process overhead & enforcement in the upstream AD group add request process.

column1: In case there's a communication issue against LDAP server during authentication attempt, Artifactory will show a misleading error and eventually block the user
column39:
Steps to reproduce:

1.Install and configure Artifactory with LDAP (I used LDAP docker image)

2.Login with LDAP user so the user will be created in Artifactory

3.Stop the LDAP docker container to cause communication issues 

4.Try to login with the user from 2 (insert correct cred)

5.Notice the error: "Username or password are incorrect"

Due to the "Temporary Login Suspension" mechanism, Artifactory will block further login attempts by creating a temporary cached bad login attempt.


 Although we have a way to configure the cache period to 0 (using artifactory.security.loginBlockDelay property), the error message can be improved (in the logs we see LDAP communication error).  

Tested on Artifactory latest (6.17.0)

column1: Add the ability to exclude artifacts from the cache-fs based on regexp or size
column39:
When using the cache-fs binary provider, it would be great if you could choose artifacts you want to ignore from ever being cached. For example, if I have a 100GB cache and I have 10 machine images in Artifactory that are about 10GB each, even if I download only one of those files, it will evacuate a lot files from the cache just to have room for one file.

That's why it would be nice to ignore specific files from being cached based on either a regular expression for their names or based on the size of the files

column1: Remote repositories URL liveliness status
column39:
It would be nice to have the table that shows the remote repositories (Admin -> Repositories -> Remote) have a column that shows the health status of the remote repo URL, and if this information can be retrieved via an REST API call.

When initially setting up a remote repository there is a URL Test check that can be done, however during the lifetime of the remote repo, the remote repo can sometimes change or be decommissioned.

I have over a hundred or more remote repositories I reference and knowing which one is still alive is slightly difficult.

A good example is this:
 * When remote repos change their transport scheme from HTTP to HTTPs, and break their HTTP requests.
 * When remote repos get decommissioned.

column1: Let access.log file to show token Id when the calls are made using access-tokens
column39:
When a user does any REST API calls using an access token, the access.log file shows "token:<user>" in place of the username. 

The request is to show the Token ID in place of "token:user" since any transient users' data might not add any value once the user is no more available in Artifactory.

column1: Set a limit to the number of thread dumps allowed by the Support Bundle UI
column39:
If a user selects too many thread dumps for a support bundle in the SB screen, there might be implications on the server performance.
JFrog Support confirms that they do not ask for more than 10 dumps.
The number of dumps allowed in the UI should be limited by an artifactory.system.property, set by default to 20.
If a user selects a number greater then the value of the system property the OK button should be disabled with a warning below the "Number of thread dumps" field stating:
"value can't be higher than (artifactory.system.property)"

column1: Reverse Proxy for Repository Path and Port.
column39:
We are trying to change from using the Port method to using the Repository Path method, because setting up ports in our internal firewall every time we add another Docker repo or Virtual Docker repo, is a lot of changes. Also having to remember what each and every port relates to every time we try to do a Docker Pull or Push is a real hassle. At the same time we can not just get rid of the Ports, as we have lot of developers that have developed code and scripts that use the ports. We need a system that can use both Port, even if we never add another Port, and the ability to use Repository Path. 

 

we changed the Nginx, by adding the following line into the config for port 443. 

    rewrite ^/(v2)/(.*) /artifactory/$1/$2;

 

When the HTTP Settings for Docker Access Method equals Port, I get the following error when trying to docker login to the system. (using ports to login works just fine in this method, but I need both methods to work)
user01@sdl08023:/data> docker login https://artifactory.example.com
Username: user01
Password:
Error response from daemon: login attempt to https://artifactory.example.com/v2/ failed with status: 404 Not Found


When the HTTP settings for Docker Access Method equals Repository Path, I can then log into the system, but when I try to push an Artifact while logged in with a Port, it will get stuck. the first 5-6 layers keep retrying, but then eventually fail.
user01@sdl08023:/data> docker login artifactory.example.com:7002
Username (user01):
Password:
Login Succeeded
user01@sdl08023:/data> docker push artifactory.example.com:7002/ant-ivy:test7
The push refers to a repository [artifactory.example.com:7002/ant-ivy]
329f32939246: Pushing [==================================================>]  35.33kB
6337131d5673: Retrying in 9 seconds
c088ea8d7bf2: Retrying in 1 second
4e1da7a1a08e: Pushing [====>                                              ]  30.31MB/316.8MB
29d6161bc883: Pushing  1.536kB
6ceea066acba: Retrying in 5 seconds
e350acecbaeb: Waiting
630a44488685: Waiting
bb07d0c1008d: Waiting
4902b007e6a7: Waiting
007ab444b234: Waiting
blob upload unknown

column1: Debian Artifactory Repositories do not follow the official Debian layout.
column39:
We should consider following the Debian official layout.

Currently in our layout if we deploy a package in the following way.
{code:java}
curl -u admin:password  -XPUT "http://localhost:8081/artifactory/debian-local/pool/dpkg_1.19.0.5ubuntu2_amd64.deb;deb.distribution=bionic;deb.component=main;deb.architecture=amd64" -H X-Checksum-Sha1:74d1b2591b043ef8e74abbc6cc1ff53942e59ff5 -T dpkg_1.19.0.5ubuntu2_amd64.deb {code}
  !https://lh3.googleusercontent.com/Ea4coLyMbsOTwmNqxDnHff9FeVtZ5IEw37IHf_px-zNUxM1cIjAMq4syvpBl3nx3Ig_yFHfhvvU-1pbfVggNDARBwUB-wDjRQ9Zexukxp9ZmJhuw_ZlpLu6xSfwHzxZMHvZe9_YC|width=487,height=208!

Notice the the the above command has distribution as Bionic and one component Main.

 

Then if we run the below command:
{code:java}
curl -u admin:password  -XPUT "http://localhost:8081/artifactory/debian-local/pool/dpkg_1.19.0.5ubuntu2_amd64.deb;deb.distribution=xenial;deb.component=backports;deb.architecture=amd64" -H X-Checksum-Sha1:74d1b2591b043ef8e74abbc6cc1ff53942e59ff5 -T dpkg_1.19.0.5ubuntu2_amd64.deb{code}
!https://lh5.googleusercontent.com/kMdkim7qiG1sQ4J-VyUjV6pxzmSi9l7RtVU0tetR907sVWAIp1MCSScOv-SlJjDcNTE21M7zrWqpuXyS9xeWJ0fR9qvMAz4uMx5wdZXd!

Notice that after issuing the second command:

Bionic distribution now has a new component Backports added to it.
 Xenial distribution now has component Main added to it.
 This should not take place

We had a workaround were we split each command to a different local repository and then configure both under one virtual repository, however this will mean you will need to manage several pools of the package for each distribution.

In the official Debian repositories there is only one pool.

Please see the below links on the Debian Repository Structure/Format.

[https://wiki.debian.org/DebianRepository/Format] 

[http://www.ibiblio.org/gferg/ldp/giles/repository/repository-2.html]

column1: Improve Storage Info API to reflect more data from binarystore.xml
column39:
Currently, if you are using a chain in the binarystore.xml, such as the below:

<chain>

       <provider id="cache-fs" type="cache-fs">                   <!-- This is a cached filestore -->

           <provider id="sharding" type="sharding">                   <!-- This is a sharding provider -->

               <sub-provider id="shard1" type="state-aware"/>     <!-- There are three mounts -->

               <sub-provider id="shard2" type="state-aware"/>

           </provider>

       </provider>

   </chain>

 

The storage info API ([https://www.jfrog.com/confluence/display/RTF/Artifactory+REST+API#ArtifactoryRESTAPI-GetStorageSummaryInfo]) returns "storageType":"user-chain", which isn't very helpful.

{"storageSummary":{"binariesSummary":

{"binariesCount":"0","binariesSize":"0 bytes","artifactsSize":"0 bytes","optimization":"N/A","itemsCount":"0","artifactsCount":"0"}

,"fileStoreSummary":\{"storageType":"user-chain","storageDirectory":"/opt/jfrog/artifactory/data/cache","totalSpace":"1.92 TB","usedSpace":"667.32 GB (33.9%)","freeSpace":"1.27 TB (66.1%)"}

The storage info API should reflect more data about the chain, such as "storageType":"user-chain \{cache-fs - sharding - ( shard1 - shard2)}". The API could also actually reflect storage used from each element in the chain, like the shards and cache-fs (as the UI does).

column1: Add Database Indexes to Support AQL Queries
column39: Currently these queries require a full scan of the nodes table. A more efficient option would be to configure database indexes. Many AQL queries filter on repo and node_type and require full scans to satisfy. A regular multi-column btree index significantly improves those queries. Additionally, on PostgreSQL both nodes_node_name_idx and nodes_node_path_idx need an operator type added, varchar_pattern_ops, to allow the indexes to be used for left anchored LIKE queries. There's also the GAVC search styles, which require trigram indexes to avoid a sequence scan of the table.

column252:
11/Dec/19 7:36 PM;angellom;* AQL queries appear to rely too heavily on DISTINCT. It requires the entire result set to be sorted, and in this case results in a very large disk sort
 * Seems necessary due to the multiple joins against node_props, but AQL could emit a query that naturally resulted in distinct results
 * Some of the intermediate node_id sorts could be made faster by increasing work_mem, but it feels like this is more of a problem with those conditions and joins requiring these sorts at all
column253:
12/Dec/19 11:57 PM;loreny;Note that we have lot of distinct queries that are extremely slow. For example, the sha2 migration runs the following:

{code:sql}
select distinct n.node_id as itemId,n.repo as itemRepo,n.node_path as itemPath,n.node_name as itemName,n.created as itemCreated,n.modified as itemModified,n.updated as itemUpdated,n.created_by as itemCreatedBy,n.modified_by as itemModifiedBy,n.node_type as itemType,n.bin_length as itemSize,n.depth as itemDepth,n.sha1_actual as itemActualSha1,n.sha1_original as itemOriginalSha1,n.md5_actual as itemActualMd5,n.md5_original as itemOriginlMd5,n.sha256 as itemSha2 from nodes n where (( n.repo = 'auto-trashcan' or n.repo like '%') and n.sha256 is null and n.node_id > 0) and n.node_type = 1 order by itemId ASC limit 100;
                                                                                            QUERY PLAN
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
 Limit  (cost=18660388.45..18660392.70 rows=100 width=375) (actual time=76550.418..76550.569 rows=100 loops=1)
   Buffers: shared hit=2475245 read=14601, temp read=2961746 written=3744756
   ->  Unique  (cost=18660388.45..19674558.64 rows=23862828 width=375) (actual time=76550.416..76550.523 rows=100 loops=1)
         Buffers: shared hit=2475245 read=14601, temp read=2961746 written=3744756
         ->  Sort  (cost=18660388.45..18720045.52 rows=23862828 width=375) (actual time=76550.414..76550.449 rows=100 loops=1)
               Sort Key: node_id, repo, node_path, node_name, created, modified, updated, created_by, modified_by, bin_length, depth, sha1_actual, sha1_original, md5_actual, md5_original, sha256
               Sort Method: external merge  Disk: 6266640kB
               Buffers: shared hit=2475245 read=14601, temp read=2961746 written=3744756
               ->  Seq Scan on nodes n  (cost=0.00..3501837.28 rows=23862828 width=375) (actual time=0.112..22764.760 rows=19357488 loops=1)
                     Filter: ((sha256 IS NULL) AND (node_id > 623697) AND (node_type = 1) AND (((repo)::text = 'auto-trashcan'::text) OR ((repo)::text ~~ '%'::text)))
                     Rows Removed by Filter: 31312607
                     Buffers: shared hit=2475245 read=14601
 Planning time: 0.260 ms
 Execution time: 83017.429 ms
{code}
Without distinct, it runs in ~ 1ms

The batching query takes ~1m30s. This is a case where DISTINCT is a huge problem - you have to sort every row that matches the predicate, rather than doing a super fast index scan on nodes_pk which is a 6GB external disk sort of 23,862,828 rows - at this rate it would take 248 days for just the batch queries. Without distinct it's under 1ms, so more like 2 1/2 days.
column254:
10/Mar/20 5:15 PM;gordonmessmer;"Seems necessary due to the multiple joins against node_props, but AQL could emit a query that naturally resulted in distinct results"

Is that the same issue as: https://www.jfrog.com/jira/browse/RTFACT-7297 ?

We're running Artifactory 6.16.0, and seeing the behavior described in that earlier ticket: given several "or" cases, AQL generates a query that joins node_props multiple times, which results in an extremely slow query.  Using PostgreSQL backend, the query that AQL generates requires 20GB of pgsql_tmp disk space and 109 seconds of execution time.  Rewriting the query to eliminate the extra joins gets us the same result with no disk use, and 0.0006 seconds of execution time.

It seems like the optimization in RTFACT-7297 has regressed.

column1: REST API to retrieve+revoke the API Token associated with an user
column39:
We need an automatic way to disable ex-employee's associated API Token as soon as he/she exits our company so that the ex-employee cannot access the repo/artifacts after his/her departure.

Currently there is only an API to pull all the tokens associated with the entire Artifactory instance.  We want to have an automatic script to run nightly to pull all the ex-employee.  Then for every employee, call an REST API to get the associated token and disable the token accordingly.  We have like 6000+ ex-employee to clean up currently.  Having this REST API to retrieve+revoke the associated API Token for a given user will be a lot more efficient.

I'm looking for something like this:

https://<artifactory_url>/api/security/user_token  -s <subject_user_id> -d true 

where -s contains the user_id of the user. For instance, if subject = "jf-artifactory@b055f797-4dd4-4e0f-b2bb-277019b43bc5/users/212717255", then subject_user_id = 212717255

where -d is the optional parameter to delete the token associated with the user with the same REST API call.

 

Thanks,

Janny

column1: Support removing a user from the group using “Update Group” REST API
column39:
With the “Update Group” REST API, we are able to add the user to a group, but we should be able to remove a user from the group.
Initially, I created a group “grouptest” and ran the Update group REST API by adding the ‘users1’ and ‘user2’

POST - http://mill.jfrog.team:12354/artifactory/api/security/groups/grouptest
{
   "name": "grouptest",
   "description" : "Test for visa",
   "autoJoin" : "false",
   "adminPrivileges" : "false",
   *"userNames" : [ "user1", "user2"]*
}

The users were successfully added to the group.

When I ran the REST API again removing ‘user1’ from the payload the user still exists in the group.

POST - http://mill.jfrog.team:12354/artifactory/api/security/groups/grouptest
{
   "name": "grouptest",
   "description" : "Test for visa",
   "autoJoin" : "false",
   "adminPrivileges" : "false",
   *"userNames" : [ "user2"]*
}

column1: Artifactory should serve artifacts from remote cache when upstream is unresponsive
column39:
Artifactory should serve docker images from Artifactoy remote repository cache (irrespective of *Metadata Retrieval Cache Period*) when the remote registry is unresponsive

This behavior occurs when the upstream returns a 429 as well (rate limiting).

+Expected behavior+:

When a client requests a docker image, Artifactory should serve from its remote cache when docker registry in unresponsive. Instead, Artifactory is requesting to the registry and will get failed when the registry is unresponsive eventhough the image exists in the repository cache.

column1: Deleting a repository from Artifactory after removing it from the indexed resources in Xray leaves orphan components
column39:
We have a bug opened in Xray for this - XRAY-2299, but this issue is with Artifactory and not Xray. When we fixed this bug - RTFACT-18891 we implemented a delete event from Artifactory to Xray when deleting a repository that is marked as "indexed" only. This Jira is regarding the situation where a repository is indexed, but then we remove it from indexing in Xray, and only then we delete the repository from Artifactory. This causes Artifactory to not send the delete event to Xray since this repository is not marked as indexed, and leaves orphan components in Xray. Steps to reproduce:
 * Add Artifactory instance to Xray.
 * Create a repository in Artifactory and deploy an artifact to it ("artifactory-5.9.1.zip" in this case, from Bintray).
 * Index the repository.
 * Make sure that the components are added to Xray's components list.
 * Remove the repository from Xray BEFORE the next step - remove it from the idexed resources.
 * Delete the repository and its contents from Artifactory.
 * After deletion, the "artifactory-5.9.1.zip" component will remain in Xray, with the location being the repository that was deleted (even though it doesn't exist anymore).

column1: Issue with resolving packages for NPM from packages.simplifier.net
column39:
Arifactory is unable to fetch NPM artifacts from https://packages.simplifier.net whereas it works fine during the direct download(without Artifactory) from the upstream URL.

Steps to reproduce

1. Create a remote NPM remote repository pointing to packages.simplifier.net [Test connection fails with 404]

2. configure the npm client to use the configured remote repository

3. Try fetching Simplifier.Core.STU3 package using NPM client

example : 


{code:java}
npm install Simplifier.Core.STU3 --registry http://myartifactory.com/artifactory/api/npm/npm-remote/
{code}


which will result in 404 entries for the packages.

4. Enable bypass head request in the remote repository configuration and try the same npm command.

The client will be providing a 500 response after fetching the package.json file.

REPRODUCE

1) Artifactory 6.13.1 or latest, create user

2) try running the following API

curl -L -XPUT -uadmin:password -H "Content-type:application/json" http://art.com/artifactory/api/security/groups/test -d '\{"name":"test","realm":"internal","userNames":["user"]}'

3) the group will be created but the user will not be added to the group

 

WORKAROUND

After performing above steps, then run the same command as a POST.  This will update the group and will include the user.

column1: Retrieve token id details (access token value, refresh token value) using JFrog REST API
column39:
As a JFrog administrator I'd like to retrieve the token id details such as access token value and refresh token value using the JFrog REST API. Currently you can retrieve the following token id details using [the following REST API command|[https://www.jfrog.com/confluence/display/RTF/Artifactory+REST+API#ArtifactoryRESTAPI-GetTokens]]. It would be fruitful to also view the token value and refresh token value, only as an administrator viewer.

Why?

Our Artifactory instance is heavily used with over 3000 engineers. There have been many use cases where users, who generate their access tokens using the REST API did not save the output and have asked what the value is. It has happened both from by JFrog administrators who generate tokens as well as other users of the platform. Thus a new token needed to be generated while deleting the token where the output was not saved. This causes additional overhead which would ideally be minimized if we could retrieve the token id details, such as access token and refresh token values.

column1: Support case insensitive include and exclude patterns for PyPi repositories
column39:
As mentioned in the KB article [https://jfrog.com/knowledge-base/how-do-i-use-include-and-exclude-patterns-on-a-pypi-repository/], since using the regular Include and Exclude patterns of *names of artifacts* will not work on PyPi repositories, in order to configure Include and Exclude patterns that will work on PyPi repositories you will need to use the Include and Exclude patterns to Include/Exclude the packages *metadata* (not its name).

In an opposite use case, if a customer wants to exclude *all artifacts except for a few that he wants to include*, it becomes harder to configure, since Artifactory uses the include and exclude patterns as case sensitive. If you have a package that you would like to include, for example - "{color:#14892c}Cython{color}", since its name starts with an upper case letter in the remote repository, you will need to create 2 different include patterns for it:
 # "{color:#14892c}**/cython*{color}" (this pattern will allow to include the *metadata file* for this package which is always saved with lower case letters no matter the package name).
 # "{color:#14892c}**/Cython*{color}" (this pattern will allow to include the *package itself* since it is saved with an upper case).

Except for those two patterns you will need to make for each package you want to include, you will also need to create the pattern - "{color:#14892c}**/simple.html{color}" to allow the index file for the repository to be pulled (if this is not present, no packages will be able to be pulled).

In the Python PEPS documentation (specifically PEP-426: [https://www.python.org/dev/peps/pep-0426/#name)] it says:

"{color:#59afe1}All comparisons of distribution names MUST be case insensitive, and MUST consider hyphens and underscores to be equivalent.{color}"

 

In order to be aligned with the Python PEPS requirements, we need to make the include and exclude patterns (for PyPi repositories *only*) case insensitive.

Then it moves on to the next node, takes another ~15 minutes. The last recorded timestamp in one of the nodes:
artifactory.log:timestamp="2019-11-13 19:12:47,132",thread="art-exec-13253",level="INFO ",class="o.a.a.s.c.BundleCollector:151",message="Scheduling task 'collectSystemInfo'"

[Customer decided to just tar xvzf at this point - it had been running for over 40 minutes at this point, as it would have taken over an hour to complete]

Eventually the customer just decided to tar -xvzf his logs, which took 3 minutes, compared to our job taking 10 minutes to collect logs, and another 2 minutes to compress, and multiply by # of nodes (5 in this case).

column1: compress debian metadata types in parallel rather than serially
column39:
Currently, each archive is done serially, rather than in parallel, which can lead to longer indexing times for larger environments - see bz2 taking 1 minute and 40 seconds. This can propagate to many minutes the more nodes there are:

{noformat}
2019-10-28 23:39:51,867 [art-exec-427924] [DEBUG] (o.j.r.d.i.a.DebianAutomaticRepoMetadataIndexer:117) - Writing Packages to path dists/xenial/temp-1572305948526/xenial/main/binary-amd64/Packages for coordinates xenial/main/amd64
2019-10-28 23:40:03,455 [art-exec-427924] [DEBUG] (o.a.a.d.i.DebianLocalInterceptor:94) - Adding sha256 to Packages file at debian-local/dists/xenial/temp-1572305948526/xenial/main/binary-amd64/Packages
2019-10-28 23:40:03,470 [art-exec-427924] [DEBUG] (o.j.r.d.i.a.DebianAutomaticRepoMetadataIndexer:117) - Writing Packages.gz to path dists/xenial/temp-1572305948526/xenial/main/binary-amd64/Packages.gz for coordinates xenial/main/amd64
2019-10-28 23:40:13,292 [art-exec-427924] [DEBUG] (o.a.a.d.i.DebianLocalInterceptor:94) - Adding sha256 to Packages file at debian-local/dists/xenial/temp-1572305948526/xenial/main/binary-amd64/Packages.gz
2019-10-28 23:40:13,302 [art-exec-427924] [DEBUG] (o.j.r.d.i.a.DebianAutomaticRepoMetadataIndexer:117) - Writing Packages.bz2 to path dists/xenial/temp-1572305948526/xenial/main/binary-amd64/Packages.bz2 for coordinates xenial/main/amd64
2019-10-28 23:41:53,148 [art-exec-427924] [DEBUG] (o.a.a.d.i.DebianLocalInterceptor:94) - Adding sha256 to Packages file at debian-local/dists/xenial/temp-1572305948526/xenial/main/binary-amd64/Packages.bz2
{noformat}

We should attempt to do these in parallel to reduce indexing times.

column1: ability to customize "docker image clean up by max unique tag" feature
column39:
Currently, the only way the "clean up by max unique tags" feature can be used is whenever the number of docker tags goes over a set number, the oldest published tag is removed from Artifactory.

It would be nice to be able to customize this feature, such as preserving (dont delete) 'latest', or certain tags containing prefixes/suffixes

or clean up via last downloaded time, rather than publish time. 

The artifactory clean up plugin does not work well with docker images.

column1: Add username to artifactory o.a.e.UploadServiceImpl log entry
column39:
Currently Artifactory logs each upload in two files: request.log and artifactory.log.

The file request.log contains the UI user but the file artifactory.log does not.

For audit purposes, I would like to add to the username to artifactory.log.

The reason is to be able to quickly find out what user deployed what file into what repository. The current workflow to find that out is to review artifactory.log, search for "UploadServiceImpl", review the repositories and files deployed, open a browser and check the UI for the user that deployed such artifact. This workflow is not efficient, cannot scale and would not give me a report of user upload activity for engineering management.

Hello, 

For some automation and security reasons it is sometimes nice to have an ssl certificate authentication on an API, or component. 

This would be a nice feature for accessing Artifactory, for repositories and to the API. 

In addition the abiltiy to autorize or not some endpoints for a specified certificate would be a powerful feature too. 

Regards,

column1: Repository level download count
column39: There is a feature in current Artifactory to get the number of downloads for each artifacts in a repository. We are having few repositories in Artifactory which has many dynamic files/directories so it is hard to get each and every artifacts to arrive a total download count on repository level. This repository level count will be an key input for us to take business decisions. Hence, would like to get a feature in Artifactory GUI to show "Download count" on repository level.

column1: Add comments in the DB queries with business functionality and Trace ID
column39:
Artifactory uses the same queries in different places, so it is difficult to identify which business functionality is associated with the query. Please *add comments* in the JDBC/SQL queries with business functionality so that the same queries get translated with different IDs in, for example, in the Oracle AWR reports. 

 

It'll be great if we add *Trace ID* as part of the comment, too

*Steps to reproduce the issue :*

1. Downloaded the paket tool from [https://github.com/fsprojects/Paket/releases].
 2.Created a Nuget repository (local,remote and virtual).
 3.Add the source URL and the dependencies in the paket.dependencies file
 4.Run paket.install to analyze the dependency and create packet.lock file.
 5.Run packet.update to update all the packages.
