column1: Artifactory fails to fetch metadata for RPM remote repository when metadata is corrupted
column39:
Whenever the metadata for the RPM remote repository cache is corrupted, Artifactory fails to update the metadata from the remote endpoint and the yum client fails with the error "Metadata file does not match checksum". We tried setting the "Metadata retrieval cache period" to 0 and we expect that as this parameter is set to 0, Artifactory should be able to fetch the metadata every time a request comes but the request is not handled until and unless we delete the contents of the cache and perform zap cache. 

We were able to reproduce the same behaviour by corrupting the metadata manually.

These are the steps we followed,
 # Create a remote repository "rpm-elastic" in Artifactory instance Art-1 which connects to [https://artifacts.elastic.co/packages/]
 # Create a smart remote repository "rpm-smart-elastic" in other Artifactory instance Art-2 which points to "rpm-elastic" repository of Art-1.
 # Configure the yum client to work with "rpm-smart-elastic" and we would be able to install and list the elasticsearch packages.

Now to reproduce the issue,

1. Created one local repository "rpm-local" in Art-2 and added the corrupted metadata files.
 2. Replicated the metadata files from "rpm-local" to "rpm-smart-elastic" repository, now the "rpm-smart-elastic" contains the corrupted metadata file in its cache.
 3. Once the files are replicated, we changed the remote endpoint of the smart remote repository "rpm-smart-elastic" to point to the "rpm-elastic" repository of Art-1.
 4. When we try to list or install the elasticsearch package using the yum client, it throws "Metadata file does not match checksum" instead of fetching the new metadata from Art-1's "rpm-elastic" repository.

To work around the issue, we manually should clear the cache and perform zap cache so that Artifactory could get the new Metadata from the remote endpoint otherwise we can use the expirePackagesMetadata plugin.

column1: Dynamic certificate validation while configuring circle of trust
column39:
Background:

As part of the circle of trust configuration, we copy the certificate files to the other Artifactory

$ARTIFACTORY_HOME/access/etc/keys/trusted location which doesn't require a restart. 

Issue: 

When we copy an invalid certificate (for example a certificate which has an extra alphabet in it) to this location Artifactory should validate the certificate is valid or not. Currently, the validation is happening only during the start-up of the Artifactory.

column1: Build Info permission
column39:
As an Artifactory admin, I want to restrict visibilty to Build Info based on the target repos (where the generated artifacts will be stored).

 

Another solution would be to organize Build Info into folders (in the Build Info repository) by specifying the target folder when publishing them and then assign a permission target on this folder. In that way, Artifactory doesn't rely on the build name (via a regexp) to set permissions.

Example for the 2nd solution : 

Let's say team A wants to publish and access their Build Info  in Artifactory, the Build Info name will take by default the CI Job name or the team can set it.
 If they want to publish it they need the permission from the Artifactory admin. So the admins *have to know the name in advance* or agree on a naming convention regarding the Build Info name (which is not always possible)
  
 Now let's say that we can store team A's Build Info into *Build-Info-Repo/TeamA folder* and then in the Artifactory permission system, we specify that any Build Info in that folder will be visible to Team A, this will greatly simplify the way to manage Build Info as it relies on 1 single criteria which is the folder where the Build Info is stored. Team A will have to publish into their folder ==> CLI + CI plugin Feature request.
  
 Now in Xray, instead of having to select Build Info by their name, the user just target Team A's folder in the Build Info repository.
  
 With this system, Artifactory/Xray Admins can assign permissions once for all for Build Info in advance without having to know the Build Info names.

column1: Increased precision for logs
column39:
Artifactory's logs currently have millisecond precision. This is fine for analysis of logs in a single node setup but it is not ideal for a busy HA setup where a load balancer distributes requests across the nodes on a per-request basis, as is the case in Artifactory's generated HTTPd config, and said logs are being sent to another platform, e.g. ElasticSearch, for further analysis. Millisecond precision in this case means that the the requests can appear in a random order. 

Can we therefore increase the precision to be nanosecond? 

It might be worth extending this to the other application logs, too - access, app, event.

column1: create permission target api should throw errors for invalid repo list
column39:
The create permission target api will return 201 even if the list repositories contains duplicate entries. It should return an error code like 400. 

Steps to reproduce:

1. create repositories a, b, and c
2. Call the api to create a permission target. Note that repository list contains duplicate repositories. 

curl -X PUT \
  http://mill.jfrog.info:12396/artifactory/api/security/permissions/1234 \
  -H 'Authorization: Basic YWRtaW46cGFzc3dvcmQ=' \
  -H 'Cache-Control: no-cache' \
  -H 'Content-Type: application/json' \
  -H 'Postman-Token: 6d064eee-989e-497a-8d09-237149a94ff4' \
  -d '  {
  	"name": "1234",
    "includesPattern": "**",
    "excludesPattern": "",
    "repositories": ["a", "b","b","c"],
    "principals": {}
  }'

This returns in 201, instead of 400 while the repositories list is invalid.

column1: Display part of the Group display in the list of groups so that SAML users can distinct between them
column39:
In order to use a SAML group, you have to add as a group in Artifactory. The exact name in the SAML and Artifactory has to match. The problem is that the name is a a concatenation of Hex. Example: 2b62b405-1352-9ed3-9984-b3415091d251.

In order to make it clean what is the actual group name, ie: "dc-developers", we populate the description field of the group. It's quite cumbersome to drill into each group to know what the actual group code(aka:name) stands for.

I'd be useful to have the description (or part of it) in the list of groups UI.

column1: Getting a list or count of running plugins.
column39:
We need a way of finding out if any, and which plugins are currently being executed in Artifactory.

In the ideal solуtion - the list of currently executed plugins would be best, but also at least a count of plugins that are being executed would help.

Additionally - is there a way to tell how many internal tasks are being executed, and if the instance is busy or idle?

We also need a way to find out if the server is idle, so that we know when to start resource-consuming tasks using a plugin.
We want to start them when no plugins are running, and eventually no backup is in progress, but we don't have a way to get the currently running backups info as well.

Thank you a lot in advance!

column1: Accurate Response for Build Upload
column39:
Currently the [build upload REST api|https://www.jfrog.com/confluence/display/RTF/Artifactory+REST+API#ArtifactoryRESTAPI-BuildUpload] returns a 204 No Content response regardless of actual result.

This makes it difficult in an automation pipeline to identify whether there might have been errors tat prevented the deployment. 

Doing a direct upload to the build info repository returns 201 as expected; the API should do the same.

column1: RPM Weak and Very Weak Dependency Functionality
column39:
Artifactory automatically picks up on an RPM's "Requires:" tags for upstream dependencies and "Provides:" tags for downstream dependencies such that when an RPM is deployed to Artifactory, the tags are reflected as sections of the Artifact's "RPM Info" tab.

RPM has, since v4.12, supported weak and very weak upstream/downstream dependency tagging through the use of the "Recommends:", "Suggests:", "Supplements:", and "Enhances:" tags. Our use case would benefit from Artifactory reflecting these tags, and we are requesting their inclusion in the RPM Info tab alongside the regular dependencies. Specifically our system use case would benefit from this feature for reasons including the following:
 # We need to be able to query (using AQL) for all upstream providers of a weak dependency, so we can install them into a full system configuration (if they exist).  But unlike hard dependencies, a missing weak dependency isn’t considered an error.
 # After selecting a set of packages (using AQL) to assemble into a full system configuration, we need to be able to query for unsatisfied weak dependencies of that system.  This is used to produce a report for human consumption.
 # We need to be able to query for all downstream consumers of a weak dependency, so we can determine impacts of changes to the upstream source.

DOCKER_BUILDKIT=1 docker build .

column1: Improving Systemd configuration
column39:
Customer was experiencing issue with the systemd after upgrading to RHEL 7.7 in regards with the existing jira RTFACT-19850 and Customer proposed these changes to our implementation:

1)Alias=artifactory.service[root@uls-ot-artifa3 logs]# cd /etc/systemd/system
[root@uls-ot-artifa3 system]# ls -l
total 4
lrwxrwxrwx. 1 root root   43 Sep 20 13:13 artifactory.service -> /usr/lib/systemd/system/artifactory.service

This symlink apparently deployed from your RPM is not required. The file in /etc is used to override the file in /usr/lib/systemd/system/ provided by the RPM. Linking them makes no sense and has no impact on the service state. It only makes it more confusing and difficult if somebody wants to override the default service file.

2) /usr/lib/systemd/system/artifactory.service should not be executable, this causes warnings in the logs while starting.

3) Your systemd unit seems to point to an old school sysv init script in /opt/jfrog/artifactory/bin/artifactoryManage.sh . 
This is really strange and seriously complicates debugging...
I propose to replace all that and get some inspiration in other Tomcat applications, like for example Atlassian Jira, that works fine with RHEL 7.7...

column1: Add new index on REPO, NODE_PATH and DEPTH
column39:
We suspect the depth query is causing the load issue. Add another index on REPO, NODE_PATH, and DEPTH, because there are no indexes that exist that fully satisfies the where clause below:

{{SELECT /*+ index(NODES NODES_REPO_PATH_NAME_IDX) */ * FROM nodes WHERE repo = :1 AND node_path = :2 AND depth = :3}}

One of the variables in the where clause is depth and there is no index on depth so it is using the available index on repo, path, and name, and it needs to scan this bigger index. Also, there is a slow of skewness in the index.

The suggestion is to use another index (path, repo, depth), note path is leading, so the index is more distributed. We have to try it for sure.

column1: PAPI allowing a user plugin to load its config files
column39: User plugins historically load configuration files via the internal API ctx.artifactoryHome.haAwareEtcDir. This API is no longer available as of Artifactory 7, and something new needs to be used instead. column1: Optimize Concurrent Docker Requests for Smart Remote Repository
column39:
When concurrently downloading Docker layers, Artifactory will request the same layer multiple times, and will continue to do so until the layer is cached.

Let's say we have two clusters; cluster A and cluster B.

B hasn't cached the image yet, and A might be a remote with cached or not.

Concurrent downloads in cluster B sends out multiple download requests to cluster A for the layers, and only when cluster B completes caching a layer cluster A stops receiving new requests for that layer. 

For example, an image has 2 layer: layer 1 (1MB), layer 2 (100GB)

Since layer 1 is small, cluster B caches it quickly, so cluster B only sends out a handful (less than 10 requests out of 100) to cluster A.

Whereas layer 2 is big, it takes a while to finish caching. Cluster B keeps receiving new requests for layer 2, so it will continue to reach out to cluster A to download layer 2, until the cache completes.

This results in more than 50 of requests already sent out to cluster A.

column1: Artifactory capabilities for non-existing repositories. Wrong return of 'only_v2'
column39:
From Github issue: https://github.com/conan-io/conan/issues/5563#issuecomment-527855621

For existing repository, when asked for server capabilities, Artifactory returns the list {{['complex_search', 'checksum_deploy', 'revisions']}}. If the repository doesn't exist it returns {{['complex_search', 'checksum_deploy', 'revisions', 'only_vs']}}. The value {{only_v2}} is quite important because it tells Conan client that only API v2 endpoints methods are available.

The problem is that the error that the Conan client can report to the user has nothing to do with the actual error. Conan client will tell the user to switch to v2, but the problem is in the repo URL.

column1: encrypted assertion certificate does not propagate if created on secondary node
column39:
in 6.12, there is a checkbox that allows for encrypted assertions. If you enable this option, artifactory will enable this feature, and generate a cert/key pair under $ART_HOME/etc/security:
artifactory.saml.encrypted.assertion.private  
artifactory.saml.encrypted.assertion.public

However, if this request is done on a secondary node (possible through a load balancer), then the cert key pair will not get propagated to the primary.

column1: Add build retention to Maintenance page and allow automated clean up
column39:
Currently, customers have the ability to clean up builds via the build retention API:
https://www.jfrog.com/confluence/display/RTF/Artifactory+REST+API#ArtifactoryRESTAPI-ControlBuildRetention

However, it cannot be configured to run automatically, for say all builds (or a select subset). Customer is requesting a feature to allow this via the UI/REST API. Allow the ability to clean up via: max number of allowed builds (like maven unique snapshots) or clean up by date. 

Whilst we do have the 'artifactCleanup' plugin, and with 6.6 a build info repository, there isn't really an easy way to clean up the artifacts associated with the build info being cleaned up with the cleanup plugin.

column1: About negative cache of pypi library
column39:
We found that when we download a library from pypi, Artifactory adds `Cache-Control: public, max-age = 31536000` even if that specified library or version is not found (error code 404).
We don't think it is reasonable and this causes problems in the environment like ours where cache server is built in front of Artifactory.
That means this cache-control makes that once we try to download a package or version which does not exist, that one would be judged not to exist for 1 year even though it is registered later and actually exists.

How can we stop issuing this cache-control in the case of 404?
In addition, we don't think Artifactory 5.x does negative caching like this. It seems to have been changed in 6.x.

column1: Add system.property to set TCP buffer size for replication
column39:
We have a limitation in our HTTP client wrapper for Apache client's for setting the buffer for TCP packet sizes.

Requesting to have this added as a system property to increase the size of the TCP buffer, which can be added using the following:

{{HttpClient client = new DefaultHttpClient(); client.getParams().setParameter(CoreConnectionPNames.SOCKET_BUFFER_SIZE, 128 * 1024);}}

When creating new replication sessions. The sending server will open an HTTP connection but the default value for the TCP buffer size is 8k currently for the java socket implementation.

This is for the HTTP wrapper for the replication method in Artifactory

column1: Creating a group with special character "/" in the group name.
column39:
Currently, the creation of Artifactory groups with "/" in the group name is not allowed. 

This is affecting a customer who has is using AWS SSO with AWS Managed Active Directory. 

The group names for the customer are generated in the format: dfdp.com//S-1-5-21-938725559-3303118240-2935151787-1174

 

But this name cannot be added in Artifactory as it contains the special character "/". Due to this, the groups cannot be created. They cannot use other types of groups because it is AWS SSO and only SIDs are passed together with the domain "dfdp.com//"

column1: Conan repositories - "Force Authentication" option
column39:
For "_nuget_" repositories there's the option "Force Authentication". It would be great to have the same option for "_conan_" repositories.

 

My setup:
 * I need to enable "Allow Anonymous Access" on my Artifactory service.
 * The "anonymous" user doesn't have access to my conan and nuget repositories at all.
 * To access the conan repository the username / password is needed.

Current result (*without* "_conan user_" command)
 * conan user -c
 * conan remote add [conan-repo-name] [https://artifactory.[mydomain].com/artifactory/api/conan/[conan-repo-name]]
 * conan install . --remote [conan-repo-name] 
 * Result:
 ** 
{quote}ERROR: [My-Package-Reference] was not found in remote '[conan-repo-name]'
{quote}
 ** {color:#333333}This is misleading...{color}

 

I would like to have the "Force Authentication" option to force the user login in such cases.

column1: Allow nuget.org style unlisting
column39:
nuget.org has a feature where nuget delete will only 'unlist' a package:
https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/nuget/nuget-org/policies/deleting-packages

This provides a safer 'delete' that does not break existing projects but doesn't allow new projects to install the unlisted package without taking extra actions to do so.

This would be a nice feature to add to the NuGet repos via a setting "Default nuget delete behavior" and options "Unlist" or "Delete"
Then for individual packages in the Artifactory WebUI you could select "Unlist" or "Delete"

Similar as to what is done in Azure:
https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/devops/artifacts/how-to/delete-and-recover-packages?view=azure-devops&tabs=nuget#delete-packages-from-azure-artifacts-feeds

column1: safe, atomic folder removal not available
column39:
In POSIX filesystem API when removing a directory with rmdir the action is atomic and only succeeds if the directory is empty. 

In Artifactory when a folder is removed it can contain other folders and files. The delete will succeed regardless of what may or maynot be in the folder. This means there is a race condition and a chance of phantom data loss.

In the Artifactory User Plugins repo there is a plugin which checks if the folder has any content and if it finds nothing it will remove the folder with `repositories.delete()` but there appears no way to limit a 3rd party from pushing into that folder while that delete is happening or having happened the moment just before the system calls the 'delete.'

In our usecase we're regularly automatically pruning artifacts. Some of them exist in a hierarchy of folders. With the level of churn we expect the likelihood of phantom data loss is high.

If 'move' is atomic then it could be possible to "rename, check if empty, move back if not or delete". However, it's not clear if move is atomic and the code required to "move back" when there is conflict would be more complicated than the POSIX FS like behavior. There would also be a risk of that "renamed" object being unnecessarily replicated. That could be worked around with a replication plugin and tagging objects not to replicate but that is getting extremely convoluted for what should be a relatively simple and safe behavior.

column1: Store-bought Docker images cannot be pulled through Artifactory
column39:
Symptoms: A "docker pull" from the Docker Hub store results in a 404 error. This is even after authenticating against the registry.

Steps to reproduce:
 # Set up an account on [Docker Hub|https://hub.docker.com/_/registry]
 # "Purchase" one of the free images from the store - [IBM DB2 for example|https://hub.docker.com/u/patrickr93/content/sub-1c950dd1-e8c5-46fe-bdaf-51904bfd828e]
 # Attempt to run the Docker Pull through Artifactory:

docker pull docker.art.local/store/ibmcorp/db2_developer_c:11.1.4.4-x86_6

Error response from daemon: manifest for docker.art.local/store/ibmcorp/db2_developer_c:11.1.4.4-x86_6 not found

 

Although the request logs show a 404 Not Found, the HTTP debug logs indicate that there's a 401 error going to "auth.docker.io":

2019-07-12 00:32:38,876 [http-nio-8081-exec-10] [DEBUG] (o.a.h.wire :72) - http-outgoing-107 >> "GET /v2/store/ibmcorp/db2_developer_c/manifests/11.1.4.4-x86_6 HTTP/1.1[\r][\n]"

[...]

2019-07-12 00:32:39,056 [http-nio-8081-exec-10] [DEBUG] (o.a.h.wire          :72) - http-outgoing-107 << "HTTP/1.1 401 Unauthorized[\r][\n]"

2019-07-12 00:32:39,057 [http-nio-8081-exec-10] [DEBUG] (o.a.h.wire          :72) - http-outgoing-107 << "Www-Authenticate: Bearer realm="https://auth.docker.io/token",service="registry.docker.io",scope="repository:store/ibmcorp/db2_developer_c:pull",error="insufficient_scope"[\r][\n]"

2019-07-12 00:32:39,059 [http-nio-8081-exec-10] [DEBUG] (o.a.h.wire          :72) - http-outgoing-107 << "{"errors":[{"code":"UNAUTHORIZED","message":"authentication required","detail":[

{"Type":"repository","Class":"","Name":"store/ibmcorp/db2_developer_c","Action":"pull"}

]}]}[\n]"

 

The workaround is to bypass Artifactory and download the image, then retag and push it to a local Artifactory repository.

Nicolas

column1: Latest versions of some python packages require python 3.5 or higher
column39: Many newer versions of python packages only support python 3.5 or higher. PyPi on the internet implements the PEP508 standard to let pip know not to use these newer versions, however the artifactory does not.   Example jupyter-console version 6 is only compatible with py>= 3.5. On pypi, there is a tag on the html link as 'data-requires-python=">=3.5"". This does not appear on artifactory. The consequence is that it is difficult to install jupyter notebook and other packages on python 2.7.   ‘pip install jupyter’ Example from [https://pypi.org/simple/jupyter-console/] Pip will download this page and see that the link for version 6.0.0; * jupyter_console-6.0.0.tar.gz Has a field called ‘data-requires-python=”>=3.5”’ Pip for python 2.7 will then know to exclude this package when determining which version to download from the page.   Version 5.2.0 does not have the tag, and so is selected and installed by pip; * jupyter_console-5.2.0.tar.gz   Example from Artifactory mirror * jupyter_console-6.0.0.tar.gz As you can see, the ‘data-requires-python=”>=3.5”’ field is not present. Pip will then assume that I want the latest version of the package (6.0.0), download it and check the version of python required. This then fails, as pip sees we have an invalid python version. However, pip will not download or check any other versions of the package to see if they work.   REQUEST Need a mechanism to retry the download if the python version is not met after initial download

column1: old metadata remains in rpm repository after metadata depth change
column39:
If you set up an rpm repository with a specific depth, i.e: 4, metadata is then calculated at the depth of 4.
Then you change the depth to 0, new metadata is calculated at the root of the repository, however, the old metadata remains at the depth of 4.
This becomes a problem when you configure replication to another Artifactory instance, where metadata is calculated at a certain depth, but since metadata is not replicated, the repositories will never be in sync with regards to file count, making JFMC DR show that the DR is not in sync.

Steps to reproduce:
1. Set up repo 'A' with metadata depth 4
2. Upload rpm files to 'A'
3. Switch metadata depth on A to 0
4. Re-index
5. Create another repository 'B' on another instance with depth 0
6. Trigger replication from'A' to 'B'

See that repo 'A' includes metadata on the root and depth 4, but repo 'B' has metadata calculated only on the root, and the file count is different.

column1: Docker image uploaded as a zip having corrupted metadata
column39:
Problem statement:
When a docker image is uploaded as a zip - the metadata is somehow not getting updated and if we try to download the manifest.json file for this image - we get the following error:
2019-06-19 18:14:21,492 [http-nio-8081-exec-5] [ERROR] 
{noformat}
(o.a.u.r.s.a.b.t.t.d.DockerV2ManifestTreeService:62) - Unable to extract Docker metadata for 'docker-test/latest'
{noformat}

Impact:
Docker images can be downloaded as zip without any issues but on uploading the same zip to some other location - we cannot pull the image anymore

Steps to Reproduce:
- Create a docker local repository and push a docker image to it using 'docker push'
- download this image as a zip after enabling folder download
- upload the same image to a new docker local reqpository - docker-test
- Now try to pull this image from docker-test using 'docker pull' command ---> Failure

column1: Endless refreshing of AWS IAM credentials
column39:
Artifactory is trying to refresh IAM credentials 15 minutes before expiration, but Kiam will only refresh credentials 5 minutes before expiration (default config). The refresh attempt leads to Artifactory being trapped in endless loops/exceptions (java.lang.StackOverflowError: null) until Kiam is refreshing the credentials. 
{code:java}
2019-05-29 11:07:11,374 [http-nio-8081-exec-3] [DEBUG] (o.a.w.s.RepoFilter :195) - Exiting request GET (100.106.192.1) /webapp/
2019-05-29 11:07:11,805 [http-nio-8081-exec-10] [DEBUG] (o.a.w.s.ArtifactoryFilter:127) - org.artifactory.webapp.servlet.ArtifactoryFilter
javax.servlet.ServletException: Filter execution threw an exception
 at org.apache.catalina.core.ApplicationFilterChain.internalDoFilter(ApplicationFilterChain.java:200)
........................................
Caused by: java.lang.StackOverflowError: null
 at java.base/java.util.concurrent.ConcurrentHashMap.get(ConcurrentHashMap.java:936)
 at java.base/java.util.Properties.getProperty(Properties.java:1104)
......................
 
{code}
 To workaround this issue, we can update the appropriate Kiam configuration values (session-duration and session-refresh).

 

Customer ASK: Artifactory should handle this error and log a suitable error message.

17/Jul/19 6:36 AM;twiechert;Dear  Sankar Kumar,

from my perspective, this is a bug and major programming flaw in the your S3 library wrapper.

As the reporter outlines, the library recursively (!!!) tries to refresh the security token, until it received a "valid" one. Without any stopping criterion, this obviously leads to a stackoverflow and should thus be considered a bug.

Generally speaking, I consider it very questionable that artifactory rejects unchanged security tokens at all - is this supposed to be a "security feature"? If so, then it isn't described anywhere at all.

column1: Make cron entry as an Optional to avoid overlapped replications
column39:
According to the current implementation in replication, the Cron expression is mandatory even though event-based replication is enabled i.e. it enables overlapped replications such as both event-driven and scheduled.

ASK: Allow this as a choice to the user by providing an optional Cron entry to scheduled replication OR event-driven replication.

column1: Update REST API repository drill-down behavior to match UI
column39:
This is a formal improvement request to resolve support request #105317.

Scenario:

Local repository with files at a/b/c/d and a/b/c/e. User1 has permission to see the first set of files, user2 has permission to see the second set.

In the GUI, either user can expand the “a” directory and see the “b” directory beneath it, since it is a parent directory of one of their defined permissions. Similarly, if either of them opens the “b” directory they see the “c” directory beneath it. And when opening the “c” directory they see the appropriate directory beneath that one based on their permissions. That they are unable to see the file at the intermediate location “a/b/c” is expected.

In the REST API with the GET /api/storage/\{repoKey}/\{folder-path} endpoint, if either user queries the “a” directory they do *NOT* see the “b” directory and are returned a 403 error. If they query “a/b” or “a/b/c” they get the same thing. Only when they query the full directory path of their permission do they get a non-error result. They are thus unable to use the REST API to navigate to files that they have permissions to in the same way as they can in the GUI. Use of the REST API requires knowledge of permission paths that use of the GUI does not.

Not seeing files along the path that they have no access to is desired. Not seeing intermediate parent directories of their permission paths is a functional difference between the GUI and the REST API, and we would like to know how to have the REST API return the intermediate parent directories so that it can be used for exploratory navigation in the same fashion.

Request:

Use of the GET /api/storage/\{repoKey}/\{folder-path} REST endpoint should function more like the UI drill-down. Ideally:
 * Navigation to a folder-path where permissions have been granted should return a 200 and a list of the elements in that location. This is current behavior.
 * Navigation to a folder-path where permissions have not been granted, but is a parent path step to a location where permissions have been granted, should return a 200 and a list of child folders that could be traversed to eventually reach the granted permission folder-path.
 * Navigation to a folder-path where no permissions have been granted and that is not a step to a deeper granted permission should return 404 (preferred) or 403 (current behavior).

column1: Deleting 'Server Path For Backup' results in backup to "/" instead of $ARTIFACTORY_HOME
column39:
Steps to reproduce:
1. Install Artifactory. It has enabled by defauly daily-backup to $ARTIFACTORY_HOME/backup/[backup_key].
2. In Artifactory UI, update the "Server Path For Backup" to any location & save.
3. In Artifactory UI, update the "Server Path For Backup" to be empty (as it is by default). Expectation is that now it will behave as by default. Instead, backups are going to "/" folder in the server.
Reason is this entry that is being written to config descriptor of the backup:
{code:java}
            <dir></dir>
{code}

As a workaround, in order to restore the backups to go to default location, the above row can be removed from the Config Descriptor.

column1: Created and last modified values will not updated after move or copy function
column39:
Currently when we copy artifacts from one repository to another the information of the last modified & created will not update. 

Steps to reproduce:

1) Create a local repo A in Artifactory

2) Create a local repo B in Artifactory

3) Deploy a file to A, note the value for the "created" and "last modified" timestamp properties

4) Wait 30 seconds

5) Now copy the file from A to B by using the [Copy Item|http://copy%20itemhttps//www.jfrog.com/confluence/display/RTF/Artifactory+REST+API#ArtifactoryRESTAPI-CopyItem] REST service (or via the UI)

6) Check the "created" and "last modified" timestamps for the file copied to B, you'll see that the timestamps are the same as for file A despite the file in B being created later.

column252: 28/May/19 3:24 PM;francois.ritaly;Providing some context why this bug is problematic in my case: I use the "created" and "last modified" file timestamps to track file promotions (across repositories) and file replications (across a network of Artifactory servers). Not being able to know when a file was created in Artifactory, makes it impossible to know exactly how long it took to replicate that file to a target server (via a pull replication).
column253: 18/Jun/19 4:01 PM;francois.ritaly;This JIRA should be changed from "Improvement" to "Bug" because this is clearly a bug.
column254:
18/Jun/19 4:39 PM;damiend; 

In JFrog's REST documentation for the Copy Item REST call it is stated:
{code:java}
Copy Item

Description: Copy an artifact or a folder to the specified destination. Supported by local repositories only.
Optionally suppress cross-layout module path translation during copy.
You can test the copy using a dry run.
Copy item behaves similarly to a standard file system and supports renames. If the target path does not exist, the source item is copied and optionally renamed. Otherwise, if the target exists and it is a directory,
the source is copied and placed under the target directory.
 {code}
 

In standard filesystem copy the file in the destination folder will have a different creation date than in the source folder.

One can choose to *preserve* the creation date with an optional flag to cp command:
{code:java}

   -p    Cause cp to preserve the following attributes of each source file in the copy: modification time, access time, file flags, file mode, user ID, and
           group ID, as allowed by permissions.  Access Control Lists (ACLs) and Extended Attributes (EAs), including resource forks, will also be preserved.
{code}
 

We appreciate that it would probably not be a runner for you to change the current behaviour as you may have customers that have built tooling around the creation date *not* being changed.

However, without having an accurate creation date on files that are promoted to repositories you cannot tell with any accuracy how long they have then taken to be replicated from one Artifactory instance to another in that repository.

 

Would you consider having the date behaviour change as an optional system flag at startup i.e if set then have copy item resultin new datestamp?
column255:
17/Mar/20 8:58 AM;francois.ritaly;Found another instance where this bug creates an issue for our end users.

Because files copied / moved in repositories don't have their "created" / "modified" dates set correctly, it's not possible for end users to infer what the latest version of a file is from the files' created dates.

This typically happens in this scenario:
- A file *F1* is published to a repository *A* (its created / modified dates (created(F1) and modified(F1)) are correct, no bug here)
- A file *F2* is published to a repository *B* (its created / modified dates (created(F2) and modified(F2)) are correct, no bug here)

Since F1 was created before F2, we have:

{noformat}
created(F1) < created(F2)
{noformat}

- The file *F1* (from *A*) is copied to *B* as *F3* (here the bug occurs and we have created(F3) = created(F1)). The correct situation would be to have created(F3) > created(F2) > created(F1) because this represents the order of creation for those files.

If I run an AQL query against B listing all the files, sorted by *descending* created date, I end up with F2 as being the newest file because  created(F1) = created(F3) and created(F2) > created(F1)

You can see how this bug is problematic: created dates *CANNOT* be used to infer latest published files when files have been copied / moved.
column257:
23/Mar/20 10:22 AM;francois.ritaly;At this stage, the only workaround I can think of (the one we rolled out internally at Workday) consists in the following:
- Implement a custom AF plugin to set 2 custom properties (say "meta.created" and "meta.modified") for persisting the correct created and modified dates upon file creation, copy or move. 
- Install the plugin in AF and let it populate the 2 custom properties for new files published, copied or moved for a while. If necessary, roll out some automation to populate the custom properties for all the items already present in AF
- Change all your AQL queries (using the standard fields "created" and "modified") to also return the 2 new custom properties (be careful: when including custom properties in an AQL query, AF will *only* return the items which defines the properties ! There is a risk of regression here as querying the 2 properties will now return less records than before. That's why the 2 properties should ideally be populated for all the items in Artifactory, not just the new ones). If your code uses the "List Files" REST call to list items, the fix is a bit more convoluted: 1) either you convert your List Files call into an AQL query (see above) 2) or after issuing the List Files call, you need to run an extra AQL query just for retrieving the 2 custom properties and "merge" the result of both queries in-memory.

The workaround requires a lot of work...

I'm all hears if someone can come up with a simpler solution to this issue.
column258:
29/Jun/20 3:34 PM;francois.ritaly;Bumping this ticket because I recently hit this issue again and I hope JFrog will understand the huge pain this bug is causing to end users.

*What I want:* Identify the most recent file updated in a repository. 

Normally, I should be able to use an AQL query, list all the files by descending modified date, limit the result to one and (quickly and efficiently) get my answer.

However the files copied via the REST API don't have a reliable created / modified date (because of this bug). So, the workaround solution is to use a custom property to store the correct modified date (see previous comment). But this yields another problem: once you start using custom properties, you can no longer sort the AQL results (that's a limitation of AQL: sort doesn't work on custom properties). 

This means that the only way to identify the most recent modified file is to:
* List *ALL* the files from the repository with their custom properties
* Sort the files on the client-side
* Resolve the most recent file

We have repositories with A LOT of artifacts, having to do this just to identify the most recent file is ludicrous and extremely inefficient in terms of DB load, network traffic, CPU and memory consumption.

I hope JFrog will seriously consider fixing this bug because not being able to trust file's timestamps in Artifactory is just unacceptable.

column1: Nuget: access token for repository without anonymous access?
column39:
I am using a nuget repository without anonymous access. Following the "set me up" documentation on the artifactory front page, I entered my (encrypted) password into the local nuget.config file.

There are two problems with this approach:
 * my CI servers need access to the repository, but I do not want to put my encrypted private password into either the repository or the CI server configuration, both of which is visible to others
 * even if I'd be ok with the encrypted password, this does not work on docker because nuget does not support encrypted passwords on linux.

I know that artifactory has access tokens, but how do I specify a token in nuget.config?

column1: Add cache fs details to Storage Summary REST API
column39:
Currently, when you retrieve the Storage Summary Info via REST API, you don't get the details of the cache fs (if you have it configured), while in UI (Admin --> Storage) you do see it.

Artifactory should show the cache fs details (Folder location, Usage, Total size) in the output of the REST call.

To reproduce:
- Set Artifactory binarystore.xml to:
{code}
<config version="v1">
    <chain>
        <provider id="cache-fs" type="cache-fs">
            <provider id="file-system" type="file-system"/>
        </provider>
    </chain>

    <provider id="file-system" type="file-system">
        <baseDataDir>/Users/test/artifactory-pro-6.10.0/data</baseDataDir>
        <fileStoreDir>filestore</fileStoreDir>
        <tempDir>temp</tempDir>
    </provider>

    <provider id="cache-fs" type="cache-fs">
        <cacheProviderDir>/Users/teset/artifactory-pro-6.10.0/cachedata/</cacheProviderDir>
        <maxCacheSize>1000000000</maxCacheSize>
    </provider>
</config>
{code}
- Start Articactory and run the following REST API:
{code}
curl -uadmin:password http://localhost:8081/artifactory/api/storageinfo
{code}

column1: Enhanced Xray webhook payload
column39:
Hi,

Today only email notifications of policy rule display link to the scanned component and link to the triggered watch.

In our team we would like those links in webhook notifications with something like *watch_url* and *issues.impacted_artifacts[*].url* new fields :
{code:java}
{
  "created": "2019-04-24T12:57:22.237366105Z",
  "top_severity": "High",
  "watch_name": "atom",
  "watch_url": "https://xray.example.com/web/#/watches/atom/edit",
  "policy_name": "atom-sec-policy",
  "issues": [
    {
      "severity": "High",
      "type": "security",
      "provider": "JFrog",
      "created": "2019-02-17T09:32:55.548Z",
      "summary": "A prototype pollution vulnerability was found in lodash <4.17.11 where the functions merge, mergeWith, and defaultsDeep can be tricked into adding or modifying properties of Object.prototype.",
      "description": "A prototype pollution vulnerability was found in lodash <4.17.11 where the functions merge, mergeWith, and defaultsDeep can be tricked into adding or modifying properties of Object.prototype.",
      "impacted_artifacts": [

column1: Add support to properly proxy private AWS ECRs
column39:
Add support to properly proxy private AWS ECRs.

 

AWS private ECR [requires authentication|https://docs.aws.amazon.com/AmazonECR/latest/userguide/Registries.html] but only grants a username/password that is valid for 12 hours. This means Artifactory can only proxy the site for 12 hours before the configuration has to be updated with a new set of credentials. 

 

The improvement request is to add a mechanism for Artifactory to automatically keep the credentials updated.

column1: Enable storing artifact at s3 root level
column39:
Hi,

According to [AWS|https://docs.aws.amazon.com/AmazonS3/latest/dev/request-rate-perf-considerations.html], we should distribute object keys in different prefixes to achieve best s3 through put. Artifactory does not support storing artifacts at root level of S3, this means all artifacts are put in the same s3 partition and we cannot fully utilize s3 capacity. Please allow artifacts to store artifacts at root level.

 

I have verified that {{<path></path>}} in blobstore.xml will make artifactory to store artifacts under {{filestore/}}. And artifactory does not like {{<path>/</path>}} at all.

 More info about optimizing s3 throughput: https://aws.amazon.com/blogs/aws/amazon-s3-performance-tips-tricks-seattle-hiring-event/

Cheers,

column1: Export / backup to filestore
column39:
Given the filestore is more or less necessary for Artifactory to function and the filestore is often going to be larger and more reliable compared to local disk it'd be really convenient for Artifactory to be able to store exports / backups to the filestore (as well as restore from).

This would eliminate the need to run backups or explicit exports and then orchestrate the backing up of that data outside the product.

column1: Separate deploy/cache permission
column39:
In a setup, where two big features of Artifactory are used:
 * multi-site topology for pull/push replication;
 * manage permission to allow users mananage their repository

the consolidation of deploy+cache permissions is extremely unhandy.

Assume, we create a pull-replicated repository set up, so on one site, there is local and multiple remotes, all contained in one user-facing virtual repository. Then, we create a permission target *pt1* that contains all of these repositories, and give manage permission to *user1*. 

*user1* wants to give *developer1* write access to the repository, and *reader1* read access to the repository. So he gives deploy/cache to *developer1* and read to *reader1*. It results in *reader1* not being able to get any artifacts that were not previously cached from remote repositories. In this case, either you give *reader1* deploy/cache (and he'll write stuff into your local repo, so it's really not a solution), or split permission target *pt1* into two permission targets, *pt2* containing only local repository and *pt3* containing related remotes. And now, it's a big mess, because to grant read to any additional user, *user1*, manager of these repositories, has to add new users to both *pt2* and *pt3*. 

This is  both counterintuitive and unhandy.

The solution I see for this would be splitting deploy/cache to two separate permissions, so the granularity not only kept, but also improved.

column1: Storage summary: change optimization % to increase, or replace optimization % with disk saved %
column39:
Currently, if you have an artifacts size of say 1 Gb with binary size of 1 GB (meaning there are no multiple references for any artifacts), the storage summary says the optimization % is 100%. However, when copying an artifact to another repository, the optimization % decreases (say to 99%). This behavior is counter intuitive with the tooltip though (The ratio of Binaries Size to Artifacts Size. This reflects how much the usage of storage in your system has been reduced by Artifactory using checksum storage.) By the tooltip, that means that the system storage has been reduced by 99%, which doesn't make sense. 

Instead of decreasing, the optimization % should increase. For example, if you have binary size of 1TB, and artifact size of 2 TB, then it might make more sense if the optimization is 200%, where 100% means no change.

Or, instead of optimization, it could be disk saved percent.

column1: Artifactory access logs should log more events
column39:
The Artifactory access logs are useful for auditing, but are incomplete for determining which actions were taken.

They should log copied artifacts and should also log overwrite events.

If not as a separate event, overwrites should be logged as a delete + deploy.

 

Additionally, logging the filesize/checksum (if available at deploy time) could be useful.

column1: Improve the Puppet Virtual metadata calculation mechanism
column39:
+*Summary:*+

Currently, the virtual repository metadata calculation partially relies on using an internal cache for an aggregated virtual repo metadata calculation.

This can cause some confusion and 404s responses for requests and successfully deployed Puppet modules (packages) to the underlying local repositories. Meaning requesting those will work *right after* deploying the packages to the local repositories, *however*, it will only work after the *internal virtual cache* has been timeout'ed and rebuilt. 

At the *worst case scenario* and with the set 30 minutes default, users can wait that period of time until a package is made downloadable from the virtual puppet repo.    

+*Mitigation:*+

Set *artifactory.puppet.reindex.period=1* under  $ARTIFACTORY_HOME/etc/artifactory.system.properties file and restart the instance.


+*Steps to reproduce this behavior:*+

1. Have a local and an aggregating virtual puppet repos.
2. Try to request the package below (still undeployed) from the puppet *virtual* repo - expect the expected 404:

*$ puppet module install  --module_repository=http://admin:password@localhost:8082/artifactory/api/puppet/puppet andreik-my_module --debug*

3. Use this script to build and deploy Puppet packages to puppet-local

{code}
RUN_TIMES=$1
i=0
mkdir my_module

while [ $i -lt $RUN_TIMES ]; do

  VERSION=$i
  echo $VERSION

cat << EOF > my_module/metadata.json
{"name":"andreik-my_module","version":"0.1.$VERSION","author":"andreik","summary":"","license":"Apache-2.0","source":"","dependencies":[],"operatingsystem_support":[{"operatingsystem":"CentOS","operatingsystemrelease":["7"]},{"operatingsystem":"OracleLinux","operatingsystemrelease":["7"]}],"requirements":[{"name":"puppet","version_requirement":">= 4.10.0 < 7.0.0"}],"pdk-version":"1.9.0","template-url":"file:///opt/puppetlabs/pdk/share/cache/pdk-templates.git","template-ref":"1.9.0-0-g7281db5"}
EOF

  cd my_module
  echo 'yes' | pdk build
  curl -uadmin:password -XPUT -T pkg/andreik-my_module-0.1.$VERSION.tar.gz "http://localhost:8082/artifactory/puppet-local/andreik-my_module-0.1.$VERSION.tar.gz"
  cd ..
  rm my_module/metadata.json

  i=`expr $i + 1`

done
{code}

4. Now, even though the package tar ball is available and visible from the virtual repo, it will only be available after 30 minutes from the time you have attempted step #2 above. *From the local puppet repo - it will available immediately*

column1: The Promote Docker Image service should allow you to set properties
column39:
Currently, the REST Promote Docker Image service does not allow you to set properties for Docker images. This makes it difficult to introduce an effective retention policy for artefacts based on property checking. 
The introduction of an additional "properties" parameter for this service (analogous to the promotion of builds) would allow the introduction of information such as the date of the promotion at the time of deployment, the test environment on which the image was installed.

This information will facilitate the introduction of an effective artefact retention policy and image auditing

column1: AQL query need to show download stats that normalize the counts across package versions
column39:
Current AQL Query:

When we run the below query for "npm-local" repository that gets the number of downloads,

Eg:-
 *items.find(*
  *{*
       *"repo": "npm-local",*
       *"name" : {"$match": "*.tgz"},*
       *"stat.downloads":\{"$gt":"10000"}*
  *}*
 *).*
 *include("name","stat.downloads").*
 *limit(500)*

We get the below output that shows download count of individual version for the package "bh-agent"

*{*
 *"results" : [ {*
  *"name" : "bh-agent-1.0.0.tgz",*
  *"stats" : [ {*
    *"downloads" : 18003*
  *} ]*
 *},{*
  *"name" : "bh-agent-1.1.0.tgz",*
  *"stats" : [ {*
    *"downloads" : 13676*
  *} ]*
 *},{*
  *"name" : "bh-logger-2.2.0.tgz",*
  *"stats" : [ {*
    *"downloads" : 16274*
  *} ]*
But the feature request is 

*"name" : "bh-agent-",*
  *"stats" : [ {*
    *"downloads" : 31679*
  *}* 
As above, what we are looking is to get all the download count by the pathname of the package instead of getting separate downloads for each version in the path. 
 
h6. How to reproduce:

We tried on our end to fetch number of downloads for content-disposition artifact with the below command:
 *"curl -uadmin:password -XPOST -H 'Content-Type: text/plain' [http://34.66.29.243:8081/artifactory/api/search/aql] --data-binary 'items.find({"repo":"npm-remote-cache", "type":"file","name":{"$match":"{color:#ff0000}content-dispo{color}*.tgz"}}).include("path", "stat.downloads", "name")' | jq '.results'| jq '[ .[] | {path: .path, name: .name, downloads: .stats[0].downloads}]' |  jq 'group_by(.path) | map({"path": .[0].path, "downloads": (group_by(.name) | map(

{"key":.[0].name, "value":.[0].downloads}

) | from_entries )})'*

we got the following result:

*[*

  *{*

    *    **"path"**:* "content-disposition/-"*,*

    *    **"downloads"**: {*

      *      **"content-disposition-0.5.2.tgz"**:* 2*,*

      *      **"content-disposition-0.5.3.tgz"**:* 2

    *}*

  *}*

*]*

 

+Feature request:+
Instead, the feature request is to get the following result:
for example:-

*[*

  *{*
 *"name" : "content-disposition-",*
  *"stats" : [ {*
    *"downloads" : 4*
  *}* 
    *}*

  *}*

*]*

column1: Prefetch / pre-check remote sources
column39:
When querying an artifact from a remote repository, the artifact may either be cached and valid or not. Once the cached version is invalidated, clients have to wait for it to be checked/fetched before Artifactory can reply which again can sum up if a whole bunch of artifacts is typically queried at about the same time, thus also invalidated at the same time.

Given the case an artifact is queried while the cached version is valid but about to expire soon, Artifactory could respond immediately but start a background process that checks the remote data for validity. Thus preparing for the next query to come and hopefully (about) always respoding from cache.

column1: Search in equipollent repositories in parallel
column39:
When requesting a maven SNAPSHOT artifact from a virtual repository containing several repositories, these repositories are searched for the latest version of that artifact. Having a lot of remote sources that makes the resolving process quite slow as response times add up.

As (and only if) all the sources are capable of providing some version and only the latest one is about to win, at least the HTTP HEAD requests could be done in parallel so that the overall process takes at most as long as the slowest response.

column1: If the database is offline when artifactory starts it will not recover
column39:
If the database is offline when I start artifactory, then artifactory's context will not be properly deployed. This means that, when the database comes back up, artifactory won't recover automatically.

That can lead to downtime even if artifactory is controlled by systemd or any other supervisor tool. It seems that artifactory's docker image tries to mitigate that by checking if the database is there before starting. However, if the database becomes unreachable after the last check and when tomcat decides to deploy artifactory and access, the same issue can happen; potentially leaving artifactory in a broken state until someone manually fixes it.

One possible solution would be to make tomcat die if the loading the contexts fails.

column1: Improve the npm Set Me Up documentation for users whose usernames are email addresses
column39:
Users whose Artifactory username contains an "@" character - which of course includes any enterprise using email addresses as usernames - cannot use 'npm login' as doing so returns the following npm error: "npm WARN Name may not contain non-url-safe chars"

Initially I was going to request the ability to update the text in the 'Set Me Up' guide ourselves, but really this would be more simply addressed if the text was updated for us by JFrog.

Currently there are two options presented by the Set Me Up page for npm:
 - npm login
 - basic authentication

At the moment, many users with "@" characters in their username will simply try the first option, see that it does not work, and request help / suggest the Set Me Up documentation is incorrect / broken.

It would be useful to add a 3rd option here:
 - npm login
 - using the /api/npm/auth endpoint (with "curl -u <USERNAME>:<API_KEY> [https://url/artifactory/api/npm/auth/]" to get a block to add directly into .npmrc)
 - basic authentication

Could the page be updated to explain that "npm login" doesn't work with usernames containing an "@" character, and to suggest and alternative (e.g. the /api/npm/auth endpoint) if it does. As Artifactory does know the username of the user, it could automatically determine that this is the case, though of course if the functionality should change in the future and allow "@" characters this functionality or advise should change with it.

This functionality would be even better if credentials could be filled in for SSO users by implementing https://www.jfrog.com/jira/browse/RTFACT-17425

column1: Artifactory CLI -Allow setting values ​​of properties for the promotion of build
column39:
Currently, the build promotion command does not allow setting properties for artifacts contained in the build.
This should be done in a similar way to Build Promotion rest endpoint.
Business case / use case:
The introduction of this new functionality will enable the introduction of artifact retention based on property values ​​for artifacts.

As part of the process of installing artifacts on the test or production environment, the build will be promoted to the appropriate repository. For artifacts, the property specifying the date of installation and flags indicating which environment artifacts have been installed will be added. Based on these properties, an effective retention policy for artifacts based on metadata assigned to artifacts can be entered for each repository.

We want to use this functionality especially during the promotion of builds containing docker images.
Currently, it is not possible to enter property values ​​when the docker-push CLI command is performed

column1: Sorting is unreliable, can't find latest/highest version of Maven Artifact in UI
column39:
When searching for a Maven Artifact in the UI (although this problem may apply to other types of searches as well), it is not straightforward to find the highest version or latest version of the specific artifact. Finding the highest version of an artifact via the UI is a very common/frequent use case.

For one thing, depending on the search, various artifacts can be mixed together in the search results, and the names of the artifacts are often truncated with an ellipsis "..." due to width constraints. This makes it difficult to tell which artifact each row describes. It would be much nicer if the results were grouped by groupId:artifactId (this is not possible in the UI right now, you can only manually group by either artifactId or by groupId). See [https://search.maven.org/] for an example.

Besides the fact that the UI doesn't know how to sort by version number, as described in https://www.jfrog.com/jira/browse/RTFACT-10694, there is also the problem that even if the relative sort order was correct, the user will still not necessarily be shown the item with the highest or lowest value for that column. It seems like this happens when there are large number of search results.

Expected results: When performing a search for a Maven Artifact, the results should be grouped by groupId:artifactId coordinate, and the highest version (according to [https://maven.apache.org/pom.html#Version_Order_Specification] ) should be displayed prominently without additional user interaction. If the user has the option to sort by version, the UI should present the highest/lowest version (according to [https://maven.apache.org/pom.html#Version_Order_Specification] ) from the entire contents of Artifactory, not an arbitrary/unpredictable/inscrutable subset of the contents. All sort columns, not just Version, should work this way.

column1: Build-info repository can not be replicated when using mesh topology
column39:
Customers using mesh topology, can't replicate 'build-info' repository without avoiding bi-directional interference.

 According to the Replication Topology whitepaper ([https://jfrog.com/whitepaper/replication-using-artifactory-to-manage-binaries-across-multi-site-topologies/]), push replication setups require multiple local repositories to handle the different incoming streams of data:

Artifactory A       Artifactory B

Repo A         ->     Repo A  | Virtual containing A and B
Repo B         <-     Repo B  |

Otherwise you get looping replication, which will cause deployments on one instance to constantly replicate in a loop.

As of Artifactory 6.6, Build information is kept in a special repository called "*artifactory-build-info*". In the past, there was a user plugin called [Build Sync |https://github.com/jfrog/artifactory-user-plugins/blob/master/build/buildSync/buildSync.groovy]that allowed Artifactory instances to replication build information.

This plugin is now deprecated, and the official way to replicate build info metadata is to use Repository Replications. However, repository replication do not support looping replications. There is also no way to create another artifactory-build-info repository to create a Mesh Topology setup.

There is no way to have a Mesh Topology for build info repositories in Artifactory yet.

 

Some possible solutions would be to allow the creation of Buildinfo repositories. Another solution would be to add a special replication setup for build info replications.

07/Jun/19 9:09 PM;patrickr;The below workaround turns out to cause looping push replications, and is not recommended

 

-A workaround if you need to sync multiple Artifactories is to use generic remote repositories to pull down the buildinfo json files, then use a plugin to push the JSON data to the artifactory-build-info repository-

-It involves 4 steps:-
 -1.Create a remote generic repository going to the remote artifactory-build-info repo-
 -2. Set up pull replications-
 -3. Install the [remoteBackup plugin|https://github.com/jfrog/artifactory-user-plugins/tree/54406c38b1c7f91c265ab11cc38aefeb45cbdd4b/storage/remoteBackup], with this JSON-

-{"build-pull-cache": "artifactory-build-info"}-

-4. Run the pull replication manually or let the cron run-

-This pulls down the JSON data, and pushes it into the buildinfo repo like it's a normal build. The metadata shows up in the builds browser and everything-

column1: artifactory.key propagation should keep a backup
column39:
Currently, if the artifactory.key on the primary node of an HA cluster gets somehow changed / corrupted, the change will automatically be propagated to all nodes of the cluster, which will resolve in losing the correct key unless you have a backup.

This improvement request, is that upon propagation of the key, to leave a backup on the target nodes.
As an example, when performing "Decrypt"/"Encrypt" operation, a backup us being saved in the filesystem.

column1: .ddeb files are not indexed in Debian repos
column39:
Packages containing debug symbols follow the naming convention $package-dbgsym_$version_$arch.ddeb

Currently Artifactory fails to index those files because their file extension does not match ".deb".

A current workaround is to rename .ddeb to .deb.  Is there a better workaround (a knob to tweak on the Artifactory server to have it index both .deb and .ddeb?

The best solution is for Artifactory to handle .ddeb files out of the box.

See [https://wiki.debian.org/AutomaticDebugPackages] and http://ddebs.ubuntu.com/pool/main/a/a11y-profile-manager/

column1: Allow for bootstrapped admin accounts
column39:
My firm wishes never to use passwords or API keys. No basic auth. We use client certificates + HTTP SSO in order to manage identity. Rather than needing to setup admin accounts after startup and needing to setup at least one with a password it'd be preferable that an account or account names could be provided to Artifactory in some way (config file, wizard at startup, ?) which would setup new admin accounts (assuming the accounts don't already exist) without the need to have an existing / default admin account.

 

This would really only be useful if other components communications between products could be made to work without basic auth (Artifactory replication, Mission Control <-> Artifactory). 

 

See: https://www.jfrog.com/jira/browse/RTFACT-15076

column1: Assume offline doesn't work for slow PyPI servers
column39:
I've configured a remote PyPI repo pointing to another artifactory which was very slow. That caused read time outs while retrieving package index (either /simple/ or /simple/<pkg-name>/). However, the repo was never set as offline. That's particularly bad when that remote is part of a virtual repo, as all requests to that virtual repo will wait until the connection to the remote server times out before they respond.

h2. How to reproduce

It's easy to reproduce the issue using toxy (https://github.com/h2non/toxy). All you need to do is point the proxy to another artifactory instance and set the latency high (eg. 1500ms, if that's your socket timeout configuration in your remote repo). This is what my toxy configuration looks like:

{code}
const toxy = require('toxy')

const proxy = toxy()
const rules = proxy.rules
const poisons = proxy.poisons

proxy
  .all('/*')
  .poison(poisons.slowRead({ chunk: 1, threshold: 2000 }))
  .poison(toxy.poisons.latency(1500))
  .withRule(rules.method('GET'))
  .forward('http://artifactory2:8081')

proxy.listen(3000)
console.log('Server listening on port:', 3000)
{code}

I've set a test virtual repo containing a local repo and a remote pointing to http://artifactory2:3000 (I bound the proxy locally on that port). After doing that this curl would always take more than 1.5s:

{code}time curl http://artifactory/artifactory/api/pypi/test/simple/{code}

Artifactory configuration:

{code}
$ curl http://artifactory/artifactory/api/repositories/test
{
  "key" : "test",
  "packageType" : "pypi",
  "description" : "",
  "repositories" : [ "local-python", "remote-python" ],
  "rclass" : "virtual"
}
$ curl http://artifactory/artifactory/api/repositories/remote-python
{
  "key" : "remote-python",
  "packageType" : "pypi",
  "description" : "",
  "url" : "http://artifactory2:3000/artifactory/pypi/api/local-python/",
  "rclass" : "remote"
}
$ curl http://artifactory/artifactory/api/repositories/local-python
{
  "key" : "local-python",
  "packageType" : "pypi",
  "description" : "",
  "rclass" : "local"
}
$ curl http://artifactory2/artifactory/api/repositories/local-python
{
  "key" : "local-python",
  "packageType" : "pypi",
  "description" : "",
  "rclass" : "local"
}
{code}

h2. Logs

As you can see, there's never a message in the logs about setting the remote index offline:

{noformat}
2019-03-11 11:57:14,715 [http-nio-8081-exec-5] [ERROR] (o.a.r.RemoteRepoBase:757) - IO error while trying to download resource 'remote-python:.pypi/simple.html': java.net.SocketTimeoutException: Read timed out
2019-03-11 11:57:14,716 [http-nio-8081-exec-5] [ERROR] (o.a.a.p.r.r.PypiRemoteIndexProvider:135) - Could not retrieve remote index from http://artifactory2:3000/artifactory/api/pypi/local-python/simple/:
Read timed out
2019-03-11 11:57:21,896 [http-nio-8081-exec-9] [ERROR] (o.a.r.RemoteRepoBase:757) - IO error while trying to download resource 'remote-python:.pypi/simple.html': java.net.SocketTimeoutException: Read timed out
2019-03-11 11:57:21,897 [http-nio-8081-exec-9] [ERROR] (o.a.a.p.r.r.PypiRemoteIndexProvider:135) - Could not retrieve remote index from http://artifactory2:3000/artifactory/api/pypi/local-python/simple/:
Read timed out
{noformat}

column1: REST endpoint do get last build number
column39:
Introducing the correct CI / CD Integration requires knowing the last number of the given build. We currently use 2 steps for this purpose
1. Downloading all the numbers of a given build using Rest point. Https://www.jfrog.com/confluence/display/RTF/Artifactory+REST+API#ArtifactoryRESTAPI-BuildRuns
2. Calculating the maximum number from the downloaded list.

Such a solution with a large number of builds is not optimal in terms of performance. It also hinders the design and implementation of the CI process using Artifactory CLI
