column1: Could non-admin users be given permission to re-index repositories for which they have write access?
column39:
Could non-admin users be given permission to re-index repositories for which they have write access?

Admins of our service currently have to field all requests for re-indexing as normal users, even if they are write members of their repository, cannot do it. I am not sure why this would need to be an admin-only duty - re-indexing should not be required in normal circumstances, but sometimes users want to give it a 'kick', and this is often their first thought when diagnosing incorrect package listings.

Ideally users with write permission to a repository would be able to issue the re-index through the Web UI or the Rest API, though even if they were limited to the Rest API this would be an improvement. https://www.jfrog.com/confluence/display/RTF/Artifactory+REST+API#ArtifactoryRESTAPI-CalculateCondaRepositoryMetadata

column1: Separate WebUIs for Management and End User Access
column39:
Least priviledge is a security best practice. RBAC is a huge help in adhering to least priviledge, but RBAC is only as good as the application that hosts it. Traditional Layer 3 dataflow priviledge practices, like Firewalling, VLANing, etc. benefit immensely from an application being able to expose a separate web interface for priviledged, administrative tasks, published on a separate port from a non-prviledged, end-user-only interface.

The ask is for Artifactory to offer the capability to, at configuration time, publish an additional stripped-down WebUI on a separate port from the existing service, solely to handle end-user tasking such as: browsing repositories, pushing builds, downloading artifacts, utilizing "Set Me Up" features. While removing the ability to preform any administrative tasks completely from the stripped-down UI. A bonus ask would be for the ability to, via the admin interface in the existing WebUI, control which features are exposed on the stripped-down UI.

Features that are not exposed on the requested stripped-down UI should also not be valid REST endpoints for the backing web REST interface.

column1: Batched Artifactory GC (garbage collection) improvement
column39:
Summary:

Request to add batched SQL queries for as part of Artifactory's GC run.

column1: A user should have the option to use their API key to propagate 'Set Me Up' settings
column39:
Currently users who log in via SAML and click 'Set Me Up' are only getting partially filled in instructions. Specifically, their API key, which is known to Artifactory, cannot be added to the snippets in the same way that a password can.

Once a user has logged in via SAML, their Profile page does not require a password to unlock in order to view or change the API key (because Artifactory has no way of validating the password), so I cannot think of a security reason why a user would not be able to populate their API key in the 'Set Me Up' tool

We specifically don't want users to use their password or encrypted password when authenticating via the command line, so ideally the current 'USERNAME:PASSWORD' instructions in the default text could be replaced by 'USERNAME:AUTH', with 'AUTH' being replaced by their API key (encoded as appropriate for tools such as npm) when they chose to do so. Perhaps the user would have the option to add their password, encrypted password or API key (and admins could switch off any of these) - so for us we'd only allow an API key to be added (if present of course).

This functionality need not be limited to SAML users. A confirmatory password could be required for non-SAML users before adding their API key, in the same as is currently required for non-SAML users adding passwords.

column1: Improve the time/efficiency of the "Artifact Count / Size" query in the UI
column39:
Currently, when having a big repository with a lot of artifacts, running the "Artifact Count / Size"  count can take a while. Need to check if it's possible to improve the query in order to have better results (speed wise). 

The SQL query that is being used is in Derby:
{code:java}
SELECT COUNT(*) AS file_count, SUM(bin_length) AS total_size FROM nodes WHERE node_type=1 and repo = 'repoName' 

{code}
 

Here is an example of running the query:

[http://recordit.co/KmzuaW92g0]

 

Most likely that this query is related to the following factors:
 # DB type.
 # DB machine specs.
 # Load on the DB at the time the query was executed.

column1: Artifactory should support deploying packages to repositories under a user specified folder structure
column39:
Artifactory should support deploying packages to repositories under a user specified folder structure. Currently only a few repository types like Yum, docker, NPM support deploying packages under a folder structure and they are able to generate metadata that references the correct path of the package in the repository.

Generally the deployment can be done to any folder structure in a repository, but the metadata will be mismatched and does not reference the package properly. Due to this the client will not be able to resolve the packages that are deployed to a certain folder in Artifactory.

column1: Allow generating credentials file for the gem repository when using the client cert authentication via cURL
column39:
Allow generating credentials file for the gem repository when using the client cert authentication via cURL to a Artifactory that is setup with HTTP SSO. Currently the REST API to create the credentials file for Rubygems repository only works with username and password.

With cURL it is possible to authenticate to Artifactory that is using HTTP SSO if you pass the cert and key. This means in Artifactory we should be able to get the HTTP SSO user based on the successful auth request with cURL and generate the "credentials" file for the Rubygems repositories. For example below is an API call for generating the "credentials" file when using HTTP SSO method, but please note that this currently fails.

 

curl –key key.pem --cert cert.pem https://<server_name>/api/gems/gems/api/v1/api_key.yaml

column1: Password label for replication should say "Password or API Key"
column39: API keys are ideally suited for replication, we should show that the password field in the UI can also be an API key. Just a change to the label is needed.

column1: Generated proxy config should include Artifactory version
column39:
When Artifactory generates reverse proxy settings, they are generated from a specific version, but upgrades, including Tomcat, may change behavior after that time. It would be useful if this part of the proxy config:

 

###########################################################

this configuration was generated by JFrog Artifactory ##
 ###########################################################

 

...also included the version of Artifactory the config was generated from.

column1: properties are not being replicated to the target repository when the target repo happens to be a virtual repository that contains a default deployment repository
column39:
properties are not being replicated to the target repository when the target repo happens to be a virtual repository that contains a default deployment repository.
 # Setup Push replication from a local repository to a virtual repository that contains a default deployment repo. In my case i tried with docker repository
 # Start the replication event. Once the replication is complete you will notice that the target local repository that is part of the virtual repository has artifacts. However these artifacts are missing properties.

If we are allowing replication to a virtual repository that contains a local repo as default deployment repository, then we should replicate the properties as well.

column1: enforcing naming conventions on repo names
column39:
we have a very opinionated view on naming convention for repositories but we don't "help" our customers.

We can add a feature (can be opt-in or opt-out) that will generate the repo name based on the product/team name + the stage name (optionally) and the name will be generated with the repo type and the artifactory "site" name.

Alternatively, we can allow the admin to add a regex to enforce his policy but that might create a problem in the UI / REST operations when trying to create the repo.

 

This might have implications on other UCs (like access federation or replication) that are based on repo names as their input

column1: /usr/lib/systemd/system/artifactory.service marked executable; please remove executable permission bits
column39: The systemd unit for artifactory installed at /usr/lib/systemd/system/artifactory.service is erroneously marked as executable. It should not be marked executable. systemd logs a complaint whenever it sees this.

column1: Self diagnosting tool
column39: Allow Artifactory to automatically collect certain *debug logs, histogram and thread dumps* in case of an event (OOM, heartbeat failure, error message)

column1: Typo in the misc folder
column39:
In the misc folder, the nginx temple file should be NGINX.txt instead of NGNIX.txt

 

/artifactory-pro/misc/tomcat/NGNIX.txt

column1: After upgrading to version 6.7.2 Artifactory is generating an invalid base URL for redirects on pypi links
column39:
After upgrading to version 6.7.2 Artifactory is generating an invalid base URL for redirects on pypi links:

Steps to Reproduce:
 # Setup Artifactory with Nginx as reverse proxy without the context /artifactory
 # Remove the proxy_set_header    X-Artifactory-Override-Base-Url from the Nginx 
 # In Artifactory set the custom base URL in the General settings which is responsible for generating the links in set me up and other redirects
 # The custom base URL is set to just http://<server_name> without the /artifactory context
 # Navigate to http://<server_name>/api/pypi/pypi-remote/simple/accc/ and you will notice that you are redirected to http://<server_name>/artifactory/api/pypi/pypi-remote/simple/accc/. This results in 404 error due to the invalid /artifactory context being added to the URL redirect.

The workaround is to set the "proxy_set_header    X-Artifactory-Override-Base-Url" in nginx with the Artifactory URL. This will fix the problem, but this should not be required when you have set a valid custom base URL in Artifactory. 

In the previous  version  (6.5.13) even without "proxy_set_header    X-Artifactory-Override-Base-Url" in nginx, the redirect was working as expected when visiting the pypi remote URL's  and the /artifactory context was not being added during pypi remote URL redirects.

column1: Reduced functionality for Edge nodes
column39:
Due to Edge node reduced functionality - some of the logic around the creation of the instance can be reduced.

Typical examples would be:
 * the automatic creation of the build info repo is not needed since you can not integrate builds against an edge node
 * the xray event indexing job is not needed since xray is not suppose to scan edge nodes
 * some plugins might be removed from automatic loading
 * some other examples

column1: Add an entry on the Artifactory.log when the user is locked
column39: Currently, when we are configuring the user [lock mechanism|https://www.jfrog.com/confluence/display/RTF/Configuring+Security#ConfiguringSecurity-UserLockandLoginSuspension]  we can't track why the user is blocked due to bad credentials or password expires. To further investigate user locking we may need an entry in the logs that let us know when the user is locked
column252: 04/Feb/19 3:00 PM;sdwire;In our use case, we have a build server configured with credentials to artifactory for a build-specific user account. We frequently find that the user account becomes locked, and builds begin to fail. But unlocking the user account immediately causes the builds to succeed.  Because we can't tell the difference between the victims (denied login because the account is already locked) from the culprits (denied login because the credentials are bad), we have not been able to identify when the user account initially becomes locked. This means we have been unable to find the source of the bad credentials.
column254: 06/Mar/19 2:15 PM;sdwire;[~andreik] We're using a cloud-hosted version of Artifactory.  How can I access that log file? It doesn't appear to be one of the options under the Logs menu.

column1: backup access/etc/keys in system backup and export
column39:
The current system backup does not include _{{$ARTIFACTORY_HOME/}}_access/

Scenario: Changed, missing or corrupt access files or circle of trust.

access/etc/keys/trusted folders not backed up in the UI backup. _{{$ARTIFACTORY_HOME/}}_access/ should be included in backup and export system
column252: 07/Feb/19 11:50 AM;arielk;The "access/etc/keys" is being backed up, but the "/trusted" folder inside of it isn't. We should back it up as well.

column1: Artifactory YAML support for smart remote repository configuration
column39:
It looks like it isn't currently possible to update smart remote repository configuration via YAML patch file:

e.g.

{code}
contentSynchronisation :
    enabled: true
    statistics : 
      enabled : false
    properties : 
      enabled : false
    source :
      originAbsenceDetection : false
{code}

response: "Key "contentSynchronization" is not part of the configuration.
column252: 31/Jan/19 6:39 PM;mattheww;It seems the key sync properties exists, but report statistics and source absense detection are missing.

column1: Pypi smart remote repo add trailing "/" to upstream metadata URL
column39:
When setting up a remote pypi repo on instance A proxying a remote pypi repo on instance B, when resolving metadata, the URL doesn't have a trailing slash at first, and is redirected to contain the trailing slash. For example, for the package Octoparse in http loggers:

2019-01-29 22:58:24,145 [http-nio-8081-exec-1] [DEBUG] (o.a.h.headers       :135) - http-outgoing-28 >> HEAD /artifactory/api/pypi/pypi-remote/simple/octoparse HTTP/1.1

...

2019-01-29 22:58:24,184 [http-nio-8081-exec-1] [DEBUG] (o.a.h.wire          :72) - http-outgoing-28 << "HTTP/1.1 302 Found[\r][\n]"

...

2019-01-29 22:58:24,188 [http-nio-8081-exec-1] [DEBUG] (o.a.h.i.e.RedirectExec:159) - Redirecting to 'http://mill.jfrog.info:12344/artifactory/api/pypi/pypi-remote/simple/octoparse/' via {}->http://mill.jfrog.info:12344

...

2019-01-29 22:58:24,189 [http-nio-8081-exec-1] [DEBUG] (o.a.h.headers       :135) - http-outgoing-28 >> HEAD /artifactory/api/pypi/pypi-remote/simple/octoparse/ HTTP/1.1

 

*It would be nice if the initial request could contain the trailing "/", so a redirect would not be needed:*

2019-01-29 22:58:24,189 [http-nio-8081-exec-1] [DEBUG] (o.a.h.headers       :135) - http-outgoing-28 >> HEAD /artifactory/api/pypi/pypi-remote/simple/octoparse/ HTTP/1.1

 

Steps to reproduce:

-set up remote pypi repo proxying pypi.org on instance A

-on instance B, set up remote pypi repo proxying instance A, with both URL and registry URL with path:

api/pypi/pypi-remote/simple/octoparse/

-on instance B, set up http debug loggers and see that Artifactory reaches out to instance A without the trailing slash first, and is redirected with a 302 Found to include the trailing slash.

column1: Improve DB interaction tests during startup
column39:
During the Artifactory startup, we should confirm we are able to make different standard DB interactions.
For example, check if index exists. This might fail due to JDBC <> DB incompatibility.

We should validate better this compatibility during startup, and if there are issues - to fail the startup.

This is to avoid possible issues after, as for example:

{code:java}
2019-01-24 01:53:35,605 [art-exec-4] [WARN ] (o.a.s.d.DbServiceImpl:384) - Can't determine the uniqueness of 'repo_path_checksum' column column in nodes table: ERROR: column am.amcanorder does not exist
  Position: 427
{code}

column1: List the scope of an access token in the UI and as a response of REST API endpoint
column39:
This is a request to add the scope for the tokens and have listed in the web interface as part of the following (/artifactory/webapp/#/admin/security/access_tokens) webpage.

As well as the GET REST call against /artifactory/api/security/token to list the scope as part of the response
column252:
05/Apr/19 8:34 AM;Olivier;This is really something that is missing for managing "Non-Existing Users" tokens.

I don't see any way to know to which group the non existing user has been attached, which can raise security issues !
column253:
28/Oct/19 10:28 PM;alexei.hider@anz.com;Agree completely with Olivier.

 

Currently there is no way for us to audit which access tokens have what permissions, which is very poor.
column254: 29/Oct/19 11:58 AM;szhargrave@ybs.co.uk;Agree, this is a significant shortcoming which could do with a resolution. Have upvoted.
column255: 01/Apr/20 6:00 AM;andy.tang@anz.com;Upvoted - need this to properly audit our RBAC, currently need to track manually which is not great.

column1: Avoid creation of multiple dbRecord.bin files when concurrently attempting to cache the same resource/artifact
column39:
Steps to reproduce:
1.Configure cache-fs

2.Perform concurrent download/upload requests for the same file

3.Notice the _pre folder contains multiple dbRecord.bin files (which are being deleted eventually), according to the number of the requests 

*When dealing with a big env, it may cause some space consumption in Artifactory

column1: Metadata Service events should have their own log file
Smart Remote Repo Does Not Display Files With Build Metadata Number
column39:
When mirroring a remote Helm repository hosted on another Artifactory (smart remote) Artifactory will not display version that have valid SemVer 2 [Build Metadata|[https://semver.org/].]

This metadata is represented with a plus sign in the version and filename as *chart-name-x.y.z+abcd*

Helm client recognizes this versioning on their searching and fetching.

 

Steps to reproduce:

Artifactory A:

create repo helm-local

deploy two charts with different versioning, for example:

*test-chart/test-chart-0.2.3+123.tgz*

*test-chart/test-chart-0.2.3-123.tgz*

Artifactory B:

Create remote *external-helm* pointed to *helm-local* and allow file browsing

The treebrowser will only show *test-chart/test-chart-0.2.3-123.tgz*

column1: add server side/backend input validation
column39: Currently, we have input validation for text input on the front end, which can easily be bypassed using HTTP Proxy tools. There should be input validation in the server side back end as well.

column1: Determine owner of API key via Rest API
column39: When we find an API key that needs revoking (for whatever reason) it would be useful to be able to look up the owner of the key so they can be notified, and for our auditing purposes. The simplest way to do this would be to open up an admin-only Rest API endpoint to find the owner of a particular API key.

column1: Docker Package Native UI - Smart Remote Repositories
column39: Provide the ability to search remote artifacts exposed via a smart remote repository.

column1: Username length increase --> 128
column39:
We have a requirement to use user names that are longer then 64 characters.

Our use case is: We are verifying Kubernetes Service Account Tokens in a custom Artifactory authentication plugin. We would like to infer from the username: service account Name, Namespace & Kubernetes instance, and the Name should look like this:

[project-namespace, ~15 chars]_[service account name, ~7 chars]@[domain_name, > 60 chars].

We find the current 64 character restriction too limiting to implement such a scheme, it would be great to increase it to at least 128.

column1: Support Microsoft Symbol Server integration with Artifactory for Conan packages containing .pdb
column39:
We would like to ensure that developers can debug production Windows software published internally using Conan.

We understand how we could publish libraries used in building our executable up to Conan and our pdb files separately to a symbol server accessible to VisualStudio.

However, given space constraints, we must manage the garbage collection of old library builds once we become certain they are no longer needed.

If we store .pdb files to a separate symbol server, then whatever lifecycle and deprecation management we decide on for Conan packages must be duplicated for the management of the symbol server pdbs.

If instead we could simply publish the pdb and lib files in the same Conan package, publish them to Artifactory and aim Visual Studio at the artifactory conan repo as a Symbol Server, we could manage those artifacts together.

Can we please request a Conan/Artifactory integration enhancement that would allow .pdb files published within Conan packages to be transparently available as if it were a Symbol Server, using the usual hash query mechanism implemented by Symbol Servers [https://stackoverflow.com/questions/1419347/microsoft-symbol-server-local-cache-hash-algorithm] ?

 

 

Please see related issue [https://github.com/conan-io/conan/issues/4047] in the Conan github repo.

column1: Storage info API should not account duplicate docker layers
column39:
_We see this in /artifactory/api/storageinfo_

 _{_ 
  _repoKey: "bi",_ 
  _repoType: "LOCAL",_ 
  _foldersCount: 535,_ 
  _filesCount: 3178,_ 
  _usedSpace: "412.72 GB",_ 
  _itemsCount: 3713,_ 
  _packageType: "Docker",_ 
  _percentage: "0.23%"_ 
 _}_ 


_However, we have only uploaded ~1900 files, totalling ~156Gb.  The difference_ 
_is in the way client and server are handling reused docker image layers._ 

_We are following good practice and automatically building new images as part_ 
_of our CI pipeline where the top layer is generally the only changing layer._   
  _When pushing, most of the layers are not pushed as artifactory returns_ 
_'Layer already exists'._ 

_The artifactory doc also implies shallow copy/links are used to handle_ 
_knowing when orphaned layers can be deleted._ 

_Example - two consecutive, automated image publishes:_ 

_[/artifactory/bi/bi/contentstorage/1.1.0.0.0-20180806060046/|http://artifactory-slc.oraclecorp.com/artifactory/bi/bi/contentstorage-prebuilt-oracledb/1.1.0.0.0-20180806060046/]_ 
_/[artifactory/bi/bi/contentstorage/1.1.0.0.0-20180806150421/|http://artifactory-slc.oraclecorp.com/artifactory/bi/bi/contentstorage-prebuilt-oracledb/1.1.0.0.0-20180806150421/]_ 

_4 layers are common, ~2.7Gb.  1 layer changes, 10Kb each time._ 

_Docker push/artifactory knows this, as it reports `Layer already exists¿._ 

_The storage info should be ~2.7Gb, not ~5.4Gb and the storageinfo REST call_ 
_should reflect the activiyy from the client's perspective including docker_ 
_semantics._

column1: Parameterize JVM memory options with environment variables in Artifactory docker images
column39:
The default JAVA_OPTIONS runs `export JAVA_OPTIONS="-server -Xms512m -Xmx2g -Xss256k ...`

 

When we pass Java system properties to the JVM running Artifactory with EXTRA_JAVA_OPTIONS we get `export JAVA_OPTIONS="-server -Xms512m -Xmx2g -Xss256k ...  -server -Xms48g -Xmx48g -Xss256k -XX:+UseG1GC`.

 

That means we have two of each option on the command line. It is not officially documented that the last command line options take precedence. However, from the following quick check the second instance of the argument (2G) is what takes precedence:

 

*$ java -version; java -Xmx1G -XX:+PrintFlagsFinal -Xmx2G 2>/dev/null | grep MaxHeapSize*

*java version "1.8.0_191"*
*Java(TM) SE Runtime Environment (build 1.8.0_191-b12)*
*Java HotSpot(TM) 64-Bit Server VM (build 25.191-b12, mixed mode)*
uintx *MaxHeapSize := 2147483648*

 

Proposed improvement is to parameterize JVM memory options with environment variables:
 # Move the existing JVM parameters out of _artifactory.default_
 # Inject them in the _entrypoint.sh_
column252:
09/Jan/19 3:18 PM;eldada;This behaviour is not new and is commonly used in Java based applications.

I agree we should try and improve this, but this is not urgent. It might require a rethink of the way JVM arguments are managed in Artifactory and its Docker image.

column1: Asynchronous API calls support
column39:
Hello,

we are using Artifactory for quite a while now and discovered that many REST API calls are designed to be used in a blocking way. For example the delete item operation of the REST API can consume a bit more time, if a very large tree has to be deleted. Another example is triggering the garbage collection leads to an API call that can take quite a while; In this case the UI is blocked until the call is finished. Both operation can easily lead to timeouts in various places.

In my eyes both operations can be considered to trigger long running or delayed executed processes. Therefore I would expect them to be implemented or at least be available in an asynchronous fashion. 

My proposal to avoid these issues:

Make every (Web) REST-API that cannot be expected to respond fast, because it's a heavy operation/process or the duration depends on the underlying data, available as asynchronous operation.

column1: Add an option to restart the Build Info migration
Improve backup/restore on windows
column40:
Windiows server 2012 R2

Windows service "Artifactory" is running as user "Local System account"

Windows share is used for the backup \\<network attached storage>\Arifactory\Backup

The user "Local System account" doesn't have rights on the windows share.

column1: stabilize package name accessibility within virtual repositories
column39:
Each of our virtual repositories meant to combine one local repository with the remote one such as registry.npmjs.org:
*   BUSINESS-UNIT-REPO:
**  LOCAL-BUSINESS-UNIT-REPO
**  REMOTE-REPO
 
We also add an enterprise-wide local repo into each business unit repo.
*   BUSINESS-UNIT-REPO:
**  LOCAL-BUSINESS-UNIT-REPO
**  LOCAL-ENTERPRISE-WIDE-REPO
**  REMOTE-REPO

We found that uploading a package to a repository, then uploading a package by the same name into another repository creates ambiguity when the two repositories are or will be related in a virtual relationship.  The collision in package names happened between 2 local physical repos (LOCAL-BUSINESS-UNIT and LOCAL-ENTERPRISE-WIDE-REPO) of a business unit virtual repo (BUSINESS-UNIT-REPO).  In another scenario uploading a remote package to a local repository causes a collision, too.

This would result in 
* potential package duplication,
* malicious local replacements of remote packages,
* unexpected authentication errors when downloading a remote package name from the virtual repository and jFrog resolving it to a local authenticated copy.

Artifactory as a software product can prevent this ambiguity at two levels for each virtual repository within each package manager:
 # prevent from superimposing repositories with conflicting package names and
 # prevent from publishing a new package name into one repository when another repository *in the same stack* already has it.
column252:
04/Sep/19 8:37 PM;ilguiz_latypov;This bit us today again in the following scenario:
 * Someone's Jenkins job (probably using poorly tested pipeline code) uploaded xunit packages to a password-protected NUGETREPO-local nuget repository couple months ago.
 * Ever since then, attempts to download xunit from NUGETREPO (a virtual repo that has a nuget-remote component pointing to the Microsoft gallery) fail using nuget.exe (but curl works).  I used a nuget.exe v. 4.9.4.5839 and a clean nuget.config such as the following,
{noformat}
<configuration>
   <packageSources>
     <add key="example-nuget" value="https://artifactory.COMPANY.TLD/artifactory/api/nuget/example-nuget" />
   </packageSources>
   <disabledPackageSources>
     <add key="nuget.org" value="true" />
   </disabledPackageSources>
   <packageSourceCredentials>
     <example-nuget>
       <add key="Username" value="USER" />
       <add key="ClearTextPassword" value="ENCRYPTEDPASS" />
     </example-nuget>
   </packageSourceCredentials>
   <config>
     <add key="repositoryPath" value="d:/packages" />
   </config>
</configuration>
{noformat}
I deleted %userprofile%/appdata/roaming/nuget/nuget.config. I also created an NTFS symlink with {{cmd /c mklink /d packages d:}}
{{packages}} to resolve relative references in .csproj files. I purged both {{d:\packages}} and {{%userprofile%\.nuget\packages}} before each nuget restore invokation.

 * The {{nuget restore -configfile nuget.config}} command *succeeded only after deleting the password-protected xunit packages from NUGETREPO-local* (using curl -X DELETE -u 'USER:ENCRYPTEDPASS' ...).
 * I suppose nuget.exe has a complicated check of the package availability that resulted in nuget.exe displaying a 403 Forbidden message followed by prompting for username and password.
 * To further complicate the picture, our NUGETREPO includes {{nuget}} which in turn combines a {{nuget-local}} and a {{nuget-remote}} repository, with {{xunit}} packages seen in {{nuget-local}} against expectation (these can be downloaded without credentials and with any other credential).

Perhaps this ambiguity (triggered by the triplicate store of an external package) triggered nuget.exe into the anonymous download mode.  I submitted the related issue with NuGet, https://github.com/NuGet/Home/issues/8551
column254:
10/Dec/19 10:28 AM;ilguiz_latypov;Another blunder was found today thanks to a meticulous developer.  A rogue Maven upload of build result into Artifactory's local repo under the group and artifact IDs of a well-known remote dependency (commons-collection) resulted in that upload overriding resolution of the remote dependency with the local one.

If this override is by design, JFrog should have a big red page or section in its web interface displaying all current overrides.  I doubt we have resources to separate resolution of remote and local dependencies by their repo names.

Oh and whoever decided to put "leap.jfrog.com" banners after couple minutes of browing an issue, this made even adding this comment a hurdle.  Please remove the banner logic and start working on this issue.
column255: 09/Mar/20 11:43 PM;ilguiz_latypov;Ping!  Just saying we had another accidental upload overriding maven-clean-plugin.  Does Artifactory have an option to prioritize external dependencies over internal ones?  We would only need to make a few proprietary external packages available via a local upload, so the option and a way to prescribe exceptions to the option would be awesome.
column257:
10/Feb/21 11:08 AM;ilguiz_latypov;I appreciate Baruch Sadogursky pointing to earlier appeals for defining exclude and include patterns on repositories, and Stephen Chin highlighting this on Twitter,

[https://jfrog.com/blog/yet-another-case-for-using-exclude-patterns-in-remote-repositories/]

but overlapping publications (of locally named packages in remote repos and of remotely named packages in local repos) could be detected automatically and could trigger alerts.
column258:
10/Feb/21 11:19 AM;ilguiz_latypov;"could be detected automatically"
 * at the time of improper publishing by poorly configured enterprise scripts and
 * at the time of improper use (when Artifactory clients download a package whose versions span across local and remote repositories).

Artifactory could maintain a list of compromised package names (by repo type) to speed up the checks at the time of improper use.  The list can be updated by Artifactory's executing both
 * the preliminary detection at the time of the package publication and
 * the periodic remote repo refreshes complemented with checks against local repos.

column1: Update MySQL connector library to the latest version
column39:
The recommended version of the MySQL connector/j library for versions 5.5 and above is 8.x.

As part of this task upgrade the mysql connector library in the following places:
 # Unit and integration tests
 # AOL servers
 # Our documentation

This is done as part of our updated compatibility matrix.

column1: Requesting a file while Artifactory is starting up returns the start up page
column39:
When requesting a file while Artifactory is starting up, the output is the Artifactory startup page in HTML.

Instead, the output should be a status code indicating a server-side error

 

Steps to reproduce:
 * Retrieve an artifact using the [REST API |https://www.jfrog.com/confluence/display/RTF/Artifactory+REST+API#ArtifactoryRESTAPI-RetrieveArtifact]while Artifactory is starting up
 * Observe HTML output instead of requested artifact

column1: Support JSON output logs in Artifactory
column39:
My current usecase is to modify artifactory logs to output json.

Working with the official docker image I've extended it in the following way.

I've modified the artifactory etc/logback.xml file accordingly

 

 
{code:java}
<appender name="CONSOLE" class="ch.qos.logback.core.ConsoleAppender">
        <encoder class="net.logstash.logback.encoder.LogstashEncoder">
            <includeContext>false</includeContext>
            <includeMdc>false</includeMdc>
            <timeZone>UTC</timeZone>
            <customFields>{"artifactory":"console"}</customFields>
            <fieldNames>
                <version>[ignore]</version>
            </fieldNames>
        </encoder>
    </appender>
 
{code}
 

the problem is the inclusion of [https://repo.maven.apache.org/maven2/net/logstash/logback/logstash-logback-encoder/5.2/logstash-logback-encoder-5.2.jar] in the webapp. I've temporarily solved it by extending the official artifactory docker image, downloading the dependency and running 'jar uf $ARTIFACTORY_HOME/webapps/artifactory.war WEB-INF/lib/logstash-logback-encoder-5.2.jar'

Because of how docker filesystem layers work, this duplicates the artifactory.war file in the resulting image.

it would be nice if we had a way to include a folder or list of jars into the webapp's core classpath, without updating the war file burned into the image
column252:
24/Dec/19 3:07 PM;iliag;The minimum of Jfrog is to support on the K8S version to json output.

Very strange for Enterprise company (and cost) not even offer this basic "feature"

column1: Support import of password-protected PEM files
column39:
Currently when we import certificates to Artifactory we do not support import of password-protected pem files:

[https://www.jfrog.com/confluence/display/RTF/Managing+Certificates]

Users can only import a certificate without a passphrase.

column1: Improve S3 error handling
column39:
Requests to S3 normally return XML and not JSON. This exception is raised when users run into certain issues on the S3 side:
 *java.lang.RuntimeException: org.codehaus.jackson.JsonParseException: Unexpected character ('<' (code 60))*

Expects a JSON, but probably received an HTML response(possible 404 etc)

Ideally, the actual HTTP response will be logged in order to point users towards a possible fix.

column1: Virtual repository UI "source path" does not reflect resolution order
column39:
*Issue*

When browsing for an artifact via virtual repo in the UI, the source path of the artifact does not reflect resolution order.

UI should reflect information consistent to resolution order in virtual repositories.

*Steps for reproduction*
 # Create local repositories
 ## maven1, maven2, maven3
 # create a Virtual repository
 # aggregate local repositories into the virtual
 ## set maven1 as top repository, maven2 next, etc
 # deploy the same file to local repositories
 # Check the virtual repo UI
 ## It will show inconsistent source path 
 # Running curl trace will still show correct resolution order

column1: Add a requirement and verification and UI/log reflection that all cluster HA nodes have the same time
column39:
This is needed for a few reason to ensure an HA cluster is healthy. 

Since the introduction of Access, and Access' tokens usage in HA propagation mechanism such as:

1. Artifactory Config changes --> an Access communication kept in memory (true to 6.4.0 -- 6.5.8) 
2. Binarystore for Remote binary provider authentication  --> Also keeps token in memory 
3. Access to Access HA sync (GRPC) --> An access token is also kept in memory

Which are time dependent for verification.


+ This adds correct and easy correction between nodes for logs correlation and sync

column1: Default Metadata Retrieval Cache Period is too low
column39:
When creating a remote repository, the default value of Metadata Retrieval Cache Period is 600 = 10 minutes.

For a NPM build, to retrieve metadata from the remote repository (internet) Artifactory do thousands of requests. The time build is highly impacted each 10 minutes.

For P2, the volume of metadata is also quite huge for each request.

Would it be better to set the default value to a longer value ? One day could be a good compromise.

column1: Docker promotion insufficient permissions throws misleading error message.
Ability to choose which artifacts in Artifactory to scan in XRay.
column39:
Currently there are two methods to initiate an XRay scan:
 * Select the repository to scan, and any new published artifact will be automatically scanned
 * Choose the option to scan all history

There is a lot of history we really do not care to scan; our preference is to scan all latest versions only, and then let new artifacts get scanned automatically. Either have an option to do this, or give the ability via an api to specify the specific artifact to be scanned (that has never yet been scanned) - I could run an AQL to get a list of the latest versions, then use that list to feed some XRay process to scan only those in the list. Or something like that.

column1: Un-black out repositories after Db Restart issue is finished
column39:
Currently, if Artifactory detects the database is shutting down, all of the repositories will be blacked out:

*"Failed to initialize local repository REPO_NAME. Repository will be blacked-out"*

*...*

*Caused by: com.microsoft.sqlserver.jdbc.SQLServerException: SHUTDOWN is in progress.* 

 

There should be some smart check to un-black out the repositories after the DB connection is re-established. Alternatively, a way to un-black out all repositories in one go would help as well.

column1: Unable to enable smart repository config parameters from Mission control script
column39:
Currently, the customer is creating a smart remote repository using a script via mission control, we are able to create a smart remote repo using the script but not successful in getting the below fields enabled for the smart remote repo :

{color:#FF0000}Report Statistics {color}

{color:#FF0000}Sync Properties {color}

{color:#FF0000}Source Absence Detection {color}

The groovy script used to create smart remote repo is picked from the below link :

[https://github.com/jfrog/mission-control-config-scripts/blob/master/repository/create/remote-nuget-gallery.groovy]

 

The parameters for a remote{{Repository}} block are listed as referred to this [link |https://www.jfrog.com/confluence/display/MC/Configuration+DSL#ConfigurationDSL-RemoteRepository].
currently, the above parameters are not listed in the remoteRepository block, for which we are trying to induce these parameters in the script and failed for the same.

We tried enabling these parameters in the script but failed to get them reflected as when the smart remote repository is created 

synchronizeProperties true
originAbsenceDetection true

contentSynchronisation true 

The customer wants to have all the configuration for the smart remote repo to be done by the script, rather than manually checking from UI for the config changes.
column253: 14/Feb/19 8:58 PM;mrichar2;Note with the above script you still have to go in and toggle the configuration (turn off, save, turn on, save).

column1: Accomodate MSSQL max index length
column39:
There are currently several tables with indexs that are larger than 900 or 1700 bytes (900 for mssql 2012/2014 and 1700 for mssql 2016), such as:

Index (MaxColumnLength)

node_props_prop_value_idx (4000) 

module_props_prop_value_idx (2048)

access_groups_data_value_idx (2048)

access_users_data_value_idx (2048)

build_props_prop_value_idx (2048)

 

Artifactory should trim these values to 900 or1700 bytes
column252:
25/Mar/19 11:32 AM;stefanga;Related to RTFACT-16995

We have been bitten by this now that we are using MSSQL with our HA cluster setup.

column1: Display Nuget v3 URL in Get Repos API call
column39:
When you run the Get Repositories API ([https://www.jfrog.com/confluence/display/RTF/Artifactory+REST+API#ArtifactoryRESTAPI-GetRepositories),] this returns the repo key, type, url and packageType.  Below is an example of the output for a remote nuget repository.  

 

  "key" : "nuget-remote",

  "type" : "REMOTE",

  "url" : "https://www.nuget.org/",

  "packageType" : "NuGet"

 

This API should return all URLs for that specific repository.  In this case it would also include the nuget v3 url.

column1: Artifactory system info displays misleading service.name by default
column39: The default value of the artifactory.service.name is [https://localhost:8080/artifactory/webapp/]. It is displayed in the log and in the ui and might confuse the users thinking this is the address of Artifactory.

column1: Performance issue using [RELEASE] keyword for Retrieve Latest Artifact REST API
column39:
If the repository has lots of artifacts, for example, over 4000 artifacts in libs-release-local.

Using [RELEASE] keyword for Retrieve Lastest Artfitact REST API, the performance is bad.
It took 9 seconds to download the latest version. 
Performance was inversely proportional if the repository was getting more and more artifacts.

However, If we use two consecutive calls such as latestVersion and then direct download link. It took less than 1 seconds. This is way faster. This could be a workaround.

column1: making a request with % or other special characters in path may lead to unexpected behavior
column39:
Steps to reproduce:

try access artifactory with below url:

[http://localhost:8081/artifactory/%0D/|http://mill.jfrog.info:33264/artifactory/%0D/]

or

[http://localhost:8081/artifactory//]

See that the request returns a 500 error with

"message" : "Repo key cannot be empty. Path: "

This may be due to the % in the url and Artifactory thinks %0D is an encoded value. 

Trying the below returns a 404 as expected:

[http://localhost:8081/artifactory/E%0D/|http://mill.jfrog.info:33264/artifactory/%0D/]

[http://localhost:8081/artifactory/%0DE/|http://mill.jfrog.info:33264/artifactory/%0D/]

[http://localhost:8081/artifactory/<repo that doesn't exist>/|http://mill.jfrog.info:33264/artifactory/%0D/]

column1: Using Artifactory as an auth provider with Xray or Artifactory behind f5 may encounter an invalid token
column39:
If you have Artifactory or Xray behind an https enabled f5, and are using Artifactory as an Auth provider, then you may get an "Found invalid token" error when logging into Xray. This may be because there is a POST that is getting redirected to a GET. The request in Artifactory (request.log) is supposed to be:
|POST|/api/system/gateway/openid/token|HTTP/1.1|200|2240|

However, with the above setup, it is being made as:
|GET|/api/system/gateway/openid/token|HTTP/1.1|405|2240|

Possible explanation:

-there is a redirect from a 30x response (possibly from https to http or elsewhere), which causes the POST to be redirected to a GET (since you can't redirect a POST request)

 

Workaround is to access Artifactory by bypassing f5
column252: 17/Dec/19 10:03 AM;akm022;I would suggest to use https instead of http in the first place when setting up an auth provider, so that redirect does not happen. If it's not possible, try to reconfigure f5 to redirect with [307|https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/HTTP/Status/307] instead of 302 to keep request verb and body.

column1: Docker registry show latest tag real version
column39:
It would be nice to actually see in Artifactory docker registry which real tag version is behind latest tag version.

Example

rhel7/rhel:lastest > rhel7/rhel:7.555

column1: Exempt Xray from global proxy before integration
column39:
When ProX license is activated, Xray page is very user-unfriendly (contains only a link to user guide).

At the very least, it should inform that global proxy must be deactivated and contain a link to the relevant settings page ("proxies"). It may also provide a text field to enter an Xray server name.
column252: 09/Nov/18 2:07 PM;gintas;See RTFACT-14081

column1: Add token_id to Refresh and Create calls for Access Tokens
column39: Currently when you get the list of Access Tokens, a token_id is provided, which can be seen in the UI. This ID is not passed as part of the response of Create and Refresh calls, and it would be useful to have this information at the moment of creation in order to correlate later.
column252: 25/Feb/20 2:16 PM;tim.harris@cfacorp.com;This is a much needed enhancement. Otherwise it is hard to track access tokens after they are created. We are in a situation where we automate creation of tokens. We have to get a list of tokens before creating, then create a token, then get a list of tokens again, then do a diff or the old list of tokens against the new list of tokens. This would be so much easier if the create token call just returned the token_id. Thanks!

column1: Log correlation
column39:
Is there any way that when a session or process gets start that all logs can have some sort of session hash that will correlate them all together? 

For example. If I wanted to deploy an artifact to a yum repo, I would get a log for each of the following, with no real way to connect them all to the same task. 

1. logging in

2. Deploy request

3. Deploy Accepted

4. Deploying properties

5. Successfully deployed properties

column1: NPM login generated tokens improvement
column39:
When a user performs npm login a token is generated.

However, these tokens are perpetual and pose a security risk (if a user gets a hold of .npmrc and extracts the token).

To help mitigate the issue can we:
 # enforce expiry policy on npm-related tokens
 # log "last used" for access tokens so customers can perform cleanup on stale tokens.

column1: Add tooltips to Artifact Repository Browser, for any folder or artifact element in the tree that is beyond the right side of the tree control.
column39: We'd like to see tooltips in the UI for paths that extend past the frame.  This would allow us to hover over something and see the full value in the tooltip instead of having to extend the frame. Specifically, the Artifact Repository Browser, for any folder or artifact element in the tree that is beyond the right side of the tree control. (I tried to add an example, but could not)

column1: Request for 'copy' function to respect virtual 'default' repo
Weaknesses in Apache Tomcat
column39:
Running a Tenable scan on Artifactory founds the following errors regarding the bundled Tomcat:
 

The remote web server contains default !les.

Description:

The default error page, default index page, example JSPs, and/or example servlets

are installed on the remote Apache Tomcat server. These !les should be removed as

they may help an attacker uncover information about the remote Tomcat install or

host itself.

See Also

[https://wiki.apache.org/tomcat/FAQ/Miscellaneous#Q6]

[https://www.owasp.org/index.php/Securing_tomcat]

 
These default files should be removed?
This considers a vulnerability?
column252:
10/Jan/20 5:07 PM;japetus;Any update on this? We use JFrog/Artifactory and recently had a PEN test done and this exact medium vulnerability was detected. We just upgraded to the latest version - docker.bintray.io/jfrog/artifactory-pro:latest - 6.16.0, but a Nessus scan still shows that this hasn't been patched. When can we expect it to be patched?

The Nessus link for the vulnerability is [https://www.tenable.com/plugins/nessus/12085.] The recommended remediation - https://www.owasp.org/index.php/Securing_tomcat.

We've figured out how to fix it, but you would need to commit these changes to the base/latest image so that any future pulls/upgrades would include the fixes.

 

To fix the issue (simplified version of [https://www.owasp.org/index.php/Securing_tomcat)] :

# docker exec -u 0 -it $CONTAINDER_ID bash 

# cd opt/jfrog/artifactory/tomcat/ 

# chmod -R 400 conf 

# chmod -R 300 /var/opt/jfrog/artifactory/logs/catalina 

# rm -rf /opt/jfrog/artifactory/tomcat/webapps/ROOT  

# cd /opt/jfrog/artifactory/tomcat/lib 

# jar xf catalina.jar org/apache/catalina/util/ServerInfo.properties 

# vi org/apache/catalina/util/ServerInfo.properties 

change server.info line to: 

server.info=Apache Tomcat^M 

# jar uf catalina.jar org/apache/catalina/util/ServerInfo.properties 

# rm -rf org 

# cd /opt/jfrog/artifactory/tomcat/conf

# vi server.xml 

add "server" tag to these 2 lines so that they look like the following: 

root@20fc7d0de641:/opt/jfrog/artifactory/tomcat/conf# grep server server.xml

        <Connector port="8081" server="Apache" sendReasonPhrase="true" relaxedPathChars='[]' relaxedQueryChars='[]' maxThreads="200"/>

        <Connector port="8040" server="Apache" sendReasonPhrase="true" maxThreads="50"/> 

# chmod 700 server.xml

vi server.xml

change from: 

<Server port="8015" shutdown="SHUTDOWN"> 

change to: 

<Server port="8015" shutdown="RANDOMCOMPLEXWORD"> 

 

# Docker commit something something something....?

column1: Backups and Import/Export UI review
column39:
Backup and Import/Export interface is very confusing at times. Proposed changes to improve:
 * System Export: "Exclude Content" should say "Exclude Binaries" (or a help bubble should explain it)
 * System Export: "Exclude Metadata" should say "Exclude Repository Metadata" and help bubble should clarify that this means indexes, metadata and properties.
 * System Import: "Exclude Content" should say "Exclude Repositories"
 * System Import: "Exclude Metadata" should say "Exclude Repository Metadata" and help bubble should clarify that this means indexes, metadata and properties.
 * Backups: Should include the "Exclude -Content- Binaries" option which is _often_ used via REST API on an external cron due to lack of option in backups.
 * Backups: "Incremental" should have a help bubble saying it is overwriting with only the delta.
column252:
26/Oct/18 11:20 PM;patrickr;For the Backups, it would very helpful to include the "exclude binaries" option. Many larger artifactories still rely on internal backups as they are convenient. It also allows users to restore individual repositories instead of loading an entire database dump.

The Exclude Binaries (Currently Exclude Content) option is very efficient for both disk space and runtime. This is because it only prints the XML metadata associated with an artifact or folder.

column1: Save the master.key file in the file system before update the DB.
column39:
We have encountered issue when Artifactory could not save he master.key file in $ART_HOME/etc/security due to permissions issue, after we have fixed the permission issue, since the DB had reference to the master.key (which never created in the file system), Access looked for the file and since it not exist could not start.

the only to recover from this state is to remove the master.key references from the DB and to restart Artifactory service.

steps o reproduce:
 # install Artifactory 5.8 and above and don't provide write access to the $ART_HOME/etc/security folder.
 # start Artifactory server - you will receive error on about that it can;t save the master.key file.
 # provide full permissions on the $ART_HOME/etc/security and restart Artifactory service - Access will not start and will look for the master.key file.

column1: Check existence of JAVA and not just JAVA_HOME during startup
Add support for searching mail addresses in Effective Permissions Tab
column39:
Currently it seems that only usernames can be used to see and search the current permission holders (see screenshot) in the effective permissions tab of a single artifact. For data privacy reasons we are forced to use usernames that are not related to the users real-name. This intended abstraction layer is very contra productive when it comes to permissions management. It is not easy to get an overview or to search for real names of users without performing nickname lookups.

I think a great improvement in comfort and clarity of permissions could be added if support for searching both - the username and the user's email address - would be possible.

column1: Replication gives error when used along with artifactory plugin
column39:
We are having an issue in replication when we use the user plugin to perform a copy and start a pull replication. 

Steps to reproduce :

We need two artifactory instances with different license, to represent two different regions A and B.

+*1. Installation:*+

In Region A:

a. Installed Artifactory v6.x
 b. Created a local repository: art1-docker-local-repodev
 c. Created a local repository: art1-docker-local-repotest

In Region B:

a. Installed Artifactory v6.x
 b. Created a local repository: art2-docker-local-repodev
 c. Created a local repository: art2-docker-local-repotest

*+2. Repository Event Based Replication(Push) setup:+*

From Region A (art1-docker-local-repodev) --> to Region B (art2-docker-local-repodev)
 From Region B(art2-docker-local-repotest) --> to Region A(art1-docker-local-repotest)

+*3. Initiated a deploy and then a copy:*+

a. Deploy artifacts to Region A (art1-docker-local-repodev), this triggers replication to art2-docker-local-repodev in Region B.
 b. In Region B, copied the artifacts, by using the storage plugin as mentioned in the wiki page : [https://www.jfrog.com/confluence/display/RTF/User+Plugins#UserPlugins-Storage] 

Here is the plugin code used : 

_import org.artifactory.repo.RepoPathFactory_

_storage {_
 _afterCreate { item ->_
 _if ("art2-docker-local-repodev".equals(item.getRepoKey())) {_
 _def fromRepoPath = RepoPathFactory.create(item.getRepoKey(), item.repoPath.path)_
 _def toRepoPath = RepoPathFactory.create("art2-docker-local-repotest", item.repoPath.path)_

_log.error("[Copy Test] Copying $fromRepoPath to $toRepoPath")_
 _repositories.copy(fromRepoPath, toRepoPath)_
 _}_
 _}_
_}_


 c. This gives an error saying "Refusing to queue replication event.... the target server...is equal to one of the origin" and fails to trigger a replication from Region B art2-docker-local-repotest to Region A art1-docker-local-repotest. This should have worked as the repositories are different. 

 

Here's the corresponding log entry:

*2018-10-19 21:14:37,751 [http-nio-8081-exec-8] [DEBUG] (o.a.a.r.c.ReplicationServiceImpl:314) - Refusing to queue replication event for 'art2-docker-local-repotest:replication-test.rtf': the target server '7763f1f3d6fafb93:373c9a14:1668cfdcf37:-8000' is equal to one of the origin '[7763f1f3d6fafb93:373c9a14:1668cfdcf37:-8000, 83e357a425d9b387:51be598b:1668cffc856:-8000]' of this event.*
 *2018-10-19 21:14:37,751 [http-nio-8081-exec-8] [DEBUG] (o.a.a.r.c.p.e.EventQueue:189) - User plugin rejected replication of path art2-docker-local-repotest/replication-test.rtf to/from target [http://10.128.0.28:8081/artifactory/art1-docker-local-repotest]*

 

Note: The copy plugin works as tested in this use case :

Deploy a file to Region B (art2-docker-local-repodev) , this triggers the copy plugin and creates a copy in Region B (art2-docker-local-repotest), which in turn triggers the event replication and replicates the file to Region A(art1-docker-local-repotest).

column39: The Release Bundle repository type should enable excluding and including paths.

column1: Backup UI should display *-cache for remote repositories
column39:
Some users could encounter confusion about what is exactly backed up in a standard Artifactory Backup, as it is not clear what in the remote repository is being backed up.

In the UI the remote repositories should have "-cache" appended to the repository name.

column1: Create a public REST API to retrieve the Xray summary data from Artifactory (what you see when clicking the Xray tab).
column39:
"There is a use case where an end user wants to get the information in the "XRay" tab when examining an artifact.  Currently the only way to get that information is with the UI REST endpoint that produces a JSON output:

 \{  "xrayIndexStatus" : "Normal", "xrayIndexStatusLastUpdatedTimestamp" : "26-09-18 18:22:14 +00:00",  "xrayBlocked" : false,  "xrayBlockReason" : ""}We request to make this information available via public REST API"

column1: Ability to Log Modifications to User Accounts, security, audit settings without setting debug mode
column39:
To meet a security review: 

Modifications to User Accounts Are Not Being Logged

Modifications to Security or Audit Settings Are Not Being Logged

 

In response to: ticket status: [#88678|https://support.jfrog.com/jFrogCasePage?id=5001r000022KBVh]

We can get what has changed by setting the logger levels to debug in the logback.xml file present in the $Artifactory_Home/etc directory, but the downside of it is that logs becomes bulkier and take up considerable amount of space in the artifactory is installed on instance and we would not recommend changing the loggers to debug level. 
 

 

Request to have ability to log modifications to user accounts, security, and audit settings without setting debug level.  

Alternatively, allowing ability to control log space via log rotation settings in admin settings.

column1: Ability to Provide Authentication to Artifactory via a proxy.
column39:
To meet a security requirement, request ability for Artifactory authentication to be avaiable through a proxy like webseal or datapower.

 

Currently artifactory does authenticaiton at the applicaiton level.  Request to have proxy do it.

 

"dont want artifactory to do authentication... plugn? can it work behind webseal, datapower?
Artifactory does not have ability of having authentication done by proxy and then connecting to Artifactory."

column1: Ability for sending an alert when a user gets admin rights
column39:
Based on response

"It is not possible sending an alert when a user gets admin rights, we can only see it in the log." in  ticket status: [#88678|https://support.jfrog.com/jFrogCasePage?id=5001r000022KBVh]

 

To comply with a security requirement, we request to have the ability for JFrog Artifactory application to send an email when a new user is given Admin level permissions.

column1: Ability to provide a clear distinction between administrative user and end user interfaces
column39:
Request to have the ability to provide a clear distinction between administrative user and end user interfaces.

To comply with internal security review and requirements: Administrative interfaces should be distinct from end user interfaces

we request the ability to enable this distintion clear. 

Suggestion is role based when admin user logs in to enable a clear distintion possilby by visual templates, colors, or additional contols.

 

We understand a few options are disabled for non-admin users on the UI, however, a clear distintion would be better to comply.  Another suggestion could be a "you are logged in as admin" banner and logged accordingly.

column1: CLI file spec to return code per artifact rather than per request.
Allow event based local replication within the same artifactory instance
column39:
It is observed that local replication is not functional. IE, if a local repository is configured to replicate to another local repository of the same Artifactory, the event based replication does not work, due to the logic of preventing replication loop. However for various use cases, replication locally is really needed and it should not a risk of replication loop at all.

How to reproduce this limitation:
 * Set up an HA artifactory with two backends.
 * Create two local repo ext-snapshot-local, and ext-snapshot-rep-local
 * Set up replication from ext-snapshot-local, to  [http://localhost:8081/artifactory/ext-snapshot-rep-local,] and enable event based replication.
 * Deploy a file to ext-snapshot-local
 * We can not see the file replicated to ext-snapshot-rep-local, until cron based replication kicks in.
 * Below log is shown if the debug level is on for logging:

{quote}{{2018-09-27 18:14:13,793 [http-nio-8081-exec-8] [DEBUG] (o.a.a.r.c.ReplicationServiceImpl:314) - Refusing to queue replication event for 'ext-snapshot-local:XmlDiff.java': the target server '637017a5dd34e42229584632682007c8b776d8fa' is equal to one of the origin '[637017a5dd34e42229584632682007c8b776d8fa]' of this event.}}
{{2018-09-27 18:14:13,793 [http-nio-8081-exec-8] [DEBUG] (o.a.a.r.c.l.e.EventQueue:189) - User plugin rejected replication of path ext-snapshot-local/XmlDiff.java to/from target http://localhost:8081/artifactory/ext-snapshot-rep-local}}
{quote}
If the replication target is configured as "https://<dns>/artifactory/ext-snapshot-rep-local", then the event based replication some time works but some time not, depending on which backend the https front-end route the request to.

 

On the other hand, the detection of replication loop seems to be based on server ID (one ID per backend) but not the Artifactory instance ID, and do not consider the name of the repository. Actually this may not be able to prevent the real replication loop in a HA setup, but it will also block valid replication path.
column252:
05/Dec/18 10:32 AM;adiv;After reviewing this we found a few restrictions, that can be worked around by editing the 'createCopy' plugin:
 * *Cron-based replication* - In order to achieve this you may remove the method 'afterCreate' inside the plugin and leaving all the other code intact. Then, you may either refer to our [PAPI page|http://repo.jfrog.org/artifactory/oss-releases-local/org/artifactory/artifactory-papi/%5BRELEASE%5D/artifactory-papi-%5BRELEASE%5D-javadoc.jar!/index.html] for creating a method that configures and runs the plugin on a Cron-base, or make a simple script that runs this [[execute plugin REST API|https://www.jfrog.com/confluence/display/RTF/Artifactory+REST+API#ArtifactoryRESTAPI-ExecutePluginCode]|https://www.jfrog.com/confluence/display/RTF/Artifactory+REST+API#ArtifactoryRESTAPI-ExecutePluginCode] by a Cron-base.
 * *Path prefix* - The plugin can be also modified to copy the artifacts to a specific path prefix inside the destination repository.
 * *Verification of permissions* - This part is irrelevant since in this case you are copying from inside the same Artifactory instance.

column1: 'Users' tooltip appears over the whole tab in the permissions -> users tab
column39: Open the tab in the screenshot. If you hold mouse still for 2 seconds (over the users grid for instance), you will see 'Users' tooltip appear

column1: Elements collide in the permissions -> users tab
column39: "Double click to add user" in the left bottom corner

column1: Auto Creation of Log Files If Not Present
column39:
We currently have a cron job which runs every night and compresses our Artifactory application log files.  Our primary node does not see much activity (based upon our architecture) so the regular artifactory log files “disappear” after being compressed (i.e. renamed with a .gz extension). We have found that the Artifactory application completely stops writing to any log file when it is not present.  This is a problem. 

 

We are asking that the Artifactory application recreate the log file (if not present) so that it can continue writing to the log as expected. Currently, there is no such mechanism and we have to restart the application in order for the log files to get recreated.  Apparently the only time the Artifactory application checks for the existence of log files is upon application startup.  We ask that it check before each write.  If the log file does not exist, create it (i.e. filemark it).

column1: When a permission target is used to grant a user access to an artifact, Artifactory does not log the applicable group name.
column39:
JFrog Artifactory logs user-related events to three log files artifactory.log, access.log and request.log.  Artifactory logs attributes related to these events such as the user name, date/time, resource name, HTTP response, etc.  However, and to the best of our knowledge when a user is granted access to a resource via a permission target by virtue of a group membership, Artifactory does not log the group under which the access was granted.

Ref. security logging against permission groups, we are requesting that JFrog enhance Artifactory such that it logs all of the following attributes in a log file (and in any sequence):

date_time :: username :: URL/artifact_name :: group_name :: permission_target_name :: privileges_granted :: access_granted|denied

This product improvement will help us comply with a security mandate that states that any user who has not utilized his group membership within the past 90 days to access a system, application, or resource shall be removed as a member of the applicable group.
column252:
11/Oct/18 7:53 AM;arielk;The security [Audit Trail Log|https://www.jfrog.com/confluence/display/RTF/Audit+Trail+Log] has some of the information requested here.
[~tim.golden@bankofamerica.com] can you please describe and see if the Audit log addresses your needs?
column253:
26/Nov/18 8:48 PM;tim.golden@bankofamerica.com;Ariel,

The audit.log appears to be focused on logging security events based upon identifying those users that make changes to the security configuration of an Artifactory instance.  It does not log the authorization event in which I am interested; which is, "Artifactory authorizes user via permission target group AD lookup".  Please talk to David Xu if you require additional clarification or context.  I understand that there may be an LDAP logger that can be applied to capture this info but it is also very resource intensive.  Maybe this logger could be modified to provide a more narrower focus on end user group authentication / authorization actions only?

Tim

column1: capability to allow crowd <> access existence check if the users are deactivated on Crowd
column39:
While using the Crowd/JIRA security realm. When users are deactivated in Crowd/Jira, the Artifactory Crowd client still says that the users are active.

If the ArtifactoryCrowdClient to be updated to ensure that users are only reported active if their status is active.

If a user exists but has a deactivated status, those users should not be reported as active.

Unlike the other security realms, the current behavior of the Crowd/Jira client does not seem to work as intended because deactivated users are still reported as active.

column1: Mission Control - Ability to specify alternate home directly location during install
column39: During Mission Control installation ElasticSearch and MongoDB home directories default to /var/lib/[product_name].  To prevent /var from filling up, we would like the ability to specific alternate home directory locations for ElasticSearch and MongoDB during the Mission Control process or post-install via a config. file (update file, stop appl, move date to new location, restart appl), or both.

column1: [API] improve Get token
column39:
Provide more information about an access token to perform audit, the minimum would be to see at least :
 * which user issued the token
 * what are the permissions targets

column1: sonar fixes
Artifactory 404 when trying to get NPM packages that are missing metadata on registry.npmjs.org on decoded slash url
column39:
UPDATE: NPMJS have fixed the metadata on their end, we tested all 5 known packages and they all seem to resolve properly. Fix would still be nice for checking both decoded and encoded when doing a HEAD request.

We've tried to reach out to NPMJS directly with no success. More of an issue on NPMJS but since the NPM client doesn't (seem) to see this issue, perhaps its something we can fix on our end.

We've (re)discovered a issue, with HEAD/GET requests, where 5 packages (that we know of) will 404 when Artifactory reaches out to get it's metadata from registry.npmjs.org: 
@babel/helper-builder-react-jsx
@babel/plugin-syntax-jsx
@apollographql/graphql-playground-html
@reach/router
@pm2/io

e.g. trying to hit registry.npmjs.org/@pm2/io will fail (404). If we encode the last slash, to registry.npmjs.org/@pm2%2fio, then it loads properly. A working package will work with the decoded slash, e.g: registry.npmjs.org/@angular/core

The packages all exist on NPMJS, *artifactory only checks the decoded slash*, perhaps we can have it check BOTH registry.npmjs.org/@pm2/io and registry.npmjs.org/@pm2%2fio?

We currently have 2 workarounds:
Add package to local
Bypass HEAD requests

NPM debug logs:
 [^pm2-io-2018-08-21T16_03_54_030Z-debug.log]  [^reach-router-2018-08-21T16_08_25_363Z-debug.log]  [^reach-router-install-failed.txt]  [^pm2-io-install-failed.txt]  [^angular-core-install-successful.txt] 

Artifactory logs are just 404:
20180906173933|295|REQUEST|127.0.0.1|admin|GET|/api/npm/npm/@reach%2frouter|HTTP/1.1|404|0

2018-09-06 17:39:13,165 [art-exec-33] [INFO ] (o.a.a.g.i.GemsRemoteIndexHandler:63) - Finished updating remote repo index for gems-remote
2018-09-06 17:39:32,021 [http-nio-8081-exec-8] [DEBUG] (o.j.r.n.r.h.NpmLocalRepoHandler:54) - Handling package metadata request for package 'npm'
2018-09-06 17:39:32,268 [http-nio-8081-exec-8] [INFO ] (o.a.r.HttpRepo      :415) - npm-remote downloading https://registry.npmjs.org/npm 7.72 MB 
2018-09-06 17:39:32,826 [http-nio-8081-exec-8] [INFO ] (o.a.r.HttpRepo      :428) - npm-remote downloaded  https://registry.npmjs.org/npm 7.72 MB at 14,196.83 KB/sec
2018-09-06 17:39:32,843 [http-nio-8081-exec-3] [DEBUG] (o.j.r.n.r.h.NpmLocalRepoHandler:54) - Handling package metadata request for package '@reach/router'
2018-09-06 17:39:33,203 [http-nio-8081-exec-8] [DEBUG] (o.a.a.n.r.m.NpmPackageMetadataMerger:144) - Skipping external dependencies check, config is empty
