column1: "Copy Link" when right clicking on Download in Search Results or Build Browser UI
column39: In the 3.x version of Artifactory Enterprise, you could right click on the Download menu item next to an artifact in the Build Browser or Search Results and copy the link to your clipboard.  In the 4.0 version, the UI changed in a way that this is no longer coming up in either Chrome, Firefox, or IE.  It would be nice to have this back as it makes the ability to copy and share that link a lot easier without having to open the Artifact Tree to get it.
column40:
OS: RHEL 6.5
Java: 1.8.0
Tomcat: Tomcat8 (from Artifactory rpm)
Installation: RPM

column1: Avoid duplication of embedded jars in war, zip & ear files
column39:
A single artifact can be stored in artifactory many hundreds of times. Consider the following

1. foo-common-1.0.jar is a 20mb jar built and deployed to artifactory
2. foo-webapp is a war which includes foo-common-1.0.jar and is deployed to artifactory
3. foo-application is a zip which includes foo-common-1.0.jar and is deployed to artifactory
4. there are 10 versions of foo-webapp and 10 versions of foo-application

This means that in artifactory there will be 21 copies of foo-common-1.0.jar (once for the artifact itself and another 10 embedded into each zip/war version). If foo-common-1.0.jar is a large artifact this can start to chew through disk space pretty quickly.

Artifactory by it's very nature is prone to redundancy / duplication in this way with many wars, zips and ears embedding the exact same jars. 

If artifactory were 'smarter' about disk usage it could inspect artifacts as they are uploaded and inspect them for duplications and store the artifacts in some pointer based file system. When artifacts are retrieved from artifactory, it could piece them back together making sure to check sha1 checksums before and after the 'smartness' is applied.

If this feature were to be implemented, artifactory could provide the exact same functionality as it does today but with drastically reduced disk space requirements, possibly at the cost of a slower response time (I'm sure caching could help here).

Please note that my actual use case involves hundreds of teams which share the foo-common-1.0.jar

Please see my original question on stack overflow 
http://stackoverflow.com/questions/32179265/artifactory-can-i-avoid-embedded-redundancies-for-war-and-zip-artifacts

column1: Property set settings (single value, multi-value) are not enforced when updating property via REST API and user can set a property with any type and any value
column39:
Currently when a user configure a property set he has 3 options:
- Any value: insert any value
- Multi value: select multi values from multi value list 
- Single value: Select a single value from multi value list

When user add a property via reset there is no validation on those settings, only in the UI which makes it a UI only feature while the majority of the use cases of settings properties is done via REST API.

Desired behavior:
If no property set was added to a repo user can set any property he would like with single, multi or any value.
If property set is assigned to repo it should be able to enforce those settings, i.e. 
single value can only be a single value and in case a pre defined set of options was configured user can only select set the property to be one of those values.
multi value can only be set to one or more out of pre configured list of values.

Due to backwards compatibility issues this will be a flag (false by default) "Enforce property settings" that can be set per property.

column1: 4.0 UX improvement - make Artefact upload errors stick around
column39:
Hi - just set up an Artefactory 4.0 instance. For the most part I love the changes to the UI.

However, one big problem: the new AJAX error messages that vanish when you click elsewhere make troubleshooting really hard. I spent this morning trying to upload a large file that was causing Java memory errors, and because I had another window open covering the top right hand side of the page, it took me several failed attempts at uploading it to even realise there was an error message and it wasn't just failing silently.

Can error messages either appear somewhere more obvious, or not disappear until manually acknowledged? 

Suggestions:
- Errors appear in a focal place that the user will pay attention to: near the upload progress bar or the 'deploy' button
- Errors persist until the user clicks to acknowledge them
- Errors grey out the 'deploy' button to make it clear there was a problem with an upload, and that it's not just that site isn't responding

column1: Place volumes into docker file
column39: Place the definitions for the directories that need persisting back into the Dockerfile.  These are stable and it makes upgrading docker images easier and less risky if we don't require more switches on the docker run command line.

column1: Artifactory's Pypi should display the README.md file
column39:
When I browse to a python package in a Web UI, Artifactory should display the project's README.md file.

e.g.  In the central Pypi, I can see argparse's README.md file by hitting:   https://pypi.python.org/pypi/argparse

column1: Artifactory should structure its Pypi browser the same as the central Pypi
column39:
Artifactory makes Python artifacts visible under the  http://my.remote.artifactory/artifactory/api/pypi/simple/python-project/python-project.1.2.3.tar.gz URL.

Pypi, on the otherhand, makes artifacts visible under the http://my.remote.artifactory/artifactory/api/pypi/simple/python-project/1.2.3/python-project.1.2.3.tar.gz URL.

i.e.  the version is not in the simple API's URL.

column1: artifactory should be more tolerant of missing configuration
column39:
scenario:

Artifactory rpm is installed.
An empty directory is mounted on ~artifactory/etc

{code}
service start artifactory
ERROR: ERROR: /etc/opt/jfrog/artifactory/default does not exist or not executable
{code}

There's several ways that this situation could happen, consider a artifactory vm with ephemeral storage like on a pivotal tile, amazon ebs, or mapping a docker volume to a real directory.  We've had a few customers who've fallen into this.

As far as I can tell the only thing that's really needed in ~artifactory/etc is the default file and that is only used by the startup script.  Everything else artifactory can make on the fly during first initialization.

I'm thinking that the shell script should do like the rest of artifactory and create the default file if it doesn't exist.  Should be easy enough, and may help some people.
column252: 08/Aug/15 8:52 AM;chaya;Got this error too with the docker image (Artifactory-oss 4.0.0) when mapping -v $ARITFACTORY_HOME/etc on an empty folder
column253:
14/Dec/15 11:21 PM;aaronr;Other errors happening:

Fail to save backup file '/artifactory/etc/logback.xml.back' from the login file: '/artifactory/etc/logback.xml'

When starting up it will not fully start because of the missing artifactory.lic file. This means the register license REST API call cannot be used.

column1: Blackduck support for Pypi
column39:
Like it has for artifacts in Maven and NuGet, Artifactory should support compliance checks of Python artifacts via its integration with Blackduck (which supports Python).

Use-Case:  Large banks running Python applications on Hadoop environments.

column1: NPM support does not expose README to npm tool
column39:
When a package is published with npm, part of the payload is a README, which the public npm will send down with the rest of the package metadata. Unfortunately Artifactory seems to ignore this, or at least not expose it anywhere.

Reference:
https://github.com/npm/read-package-json/blob/master/README.md#other-relevant-files-besides-packagejson

column1: non-cached remote requests pass on "Accept-Encoding: gzip" header.
column39: If a remote server is passing a "Accept-Encoding: gzip" header type from a remote request it is passed to Artifactory. If the remote repo has the "Do not Store Artifacts Locally" option checked, this will pass the flag along to the downloading client even though the decompression has already been performed. (this does not happen if the remote-cache is enabled). This causes the downloading client to try to handle the on-the-fly decompression improperly, ending in a corrupted artifact.

column1: Ability to use multiple Git LFS repositories
column39: Currently .gitconfig needs to be updated each time a different repository needs to be used for GIT LFS. Please create a way to make the use of multiple GIT LFS repositories easy.

column1: Change repository icons, corresponding to "Repository Type"
column39:
Please consider adding a feature so that the repository icon update automatically according to the Repository Type selected for each repository. 

A screenshot of an example has been attached to this ticket.
column252: 14/Jul/15 6:04 PM;joshuah;A screenshot if new feature is added

column1: Promotion status longer than 64 characters throws an SQLDataException
column39: This exception is due to a database limitation, we should catch this exception and present a more understandable message.

column1: Purpose of Enable Token Authentication unclear
column39:
In the remote docker registry configuration the Enable Token Authentication doesn't really let you know what the ramifications are of setting the switch.  If you set it that breaks normal authentication.  The only visibility that something odd is going on is that the user on the remote end shows up as 'dummy' instead of the credentials supplied.

I'm thinking how it should work is the text in the mouse over for the enable token radio button needs to be expanded.  Additionally graying out the user name and password fields in the advanced tab would be nice, even better would be some sort of message our mouse over prompt saying why the fields are being grayed out.

column1: Add system property to disable "missing URL Base" error banner
column39: In some cases it is desirable to leave the Custom URL Base empty. The problem is, this leaves the missing URL Base error banner in the top of the UI. Need to either have a way to disable this using a property or know when to suppress this warning automatically.

column1: Support for Filtering Maven Optional
column39:
Our java modules have some compile time dependencies which are for the purpose of compile time annotations, the developers have used the maven optional declaration on those dependencies .
https://maven.apache.org/guides/introduction/introduction-to-optional-and-excludes-dependencies.html

Since generally where the optional parameter is used we dont ship the items with our distribution  we feel it would be appropriate to allow the identity and exclusion of such libraries from the license exports, alognside also the alerts and API calls, this should be implemented in a similar manner to that of the maven scope which already allows us to filter compile, runtime etc.

column1: BuildInfo dependencies should be searched by checksum and module id
column39: Currently, BuildInfo dependencies are searched by checksum only; in case of multiple paths, the first path is returned, regardless of whether the artifact name matches the module id in BuildInfo or not. I would like Artifactory to prefer paths where the artifact name matches the module id.

column1: Internal Authentication tries LDAP first if a LDAP Server is configured
column39:
In an environment with mixed internal and ldap users, when you try to log with a user that is flagged as internal, the authentication try to do a bind in ldap first.

It doesn't prevent the user to login, as the user is not found in LDAP it falls back on internal authentication.
But it creates a lot of false errors in the LDAP access log.

Ideally there would be a configuration option to specify order of realms in authentication.

column1: Add the option to publish from the Push To Bintray screen
Nuget feed generated by Artifactory should comply with the nuget gallery feed specifications
column39:
The nuget feed that is being generated by Artifactory has some discrepancies when compared to the feed provided by the nuget gallery. For example, the 'Created' field is returned as a String (http://localhost:8081/artifactory/api/nuget/nuget-local/$metadata) - 

<Property Name="Created" Type="Edm.String" Nullable="true"/>

When the Nuget gallery returns (https://www.nuget.org/api/v2/$metadata) - 

<Property Name="Created" Type="Edm.DateTime" Nullable="false"/>
column252:
22/Sep/15 5:42 PM;cmckenzie;This issue has so far impacted us in the following ways.
* Tooling we wrote to identify old and possibly unused package versions fails because the "Created" field is listed as a string instead of a datetime.
* Tools we have that provide searching and metadata viewing capabilities for nuget packages fail because the artifactory api does not match the expected schema.

Ideally, the artifactory nuget odata feed would be indistinguishable from the one found here: https://www.nuget.org/api/v2/$metadata

column1: security.import.xml should import from $CLUSTER_HOME/ha_etc
column39:
Currently in a HA setup, a security.import.xml file is imported from the $ARTIFACTORY_HOME/etc folder when it should really happen in the $CLUSTER_HOME/ha_etc folder. This is also going to relate to this issue:

https://www.jfrog.com/jira/browse/RTFACT-7598
column252: 22/Jun/15 11:20 PM;aaronr;Linked issue will also happen for security config.

column1: Update to version 3.8.0 automatically set artifactory.repo.global.disabled=true
column39: Upgrading the 3.8.0 set artifactory.repo.global.disabled=true.  This was not documented in the upgrade guide anywhere.  Caused a day wasted by development team as they could not access artifactory while the issue was being debugged.

column1: support automation/official tag in docker search
column39:
we use artifactoy pro for docker registry v2 version, and we want to have better private docker service inside the company.

If I do from docker hub, I can see the official & automation [OK] tag and stars for docker images/

{quote}
docker@boot2docker:~$ docker search ubuntu
NAME                             DESCRIPTION                                     STARS     OFFICIAL   AUTOMATED
ubuntu                           Ubuntu is a Debian-based Linux operating s...   1804      [OK]
torusware/speedus-ubuntu         Always updated official Ubuntu docker imag...   25                   [OK]
ubuntu-upstart                   Upstart is an event-based replacement for ...   25        [OK]
tutum/ubuntu                     Ubuntu image with SSH access. For the root...   25                   [OK]
{quote}

Is it possible to have those things supported in artifactory especially for AUTOMATED metadata ?

like special API inside artifactory to tag it, so we can use it for own CI job to upload and mark it.

Will be nice if you have feature in artifactory jenkins plugin to handle this as well ?

column1: 'Fix Checksums' warning does not apply for all packaging systems / clients
column39:
"Client did not publish a checksum value.
If you trust the uploaded artifact you can accept the actual checksum by clicking the 'Fix Checksum' button."

The warning appears when the deploying client does not provide checksums when uploading and Artifactory calculates it on its own.
This is kind of a 'maveny' approach that does not fit all clients (i.e. Git LFS, NuGet, others?) and might cause confusion with users.

column1: API for re-f
propagateTask should check if the ha-node.properties 'context.url' ends with a '/' and remove it
column39: A task that is triggered from a non-master node is propagated to the master node. Artifactory takes the context.url from the node's ha-node.properties and appends '/api/ha/propagateTask' to it. If the context.url ends with a '/', the propagate task fails because the appended URL has 2 slashes in it.

column1: Publish checksums for Vagrant box files
column39:
Vagrant's metadata.json format provides properties for box file checksum validation.
Please populate values for "checksum_type" and "checksum" properties.

column1: Have Dry Run operation to support before events from user plugins
column39:
Hi,

The "Dry Run" button on the Move dialog does not trigger beforeMove events.
It would be great to have this so that if any move is Cancelled in user plugins then the user can have consistency between "Dry Run" and real operation.

Same thing for Copy or any other operation where "Dry Run" is available.

Thanks,
Regards,
Guillaume

column1: Repository hit rate used for repository ordering
column39: It would be nice if there were a way to see which repositories have artifacts that are resolved most often - number of hits.  That information could be used to manually or automatically tune the repository ordering for higher performance.

column1: Provide smaller url similar to tinyurl
column39:
One of our customer would like to have smaller/smarter urls available for artifacts so that the customer doesn't have to provide the full url.  Something like what TinyUrl does.  It could be shown on the info page of an artifact

http://tinyurl.com/

column1: REST API methods for resolved repositories and repository layouts
column39:
Hi,

Today there is no documentation on any method on the REST API that would allow to view/edit/create Repository Layouts.
There is also no method that allow to see the resolved repositories of a virtual repository.

Is it possible to add such functionality, please.
Thanks,
Regards,

Guillaume
P.S.: RubyGems reindexing REST API is in RubyGems documentation but not in REST API documentation. Can you also fix that please.

column1: For SAML SSO Integration, please add an ability to manage multiple SAML certificates in order to provide controlled rollover from one certificate to another with minimal or no downtime
column39: Artifactory currently allows only one SAML certificate to be placed for the SAML SSO Integration, but we would like to be able to have multiple SAML certificates put into the setting. It is so that we can make the switch from a expired SAML certificate to a new certificate with minimal or no downtime.

column1: Add option to send Bintray user and api key as headers to the Bintray REST api commands
column39:
Should be passed in a similar way to Bintray's api:
X-Bintray-Subject
X-Bintray-ApiKey

column1: Improve the backup/ import process for large storage sizes
column39: We need to try and find a way to improve the import and backup process so it will take less time for large storage size.
column252: 19/Nov/15 9:25 AM;Simon;any update on this?

column1: HA clusters should load plugins for all nodes and just for master
column39:
Some plugins for purposes of updating and non-duplication should be able to be installed in the $CLUSTER_HOME. 

Currently this behaves strangely. The plugin should be documented more clearly for HA and there should be a way to load plugins for all nodes or just for the master node.

column1: Cannot see "Add" button when configuring Push Replication
column39:
When setting up Push Replication, it is possible for the interface to be shrunk, vertically, such that the "Add" button is not visible.  It is not readily apparent that this is a scrollable interface, so it's easy for the user to be confused and unable to add locations to push to.

System: Mac OSX
Browser: Chrome

column1: How to specify the MD5 checksum of .deb when uploading via HTTP API
column39:
I have created a small Bash script in order to upload {{.deb}} files to Artifactory from within a Gradle build.

The upload works as expected but the checksum is created by Artifactory and therefore not trusted until I click the button in the management interface.

The script is attached to the ticket.

Is it possible to also transmit the MD5 sum to the API? If not, than that should be possible.

column1: Enabling "Do not store artifacts locally" makes files unreachable for GC
column39:
If you have a remote cache with artifacts in it and then set the "Do not store artifacts locally" setting the cache will disappear but cannot be garbage collected. In the Storage summary there will be a flag indicating this for that repository. If the cache is re-enabled and files deleted, and then re-enabled the repository cace still shows up in the storage summary as "deleted but not cleaned". This seems misleading.

Empty caches with the "Do not store artifacts locally" option set should either say "disabled" or not be listed. Full caches with the option set should not reference the artifacts and GC should find and delete the unreferenced artifacts.
column252: 02/Oct/15 11:22 PM;omarf;the workaround for this bug is to recreate the deleted remote repository, disable ‘Do not Store Artifacts Locally’. This will allow you to delete the cache, run garbage collection, etc.

column1: Put focus on Username on Login Form
column39: When loading the Artifactory Login form, put the cursor in the Username field so that it's possible to start typing right away (instead of having to click on or tab to the field first).  This probably wouldn't be so annoying if I wasn't having to log in multiple times throughout the day (see RTFACT-4076).

column1: Keep audit for each artifact in Artifactory
column39: Have an audit (History) on every artifact in order to keep track changes. For example, if an artifact was override then by who, when, what were the properties that were changed etc...

column1: artifactory.plugin.scripts.refreshIntervalSecs should be defaulted to 600
column39: When this property is needed is usually during a time when restarting the server to enable it is not desired. it has been proven that this property works well in production instances, the default should be enabled as it is the more common need.

column1: maven-metadata calculation should not be triggered for non-maven layout artifacts
column39:
We currently trigger a comprehensive maven metadata calculation for the entire repository (all maven-metadata.xml's on the repo) when deleting non maven artifacts. Here's how to reproduce - 

1.deploy a maven build to artifactory
2.curl -X PUT -uadmin:password "http://localhost:8081/artifactory/libs-snapshot-local/someFolder/someFile.txt"
3.Delete the file

You can see the metadata calculation acting if you install the below plugin - 
storage {
       afterCreate{item ->
        log.warn item.getRepoPath().toString()
        }
}

The delete of someFile.txt will trigger the calculation of all the maven-metadata xml files of the corresponding repository (and a chain of afterCreate events) - 

2015-03-27 04:40:43,481 [art-exec-7] [WARN ] (afterCreate         :4) - libs-snapshot-local:org/jfrog/test/multi/maven-metadata.xml
2015-03-27 04:40:43,497 [art-exec-7] [WARN ] (afterCreate         :4) - libs-snapshot-local:org/jfrog/test/multi/2.17-SNAPSHOT/maven-metadata.xml
2015-03-27 04:40:43,516 [art-exec-7] [WARN ] (afterCreate         :4) - libs-snapshot-local:org/jfrog/test/multi1/maven-metadata.xml
2015-03-27 04:40:43,534 [art-exec-7] [WARN ] (afterCreate         :4) - libs-snapshot-local:org/jfrog/test/multi1/2.17-SNAPSHOT/maven-metadata.xml
2015-03-27 04:40:43,553 [art-exec-7] [WARN ] (afterCreate         :4) - libs-snapshot-local:org/jfrog/test/multi2/maven-metadata.xml
2015-03-27 04:40:43,567 [art-exec-7] [WARN ] (afterCreate         :4) - libs-snapshot-local:org/jfrog/test/multi2/2.17-SNAPSHOT/maven-metadata.xml
2015-03-27 04:40:43,584 [art-exec-7] [WARN ] (afterCreate         :4) - libs-snapshot-local:org/jfrog/test/multi3/maven-metadata.xml
2015-03-27 04:40:43,599 [art-exec-7] [WARN ] (afterCreate         :4) - libs-snapshot-local:org/jfrog/test/multi3/2.17-SNAPSHOT/maven-metadata.xml

 *Note - this also applies to non maven layout repositories

column1: Download links in tree browser should respect Custom URL Base
column39:
We have a custom base URL set as {{http://xxx}} yet when viewing an artifact in the Tree Browser the Download action link is an {{https://}} link (because we redirect browsers to https for SSO). This mean that when people copy the download link they always need to manually change https to http to put in curl/wget etc commands.
We would like the download link to respect the custom base url as opposed to the base url from the browser.

column1: configuration directory for default
column39:
Usually on linux packages configuration files also support configuration directories.  For instance look at /etc/profile and /etc/profile.d, files in the directory are appended to /etc/profile to build a configuration on the fly.  This allows changes to a configuration in an upgradable without resorting to merging configuration files or replacing them with new files from the new rpms.

We've been running into customers who have to make changes to their $ARTIFACTORY_HOME/etc/default file, when artifactory is upgraded the new configuration file replaces their edited one.  If instead we read files out of $ARTIFACTORY_HOME/etc/default.d/ in addition to reading the current file users would be able to make changes that would live over upgrades to artifactory.

column1: "Compress The Internal Database" should compress more tables
column39:
The "Compress The Internal Database" function (Artifactory --> Admin Tab --> Maintenance) is presently only cleaning up the "BINARIES" table in the Derby DB, so the rest of the DB is blowing up because it's not being cleaned up.

You can see this in the code at org.artifactory.storage.db.DerbyUtils#compressDataStore

At the very least, we can see that the BUILD_DEPENDENCIES, BUILD_JSONS, and MODULE_PROPS tables are problematic

column1: Customer Request: ability to examine & take action on components contained in zip files
column39:
From the ticket:

Customer wishes to be able to examine identifying characteristics (md5sums) for artifacts contained within an archive (zip).
 They would prefer to not download a the archive if it contains a file already present on the local filesystem.
 Customer is using our REST API.

column1: We want to be able to exclude OSS license checks on your published modules and run only on the build’s dependencies.
column39: Basically, we want to exclude any of our own libraries from the version check.  For example, can we exclude com.spartasystems.* from showing up in the open source license check.  Each time we add our own library, it causes an issue to the open source licenses check.

column1: Allow to request archived response from REST API
column39:
Certain REST API calls may return a JSON response that is very large. The following request:{code}https://repo.jfrog.org/artifactory/api/storage/repo1-cache?list&deep=1&listFolders=0{code} gives back a 1Gb (!!) JSON file. If one could request an archived response in GET parameters (rather than traditional HTTP headers) and retrieve a zip/gz-ed JSON instead that would speed up greatly the download part of it. Same 1Gb JSON from the example above archives nicely as 167Mb zip/gz archive.

This could look like:
{code}https://repo.jfrog.org/artifactory/api/storage/repo1-cache?list&deep=1&listFolders=0&archive=zip
{code}
or
{code}https://repo.jfrog.org/artifactory/api/storage/repo1-cache?list&deep=1&listFolders=0&archive=gz
{code}

column1: Debian-Repository: Mark Release, Packages and Sources as viewable
column39:
As a user of the Web-UI 
I want to view Release, Packages and Sources files of Debian distributions directly
So I do not have to download and open them in a text-editor.

We use Artifactory for dpkg as well and sometimes want to take a look into the Release, Packages and Sources files. However, as these have no extension, we are not able to configure this ourselves via the mime-types.xml.

Regards
Mirko Friedenhagen

column1: The repositories.getStats() Java doc should be more detailed
column39:
When using the papi repositories.getStats() on a file that has no stats (or a directory), the return type will be null.
Currently, the docs only mentioned that it may be null, but without giving any example or reason.

column1: Change the form name of proxy username/password fields so they do not autofill
column39: username/password fields in configuration pages often autofill because of their form names which can cause issues. Should rename them so browsers do not target them for autofill.

column1: More information from Storage Dashboard
column39:
Enhancements requested in the Storage Summary dashboard: 
 1. Ability to export the dashboard metrics to Excel (or other formats)
 2. Ability to pull the dashboard data using a REST API
 3. Ability to add/remove columns from the Storage Summary (eg: Public Description of Repository)
 4. Please include below metrics also:-
 No. of artifacts deployed/added in the last 24 hours (and their size) to Artifactory
 No. of artifacts deleted in the last 24 hours (and their size) from Artifactory
 5. An Audit tab that shows which users deployed which artifacts at what time. Would be useful to track downloads similarly too. 
 6. Historic trends of data usage on different repositories

The above is all useful information for any kind of repository administrator, and would surely benefit every organization.

column1: Remove ability to delete repositories with content
column39: Right now, repositories containing content can be deleted using either the REST API or the console.  Although the console does prompt the user prior to deletion, it would be nice if deletion of repositories (via either method) could be disabled in the Artifactory configuration.  This would help protect users from accidental deletion.

column1: Allign with the behavior of latest YUM createrepo
column39:
The latest version of YUM createrepo includes a few changes to the way Yum repositories are created:
* Include the file's checksum in the metadata filename, helps HTTP caching (see --unique-md-filenames) 
* The default  checksum type used in repomd.xml and for packages in the metadata is now "sha256" (if python has hashlib). The older default was "sha", which is actually "sha1", however explicitly using "sha1" doesn't work on older (3.0.x) versions of yum, you need to specify "sha".

The new behavior should be configurable so we can continue supporting older version of Yum.

For more info see http://linux.die.net/man/8/createrepo
column252:
17/Dec/14 9:00 PM;ted.sheibar;The lack of generating sqlite databases contributes to a scalability issue, as more time is taken each deployment to rebuild the yum cache from an xml file after being downloaded from Artifactory. Our company follows continuous integration & delivery practices, and so has multiple deployments, across multiple products, multiple times a day. Any extra time added to that process, therefore, has a profound effect on our SDLC. It is our sincere hope that this improvement gets JFrog's attention sooner than later.

Thanks very much

column1: REST API call for Update Repository Configuration does not include P2 config
column39:
No way to influence P2 configuration of an Artifactory virtual repository via REST API.

NOTE: upon completion Documentation must be updated.
column252:
15/Dec/14 7:27 PM;michal;As a temporary solution for this issue please refer to this user’s plugin:
https://github.com/JFrogDev/artifactory-user-plugins/blob/master/config/getAndSetP2Url.groovy
This plugin will enable you to overcome the version issues by executing cURL commands. In order to deploy this plugin you’ll need to copy this plugin into $ARTIFACTORY_HOME/etc/plugin. In addition you’ll need to set up $ARTIFACTORY_HOME/etc/artifactory.system.properties to load the plugin by setting artifactory.plugin.scripts.refreshIntervalSecs to a value greater than 0.

This plugin supports two commands: 
getP2Urls - returns the current P2 settings in your artifactory. the cURL command to execute this is: curl 

-uadmin:password -X POST "http://localhost:8081/artifactory/api/plugins/execute/getP2Urls?params=repo=repoKey"   Set the value of repoKey to the name of your P2 virtual repository. 
modifyP2Urls - Will modify the P2 according to the version set up in the json file. 
An example to a json file could be:
{
"repo": "p2-virtual","urls": [
         "http://dl.google.com/eclipse/plugin/3.7",
         "http://download.eclipse.org/releases/luna",
         "http://download.eclipse.org/mylyn/releases/luna",
         "http://download.eclipse.org/eclipse/updates/4.4",
"local://p2-local/eclipse-repository/eclipse-repository/1.0.0-SNAPSHOT/eclipse-repository-1.0.0-20141213.002711-2.zip!/"
]
}

The cURL command would be:

curl -uadmin:password -T /path/to/jsonFile  -X POST "http://localhost:8081/artifactory/api/plugins/execute/modifyP2Urls"

As a note, we still plan to improve this with a more permanent solution. Please watch and vote for these tickets so you will receive updates on future development.
column253:
31/Aug/15 8:59 AM;alpoga;Thanks for the workaround!

I just tested the "modifyP2Urls" API call and it seems to be slightly broken with Artifactory 4.0.2. I have raised an issue on the GitHub page: https://github.com/JFrogDev/artifactory-user-plugins/issues/34

It is possible to fix the issue by removing the call to "repoDescriptor.isP2Support()" on line 103.

column1: Moving an artifact in the tree browser view resets the entire folder hierarchy view when move completes
column39:
If I use the Artifactory web UI repository browser view and navigate through the folder hierarchy (expanding multiple levels of folders in the process) to select an artifact to move an artifact to another repository, when the move action completes, the folder view in the repository browser is reset (to the default?) view, ie. all folders are closed as if I had clicked the "Artifacts" tab.

This can be a real nuisance when moving multiple artifacts as each time I need to expand the same folders in the tree again to find the next artifact to move.

It would be nice if Artifactory would just keep the existing view once the move action completes (OK if you need to close up the one folder that it was moved from, but please don't close up all the parent folders as well!)

column1: Run license checks as part of the build independently of CI server
column39:
Currently, run license checks cam be performed as part of the build, but only if "... you run a build from your CI server" (see https://www.jfrog.com/confluence/display/RTF/License+Control ).
Can there be an option for maven builds to run a license check directly (i.e. as a command)?

column1: Add logback appender for replication
column39: Separate the fine grain logs of replication to a separate log file. The replication and summary should also be logged to the main logger.

column1: Crowd users not synchronized should not be able to log into Artifactory
column39: Currently users who are part of the Crowd Server but have not been synchronized in Artifactory can log in.  Should have an option to only allow synchronized users.

column1: More Filters for the REST API
column39:
I'm currently working on the Artifactory Pro Integration for VersionEye Enterprise. Specially using this Endpoint from the REST API: 

http://www.jfrog.com/confluence/display/RTF/Artifactory+REST+API#ArtifactoryRESTAPI-FileList 

Would be awesome to have more filter options. For example for file types. I would like to get back only pom files. In everything else I'm not interested.

column1: Only one admin should be enforced to have an internal password
column39:
Original request: Forcing Admin to have an internal password is not needed and should not be mandatory.

This behavior is meant to prevent a scenario where there is no admin user with an internal password which might cause all admin users to lock out of Artifactory due to a misconfiguration of LDAP.
System should verify there is at least one admin user with an internal password at all times.
column252: 22/Sep/14 9:22 AM;royz;Related to: https://www.jfrog.com/jira/browse/RTFACT-6356
column253: 13/Nov/14 8:47 PM;jamesmcshane;This allows an administrative user from LDAP to authenticate using two different passwords.  There should be an option to require the single administrative user with an internal password to be an internal user.

column1: Permission target screen should include a filter to search a user/group
column39:
While trying to manage permissions in the Artifactory permission target screen - users/groups tab, the interface does not scale well for large numbers of pages and it is difficult to navigate when there are many pages of users/groups.
I needs a mechanism that will improve the navigation such as filter to search the user/group
column252: 10/Oct/14 7:02 PM;aaronr;Also applies to groups in Crowd -> synchronize groups.

column1: Posibility to rename artifacts when promoting
column39:
As far as I can see from the documentation, there's no way to promote a build and change the artifact's name/path on the same process.

My use case is, I have the artifacts in the CI repo following this naming pattern:
{{product_name-X.Y.Z-b999.zip}} For version X.Y.Z, build 999

When promoting this build, I'd like to get rid of the build number in the naqme:
{{product_name-X.Y.Z.zip}} For version X.Y.Z once it's released.

I know I could "move" the artifacts once they have been promoted, but that means giving the service account used for promotion the "delete" permission. The reason for not doing that is so artifacts can not be accidentally overwritten.

Thanks

column1: Artifactory log should not print INFO message for every path that is not found
column39:
When browsing through a virtual repository into a path that is not exist in the aggregated repositories, Artifactory sometimes print into the log the the similar INFO messages as the following
2014-09-12 15:43:46,289 [http-bio-8081-exec-9] [INFO ] (o.a.r.s.RepositoryBrowsingServiceImpl:236) - Error while listing remote resources for jcenter/orgjfrog/jfrogorg/orgjfrog: Not Found
...

column1: NuGet error for package version not found is not descriptive
column39:
The error occurs when a nuget package is requested that has an incomplete version string specified.

Referencing a package as such:
<package id="SomePackage" version="2.0.7" targetFramework="net40" />

Version "2.0.7" does not actually exist in the local nuget repository, so the server is calling out to the remote repos in an effort to resolve the package.

Calling:
http://localhost:8081/artifactory/api/nuget/nuget-virtual/Packages(Id='SomePackage',Version='2.0.7')

Which returns:
{
  "errors" : [ {
    "status" : 404,
    "message" : "Not Found"
  } ]
}
And then the below corresponding pattern will be in the artifactory.log:

2014-09-12 12:02:44,394 [http-bio-8081-exec-2375] [WARN
] (o.a.a.n.o.r.PackageEntryResponseBuilder:57) - No entity found in entityset Packages for key Id='SomePackage',Version='2.0.7' and query info []

2014-09-12 12:02:44,394 [http-bio-8081-exec-2375] [DEBUG] (o.a.a.n.NuGetServiceImpl:888) - Executing remote NuGet query: https://ci.appveyor.com/nuget/appveyer-user-15dvq7rlh05a/Packages(Id='SomePackage',Version='2.0.7')?includePrerelease=false&includeAllVersions=false

2014-09-12 12:02:44,683 [http-bio-8081-exec-2375] [ERROR] (o.a.a.n.NuGetServiceImpl:804) - Unable to perform a remote NuGet query on 'https://ci.appveyor.com/nuget/appveyer-user-15dvq7rlh05a' with the parameters
 'filter='null', orderBy='null', searchTerm='null', targetFramework='null', includePrerelease='false' skiptoken='null' skip='null', top='null', select='null', inlinecount='null' id='null', packageIds='null', versions='null' includeAllVersions='false'': HTTP/1.1
 404 Not Found
 
Please update the error message in the log to be less confusing. If there is a large number of valid packages being pulled down in parallel, the debug message is lost in the noise of other successful remote queries. Additionally, if debug is not turned on, the the error has no real info as to what is calling it with all the "null" parameters. Tracking this down is additionally difficult since the order which the nuget packages are restored is non-deterministic; if builds fail to finish, their nuget restores at different points.

column39: show a repository's includes pattern and excludes pattern in the repository's Info window for non admin users

column1: Folder deletion should not be done in one transaction
column39:
Delete folder in Artifactory can consume a lot of memory and even lead to java out of memory.
The deletion should be spitted to a few transactions to avoid this.

11/Feb/15 2:06 AM;charlesk;Hi there,
Would this still be a problem if we are just deleting a folder with no children?

So for an example, if we are trying to delete "folder1".
/repo1/folder1/foo.txt
vs
/repo1/folder1/1/2/3/4
/repo1/folder1/1/2/a/b

Thanks.

column1: Enhance Grapes compatibility for user plugins
column39:
Trying to use Grapes dependency resolution in a user plugin. Artifactory lacks the ability to populate the disk cache (~/.groovy/grapes or etc/plugin/lib) in advance.The embedded Groovy ignores @GrabResolver, which is undocumented. ~/.groovy/grapeConfig.xml is the recommended way to deal with that. 

~/.groovy/grapeConfig.xml can point to localhost to resolve through the Artifactory itself, but it causes deadlocks, especially when Artifactory uses a proxy. Suggest splitting the plugin registration process in two steps, first upload the plugin, resolving the dependencies and populating the cache, then activating the plugin upon restart and resolving the dependencies from cache. Artifactory could be configured to scan etc/plugin, but it is not recommended in production and upload is a more elegant solution. Upload can check and copy grapeConfig.xml if needed. 

The embedded Groovy may have problems when @Grapes find dependencies that are already included in Artifactory itself. Should provide ivy.xmls for jars included in Artifactory and add configuration to grapeConfig.xml so that modules corresponding to libraries in Artifactory are always resolved to the Artifactory distro. Artifactory should use <modules> in <ivysettings> to set a filesystem <resolver> that points to libraries in Artifactory so that Ivy in Grapes will be aware of them. Then you could just include grapeConfig.xml in the distribution (and, of course, ivy.xml for Artifactory libraries).
column252:
04/Sep/14 6:46 AM;gintas;This is a related to RTFACT-6562, RTFACT-6308, RTFACT-5864
etc/plugins/lib with random jars is a cludge

column1: Prevent download and remote listing of non "repo" resources when the request in coming from a global Virtual repo
column39:
Prevent download and remote listing of non "repo" resources when the request in coming from a global Virtual repo.
This issue was fixed for RubyGems and should be resolved for Nuget, NPM and other environments.

column1: DistributionManagement/Repository Reference panels always show http
column39: Even when accessed through https

column1: Split off the garbage collection logging into a separate file
column39:
Since garbage collection is such a critical part of customer issues, we should be logging it to a separate file.  We should also add the logger to the logback.xml file by default as 

<logger name="org.artifactory.storage.db.binstore">
        <level value="warn"/>
</logger>

column1: Age of the deployed artifacts is not from created day
column39:
The issue is that the age in General tab on the artifact itself is very high.

The scenario can occur once a file is resolved from a remote repository  and Artifactory gets the last updated time from the remote repository or when deploying artifacts from an archive file (exploding the archive content to Artifactory) the last updated time of the artifact in Artifactory is identical as the last updated time of the file inside the archive.

The only scenario that is different is when manually deploying artifact (single artifact and not exploding from an archive) as the upload is based on streaming which doesn’t serve the “Last modified” property to Artifactory, therefore Artifactory is allocating the current time as the last modified property.
 
The age is calculated by : (current time) - (last modified).
column252:
20/Aug/14 5:59 AM;Simon;In fact users doesn't want to have different "Age" calculations depending on the deployment method - which in fact cannot be seen when accessing the artifact.

A user sees an artifact and just gets the following information presented:
- Creation date 
- Age

The human logic sais that the age depends on the creation date - if a file gets created, it's existence is referred to this date.

Next is there can be two files present maybe within the same directory with the same creation date but different ages. This is not explanable to any user of Artifactory.
column253:
20/Aug/14 6:00 AM;Simon;What we need to have is one of those Enhancements:
- Change the age calculation to the upload date and not the modification age (possible solution: changeable by server configuration)
or
- add a new artifact information for the "Artifactory Age" or something else.

Enhancement one (server configuration) is the preferred one.

column1: 404 response from Artifactory is cached indefinitely
column39: Need to send a header telling the browser not to cache the response

column1: Packages tab in Repo configurations needs redesign
column39:
There are currently 7 supported packages and more will come, making the packages tab very cumbersome and difficult to navigate. Some packages require additional configuration (NuGet). The per package panel should only be displayed for enabled packaging.
Selecting multiple packages should warn the user that it is not advised.

column1: Property sets should not require set name as part of property name
column39:
Property sets would be more useful if we could create a property set without requiring the set name to be part of the property name. I am able to create Artifactory properties named "application_name", "release_type" etc. and add these to the build using the TeamCity plugin. 
When I want to search for artifacts using the property search, I am forced to type in the property name, as I can't save "application_name" or "release_type" in a property set. 
If I instead name my property <something>.<something else> I can create a property set using <something> as the set name.

This is an odd restriction that's not documented anywhere I've seen.

column1: Log actions during dryRun
column39: During dryRun of Artifactory REST services there is no logging on the server-side as what actions would be performed, would it be actual service invocation. This logging would be of great help while writing and debugging some potentially destructive service invocation.

column1: GC tasks triggered during task already running queues rather than rejecting
column39: When a cron trigger causes a GC job when the GC job is already running, it will queue the GC job.  This is not desired as this would cause endless GC jobs if they take too long which would hinder performance.  The job should instead be rejected and logged if there is already a job running.

column1: Allow users with deploy permission to calculate YUM metadata
License files within artifacts cannot be associated
column39: When using the "Search For Archive License File" link in the general properties for an artifact the license.txt file is found and can be viewed but there is no way to associate it with an artifact within Artifactory and therefore no way to do a property search based on the contents of that license.txt file.

column1: User plugins property closures should be triggered when deleting or deploying a folder with matrix params
column39:
When deploying a folder with matrix parameters (which translate into properties in Artifactory), the user plugin property closures should be triggered.

For example:
curl -X PUT -uadmin:password "http://host:port/artifactory/libs-release-local/org/jfrog/test/;qa=true" 

should trigger the 'afterPropertyCreate' closure

Currently, the closures are only triggered when deploying file with matrix params, or when using the REST-API set property query.

column1: Artifactory should support "/./" and "/*/" for deployment path
column39:
Artifactory should support deployment URLs containing the dot (.) symbol representing the current directory.
Currently when deploying to such a URL, for example: http://localhost:8081/artifactory/ext-release-local/foo/./1.0/foo-1.0.jar, Artifactory will fail with an internal error:

{noformat}Sending HTTP error code 500: Cannot save item LockEntryId ext-release-local:foo/.. Mutable item is null.{noformat}

This is highly relevant for cases when a client, such as apt-get, is resolving from a remote repository and automatically adds the dot symbols.

column1: inconsistent support for searching virtual repos (Artifact Version Search = yes; Checksum Search = no)
inconsistent behavior from empty search (Artifact Version Search vs. Checksum Search)
column39:
Artifactory responds to an empty search from Artifact Version Search with a 404 HTTP status code.

Artifactory response to an empty search from Checksum Search with a 200 HTTP status code, and an empty list in the "results" JSON.

It's hard to say which of these is "right", but it seems very odd to me that they are not the same.  Furthermore, the documentation for neither of these addresses what the behavior for an empty search is:

* http://www.jfrog.com/confluence/display/RTF/Artifactory+REST+API#ArtifactoryRESTAPI-ArtifactVersionSearch
* http://www.jfrog.com/confluence/display/RTF/Artifactory+REST+API#ArtifactoryRESTAPI-ChecksumSearch
column252:
25/Jul/14 6:25 PM;rich.fromm;There is a precedent for other API calls returning bad behavior within JSON, and not through error HTTP status codes.  Both Move Item and Copy Item generally return a 200, and express badness through WARNING and ERROR "messages" in the JSON.  I think this is arguably justified for several reasons:

* move and copy can be recursive, and some operations can pass, and others can fail.  HTTP status codes don't adequately allow for the addressing of partial failures
* move and copy can execute operations that pass, but deserve special attention via warnings.  HTTP status codes allow for the communication of errors, but not warnings.

But neither of these are true for a search operation.

column1: Allow "promotion" of non-Maven builds
column39:
According to the documentation, you can only access "promotion" of builds when using a maven build.

It would be useful to be able to define promotion for a specific build or repository, so that artifacts can be easily moved from one repository to the next either through the Web UI or through the TeamCity plugin, when our build is not a Java/maven project.

column1: Support for license status from Blackduck on File compliance info REST query
column39: Return the code center artifact approval status (Approved, Deferred, Rejected etc.) as part of the "File Compliance Info" REST API

column1: property search REST query on a virtual repository returns an empty JSON
column39: Property search is not supported on virtual repositories, the response should reflect that instead of returning an empty JSON object.

column1: The Artifactory logs should include property changes information
column39:
When adding/setting property to a file, the Artifactory log should include this information.

Currently, the only entry that is available in the request.log is when running the property set REST-API query, the request.log will only print similar information as the following:
20140629105637|26|REQUEST|127.0.0.1|admin|PUT|/api/storage/ext-release-local/file.jar|HTTP/1.1|204|-1

column1: Add option to bypass proxy for certain hosts
column39:
Can you please add an option to proxy definition page to bypass proxy for certain hosts? This is a fairly common concept, e.g. on linux, tools such as curl and wget observe no_proxy environment variable. All browsers also have this option.

Detailed reasoning below:

We are using artifactory to proxy python pypi packages via a third party tool called pypi_redirect. This tool intercepts request for pip packages and translates them by sending a http redirect (302) back to the caller (artifactory). So in summary, artifacotory needs to talk to both http://localhost:9292/ and htttp://pypi.python.org/

Now, since we are behind a corporate web proxy, we need to tell artifactory about the proxy so it can reach http://pypi.python.org/. However, by doing this, it can't talk to http://localhost:9292 because it it trying to reach it by going through the proxy. There are ways to get around this but it is non-optimal. It would be better if you could just define a bypass rule instead.

Of course, an even better solution is for artifactory to be able to support proxing pypi repositories natively so we don't need to resort to third party tools!

Many thanks
column252:
07/Jan/19 2:41 PM;Wim Lauwers;Even though there's now PyPi support natively, this would solve another problem: when changing the default system proxy, it gets applied retroactively on all remote repositories. We have a mix of remote repo's both on the Internet and our Intranet. For the Internet we must have the proxy, for the Intranet it's unnecessary (it works for most but it's much slower than going directly). We must have a system default proxy or search in remote repo;s doesn't work.

Another solution would be to not retroactively apply this proxy, but having this new feature would be great as well, since the number of Intranet domain names is limited and we don't have to remember when we do or don't have to use a proxy.

column1: Email alert when disk space usage reaches preset threshold
column39:
Justification:
Currently information on looming disk space shortage is clearly displayed at the top of the application screen. This is good as far as people actually use GUI.
In environment that routinely uses REST API to deploy items to and to resolve items from repositories, it is easy to miss this disk space alert. 

Request: enable email alert to Artifactory owner whenever storage space limit & warning are reached.

column1: Remove the warning about plugins reload in production and set default reload to 15 min
column39:
People have to restart their production servers to reload plugins. That's a bad practice.

Good practice is to have reload enabled with a relatively big interval (15m). 
Let's make it a default.

column1: Maven settings file doesn't contain the httpConfiguration
column39:
The Maven settings file is missing:

<configuration>
        <httpConfiguration>
          <all>                    
                <usePreemptive>true</usePreemptive>                    
          </all>
        </httpConfiguration>
      </configuration>

column1: Display LDAP user attributes when performing connection test in the LDAP panel
Unnecessary maven-specific options when manually deploying an artifact
column39: It confusing to have maven-specific options when manually deploying to a repo with a non-maven layout. Therefore "Deploy as Maven artifact" should be unchecked in such cases. It may require that layout information is made available in Artifactory API.

column1: Allow permission targets to be renamed via the "Permissions Management" UI
column39:
Per a discusssion with JFrog support:

Permission targets can be renamed by editing/saving the security descriptor through the admin UI. However, permission targets cannot be renamed by editing the target itself in the "Permissions Management" section (the "Name" field is disabled).

Since renaming targets is technically possible through the descriptor, this restriction on the UI side doesn't make sense. The way we leverage targets causes us to have to rename them sometimes, and editing the descriptor isn't practical because we have a large number of targets.
column252: 14/Nov/19 8:51 AM;andrey-kuznetsov;As of now, security descriptor is readonly, so there is no way to rename permission now.
column253:
15/Dec/20 2:50 AM;nishant.kansal@ukg.com;I too was looking for this option until I got the reference to this issue.

Any update on whether this will be available in the future?

column1: Add to the exclude/include patterns to exclude/include by artifact checksum
column252: 02/Mar/14 10:42 AM;ariels;This will be very helpful when we know that there is a junk file that is flushed to the online servers and we want to block it.

column1: Auto-import user details from LDAP
column39:
When using the "Users Management" feature, I want to add in a new user I know in in my LDAP server (prior to them logging into Artifactory).

I can click "New" and enter the user ID that I know matches the value in the LDAP directory. I can assign permissions and add the user to internally managed groups.

However, it would be much nicer if instead of New, there were an "Retrieve" or similar to get the user details into Artifactory from LDAP (e.g. email address, "real name").

column1: Retrieve and use user's real name from LDAP
column39:
It is not unusual when using AD to authenticate using a username stored in sAMAccountName.

This is supported by setting the LDAP search filter to (&(sAMAccountName={0})(objectcategory=user))

However, the sAMAccountName rarely equals the user's real name and it would be helpful if:
1. This was retrieved from the LDAP server (probably from the cn of the found entity)
2. The real name was displayed (instead of or as well as) the login ID where it makes sense - e.g. in "Users Management", Group Management, etc.

column1: Have a read access to repository configuration for non-admin users
column39:
Hello,

We have a lot of support to do to our user because they are not aware of the configuration of the repository they are using.
We can provide a separated view through a plugin but having read access to the admin tab (at least some parts) for non admin users could be somehow interesting.

Thanks,
Regards,

Guillaume

column1: howto get/delete a build using build_number and started with rest API
Support SSH layer for login into Artifactory.
Export REST-API JSON should contain the excludeBuilds parameter
column39: The 'artifactory.system.ExportSettings+json' should contain parameter to exclude builds

column1: Delete versions when top checkbox is checked remove all versions
column39: It would be better if the user have to options to choose between deleting all versions in current page and deleting all versions
column252:
12/Feb/14 6:55 AM;cblomqvist;Some suggestions:
1. Put this text in the GUI:
"*Note: Ticking the topmost box affects all versions on all pages!*"

2. Have the confirmation popup list the number of versions it is going to delete.

3. Display this text in the confirmation popup when relevant: 
{panel:title=Warning!|borderColor=#ccc|titleBGColor=#F7D6C1|bgColor=#FFFFCE}
You are deleting ALL versions! 
Are you sure?
{panel}

column1: Add support for "Content-Disposition" to the "PUT" concerning file uploads.
column39:
Hello,

At the moment, the "PUT" method handling implemented by the RESTful API layer does not support file uploads when the "Content-Type" is set to be "multipart/form-data" and relevant "Content-Disposition" header is preset. This is often true, when an underlying HTTP library (and a lot of them do it) send a file to the remote server using aforementioned approach, instead of just streaming the content of the file (performing rather a crude "PUT" to the server.

Lack of support in such a case causes all the extra information related to the "Content-Type: multipart/form-data" and "Content-Disposition: form-data" (namely the boundary details and content MIME type, etc) being saved as part of the artefact itself corrupting its content in due process.

For example, given the following upload example:

{code}
kwilczynski@ukml13899 ~/Artifactory$ echo 'This is a test ...' > test.txt
kwilczynski@ukml13899 ~/Artifactory$ date >> test.txt

kwilczynski@ukml13899 ~/Artifactory$ cat test.txt

--40e8a89fcbb443bd9c6ff771e4fcd05f

This is a test ...
Mon Feb 10 14:12:21 GMT 2014

--40e8a89fcbb443bd9c6ff771e4fcd05f--

kwilczynski@ukml13899 ~/Artifactory$ diff -uNr test.txt test.txt-new

+++ test.txt-new	2014-02-10 14:12:44.000000000 +0000
@@ -1,2 +1,7 @@
+--40e8a89fcbb443bd9c6ff771e4fcd05f
+Content-Disposition: form-data; name="file"; filename="test.txt"
+
 This is a test ...
 Mon Feb 10 14:12:21 GMT 2014
+
+--40e8a89fcbb443bd9c6ff771e4fcd05f--
{code}

As can be seen above, extra information was saved alongside rest of the content.

It would be of a great help of Artifactory would support "Content-Type: multipart/form-data" and utilise boundary information from within the "Content-Disposition" header to correctly save the payload.

Thank you for help and all the hard work in advance!

KW

column1: Better handling of public/private keys for user authentication
column39:
I think the way to manage user password encryption is a bit strange: the private keys are stored unencrypted, and they seem only to be used as a "password" for PBE (the related code is in CryptoHelper.java)

I suggest the following approach:
  - Generate a key pair, the private key being encrypted (with PBE) using the user password (or let the user import it).
  - Generate some random token
  - Generate a signature on the token, using the private key. The user would do this on his profile page (since the current password is already required, this would allow to unlock/decrypt the private key and sign the data).
  - The user has to copy the signature as the "encrypted" password, similarly to what he does with a "{DESede}" password.

When the user tries to log in with his encrypted password, the following is done: 
  - the encrypted password, which is in fact a signature, is checked against the token and the public key. 

Benefits:
  - The private key of the user is stored encrypted and cannot be compromised easily even if the attacker has access to the server hosting Artifactory.
  - Only the token and the user public key are used for verification.

I added code examples as a small maven project.

column39:

With that:

Also, it is possible in 3.x and above to change the data/filestore (the biggest and most important folder in data) using the "binary.provider.filesystem.dir" property in the storage.properties file.
Documentation is here: http://www.jfrog.com/confluence/display/RTF/Changing+the+Default+Storage

Filestore and backup re-routing to hardcoded separated folder or disks seems sufficient for most usage.
Do you have other needs?
column254:
24/Jan/14 3:15 PM;andrew.bilukha@sac.com;Definitely, symlink on Windows is not practical -- no one does this in Enterprise environment, nor will we.
As for your other comment regarding the binary.provider.filesystem.dir property in storage.properties file -- it's not even there. Below is our storage.properties file.  The documentation page you are referring me to appears to be incomplete -- it does not explain to set to what values in which files, and paths to those files.  Examples are pivotal.  However natural the supposition could be to the person that wrote the page that the reader of that article is a Pro with your tool --  it's erroneous. The info really should be spelled out step-by-step.

{code}
type=derby
url=jdbc:derby:{db.home};create=true
driver=org.apache.derby.jdbc.EmbeddedDriver

## Determines where the actual artifacts binaries are stored. Available options:
## filesystem - binaries are stored in the filesystem (recommended, default)
## fullDb     - binaries are stored as blobs in the db, filesystem is used for caching
## cachedFS   - binaries are stored in the filesystem, but a front cache (with faster access) is added
## IMPORTANT NOTE: This property should not be change after the initial setup. To change binaries storage you have to export and import
#binary.provider.type=filesystem

## Determines the maximum filesystem cache size in bytes when using binary provider type fullDb or cachedFS. Default is 5GB
## Supported units are GB (gigabytes), MB (megabytes) and KB (kilobytes)
#binary.provider.cache.maxSize=5GB
{code}

And lastly, Frederic,  May I suggest just for the benefit of your brand and software, to invest into a Windows installer -- something created with InstallShield that takes an admin or evaluator through the first steps of installing and configuring your software.  The frustration you save to the person that evaluates your soft for the first time will turn into real dollars when the prospective client does not walk away from the frustration of setting things up.

column1: Improve logging of blackduck connectivity
Please add a REST api to determine if a path is a file or a folder
column39:
Full details are here:
https://github.com/JFrogDev/artifactory-client-java/issues/21

"OK, now I see what you mean. Currently the REST API does not expose a query that returns you an answer whether some path is a file or a folder. Here's what you can do:
1. Open a JIRA request for it.
2. In a meanwhile you can implement isFolder(repoPath) on the repositoryHandle by calling the File List request without listing the folders to determine whether the requested path is present in the list or not (if present - file, if not - folder)."

For an ssh proxy, I need to query for an item and get basic details about it.
Right now, I end up making 2 rest calls, one for a file and one for a folder combined with isFolder to determine if the object exists, and what type of object it is.

Using a httpclient based artifactory client, I am able to call:

http://test.artifactory/artifactory/api/storage/areese-ssh-proxy-test/com/yahoo/dps/sshd/0.0.1-SNAPSHOT/maven-metadata.xml

or:
http://test.artifactory/artifactory/api/storage/areese-ssh-proxy-test/com/yahoo/dps/sshd/0.0.1-SNAPSHOT/

and parse the resulting json to decide if it's a file or a folder.
The important things attributes I care about are:

children
created
lastModified
lastUpdated
repo
size
uri

I need children because if it's a folder, I want to be able to list the children.

I'm trying to move off of our home built artifactory client, and with the exception of this bump it's working.
:)

column1: REST API call for enabling replication/setting cron replication expression
column39:
My team is working on a dashboard for our Artifactory instances. One of the ideas proposed is to be able to configure replication on a remote repo from a single dashboard via the REST API as opposed to have to go into each remote site and enable replication/set the cron expressions manually. We maintain a decent amount of Artifactory instances(15+) and it's a lot of work to log into each server and setup replication every time we want to add a repo. 

After looking into whats available from the current REST API, I don't see a way of doing this in the current repo-config JSON. Is it possible to add this as a part of the repo-config JSON?

column1: catalina logs should be rotated
column39: The log files in ARTIFACTORY_HOME/logs/catalina are rotated differently (logging.properties) than the log files in ARTIFACTORY_HOME/logs (logback.xml).  Specifically, they use org.apache.juli.FileHandler which doesn't have any functionality to specify the maximum number of log files to keep, so the logs pile up until they fill the disk.  The catalina log files should use the same log rotation mechanism as the other log files.

column1: Allow POST for SetItemProperties
column39:
My use case is to upload a larger file (>100 lines) with free text information from a legacy build process.
What would work best for me would be if I could POST this file in a similar way to http://www.jfrog.com/confluence/display/RTF/Artifactory+REST+API#ArtifactoryRESTAPI-SetItemProperties
At present I urlencode the contents of the file and use the existing SetItemProperties with PUT, however I am afraid that there will be some files that are too large to be sent as contents of an URL. 

More context can be found here: http://forums.jfrog.org/REST-API-curl-properties-and-file-contents-tt7579028.html

column1: Separate Log File for Backup
column39:
There is the general log file artifactory.log and a separate log file for import/export activities, import.export.log . But currently there is no possibility to log backup activities in a separate log file. I would need a separate log file to log only backup activities. Then I can save the backup log along with the backup file. This has two big advantages.
- It is easier to check all backup messages, because I must not pick them up between all other artifactory log messages.
- When I restore the backup and find some problems (e.g.: missing artifacts or missing build information) I can check in the backup log file, whether there occured already problems during the backup, or whether these problems are related to restore.
If you need any further info, why I need this feature you can please contact me any time by michael.korte@zeiss.com .
Thanks in advance .

column1: start initscripts in more standard/secure way
column39:
Current install script create artifactory user using bash as the shell. This is not currently a best practice for *nix system accounts.

This can be fixed by making simple changes to the artifactory initscript and the installService.sh script.
 
The changes basically entail changing the useradd to create the artifactory user a no login shell, and updating the the init script to use the deamon function or start-stop-daemon to start the artifactory tomcat instance.

It would also be nice to make the artifactory UID configurable to better support HA installations.

column1: Provide a way to access the server url
column39:
As I'm writing various user plugins, I find myself having to provide the server URL in a configuration file. Since these plugins are independent, I have multiple config files in which the URL is repeated. Not great.
It would be great if Artifactory could provide a variable or a system property to expose the server url.
No magic is needed, a field in the UI to control this could suffice. This is what Nexus does.

column1: UninstallService.sh should not pkill when user is root
PAPI to download artifact into a remote repo
column39:
Currently the PAPI provides the method Repositories#getContent to obtain bytes from a repository.  However this API is limited in that it will only return the artifact if it is already available in the repository.
In the case of remote repositories (and probably virtual), if I need to trigger the download of an artifact into the remote repository, I have to do an http request on the server and this has several problems:
- An admin l/p needs to be provided to access the repository and thus coded into the script or config file
- I need to have a file (the user plugin itself or a config file) to keep the name and port of the server (unless of course there is a variable that contains this info)

In the context of user plugins, it would be much more convenient if there was a PAPI that would cause an artifact to be downloaded. For example we could imagine to extend the getContent method to take an additional parameter.

column1: Allow option not to overwrite dependencies in build promotion
column39:
We've the following usecase
Our first build has a dependency on a given artifact, and another build also uses that same artifact (something from apache common)

We do build promotion using the api/build/promote REST call, where we indicate to copy artifacts and dependencies.

This works fine for the first build, it copies the build, the artifacts, and the dependencies (including the apache common library).
Now we try to promote the 2nd build. This however fails because it asks for DELETE permissions for because it needs to overwrite the apache common artifact.

I don't like this behavior for 2 reasons:
* I don't want our deploy user to have delete permissions
* I don't want anything in our release repo to be deleted (ever), I only want files to be added.

Hence my suggesion: Add an option (or make this default) to skip an dependency copy if it already exists in that repository. I don't really see a reason why you would delete and deploy it again anyway?
column252:
18/Jun/19 1:09 PM;antoine.lemieux;+1

We have the same problem..  we want to keep our promoted repo (Production) with no capabilities to delete anything.

The promotion shall ignore already promoted dependencies instead of breaking the promotion with an error.

Having the option of either would be great.   For now, we have to stop promoting all dependencies and only promote the produced artifacts... making our build less likely to be reproducible unfortunately.
column253: 30/Mar/20 2:37 PM;acormier;How are people working around this?  I would assume this is an extremely common situation where builds share dependencies.  Giving the CI the ability to overwrite the dependencies on a would seem to cause all sorts of issues.  This is one of those things where a very small amount of effort would make this workflow MUCH easier to accomplish.

column1: Server Error Messages Revealing  Information
column39:
By manipulating URL parameters,  our IT security determined it is possible to trigger error messages that could reveal information about the application or back end server environment.  This information can provide an attacker with clues that may be helpful when exploiting other vulnerabilities.
e.g.,

message

description The server encountered an internal error () that prevented it from fulfilling this request.

exception

java.lang.IllegalArgumentException: URLDecoder: Incomplete trailing escape (%) pattern

	org.apache.wicket.request.Url.parseQueryParameter(Url.java:100)
	org.apache.wicket.request.Url.parse(Url.java:228)
	org.apache.wicket.protocol.http.servlet.ServletWebRequest.getContextRelativeUrl(ServletWebRequest.java:192)
	org.apache.wicket.protocol.http.servlet.ServletWebRequest.<init>(ServletWebRequest.java:109)
	org.artifactory.webapp.wicket.application.ArtifactoryWebRequest.<init>(ArtifactoryWebRequest.java:96)

column1: 'Delete Versions' on snapshots should delete the maven metadata
Expose p2 repository XML
column39:
I think you should consider exposing the generated XML code when opening an aggregated p2 repository through a browser. It would make debugging a lot easier. Eclipse and various p2 tools will all cache the information they obtain, so sometimes it is quite hard to figure out whether or not one did something wrong in the p2 repository or in the target definitions. Clearing the cache will help but I don't think many users are aware of how to do this. It will also take extra time as everything has to be resolved between tries.

All in all it would certainly help if one could open the aggregated p2 repository URL and be able to browse or view the p2 content. See for example http://download.eclipse.org/modeling/emf/updates/

column1: Add a flag in import to ignore checksum errors and trust the files

Need a specific flag for ignore checksum errors.

column1: Retrieve Build License Usage and License Configurations through REST
column39:
To programmatically generate reports on OSS usage of our software, it would be great to extend the REST APIs to include:

1) for a given build, the list of licenses used by this build and for each license, the dependencies included (name/version). There is an export CSV function, but I would like to retrieve this list programmatically through REST. 

2) the list of defined license configurations. This list can be exported manually as XML, but I also this one I would like to retrieve this list programmatically through REST.

What we would like is the ability to generate a *single* daily summary report that list all the violations for some given builds.

Thanks

If we want Build Info for unstabel builds too (and we do) we need to use "Deploy even if the build is unstable" even though we do not deploy.

IMHO a more descriptive message is in order

column1: Change the default landing page in the Web UI
column39:
My users do not log in to Artifactory to download client settings very often, but that's the Home tab they see every time they navigate to Artifactory or log in.

The most frequent use case for my end users is to immediately switch to the Artifacts tab and use the Tree browser or a Quick Search. I would like my users to see the Quick Search by default.

Can administrators of the system select the default landing page when a user logs in?

column1: Make tabs bookmarkable
column252: 16/Aug/12 5:50 PM;mortenag;It would be good if instead of doing hacks where the URL is retrieved from a special "button" on each page, the location was reflected in the address bar in the browser.

column1: Support integration revision cleanup for paths with no file integration revision
column39: For example, [org]/[module]/[baseRev](-[folderItegRev])/[module].[ext]

column1: Dependency Declaration warning can't be avoided
column39:
When using a repository layout other then the Maven layout, the "Dependency Declaration" section for a module displays the following unnecessary warning in bold red ....

"Maven might not be able to resolve this artifact since the repository isn't configured to use the Maven layout."

Is it possible to have the default selection for "Build Tool" be set to another value then "Maven"?

--- below is also a reply from the support regarding this topic:

The logic behind the dependency declaration panel is:
1. We search for the last selected tool by a cookie - if found, we use it.
2. If no cookie is found - we try to "guess" the build tool according to the repository layout (maven=maven-2-default, ivy=ivy-default, gradle=gradle-default).

So if you are using a custom layout we are not able to guess it and falling back to maven.

--- EOM
column40: Artifactory Pro Power Pack 2.6.1 (rev. 13124) on Linux.

column1: Add replication commands to artadmin
column39: It would be useful if artadmin could issue a command to enable / disable scheduled replication and also trigger immediate replication on a given repository.  This would enable replication to be controlled from scripts or cron jobs without having to use the REST API.

column1: P2 artifact deployment
column39:
Currently p2 artifacts are deployed by doing multiple operations (delete old artifacts, deploy the new ones one by one).
If this operation fails in the middle, the entire team, depending on p2 artifacts will suffer.
Would it be possible to deploy p2 artifacts transactional, in one operation? Instead of sending all jars one by one, to send one zip archive with p2 site and inflate it after send was complete?

column1: Recognize Password Changes in LDAP
column39:
Maybe it's also a bug?... but currently more liekely an unrecognized misbehaviour :D.
We run Artifactory's authantication via LDAP.
We have a password policy to force the users to change their passwords in regular periods.
We force password encryption in Artifactory.
We recognized, that the encrypted password is stored in Artifactory's database and if a user authenticates it is just checked against the ecncrypted form. Sadly if a user changes his password in LDAP the "old" encrypted password still works in Artifactory.
- Well, it seems it is newly generated if you log in via web-UI
- But most users just start their maven scripts and don't use the webinterface and thus can log in via "old" login
- Using the REST-API is also possibly with old encrypted pw.

You may implement a check where it looks into LDAPS "last password change" for that account and compares it to the users last login to Artifactory - and force rebuild of encrypted password if there is possibly a new one.

column39: Preferably separate it by serverId

column39: The old springsource URLs are now dead servers, and so auto converting the URLs for all configuration seems logical.
