column39: Another feature request that would make replication more suitable for use in a high availability deployment.

column1: Provide a better error message when Gradle build attempts to deploy a snapshot artifact to release repo and vise-versa
Description of virtual repository layout is the same as remote repository (talking about artifacts storage)
column39: "Select the layout the repository should use for storing and identifying modules" is wrong description for virtual repository - it doesn't store anything. It should be something about "on-the-fly transformation".

column1: Early fetch jars and sources not only for Maven
column39:
For now we only download jars for pom and sources for jars if using Maven. We can do better:
For Ivy we can open ivy.xml to know which jar (and sources) to prefetch.
For others we can know which sources to download by looking at repository layout.

column1: Repository restore should be more resilient regarding import path alignment
column39:
When importing a repository, and in particular, when restoring from backup, it is tricky to get the import right. The 'Import from Path' entry has to be exactly right or else a whole bunch of artifacts can get imported in the wrong place. It seems that since the repository name is itself in the path, the imported should find this and auto-align the directory depth.

This is similar to RTFACT-4709, but more about improving this existing mechanism.

column1: Recursive addition of metadata at the repository level should apply to newly-deployed files too
column39:
Scenario: I have a gradle-init-scripts local repository into which I want to deploy our various Gradle init scripts.  Most or all of these init scripts contain ${security.getCurrentUsername()} and similar variables requiring filtering, and thus requiring that "artifactory.filtered=true" metadata is present.

Artifactory allows for setting metadata recursively at the repository level, but this only applies to files that are already present in that repository.  In other words, the recursive setting isn't "sticky" -- it doesn't apply to newly added files.

I'd like semantics here that express "every file in this repository will be filtered (or have whatever bit of metadata), immediately on deployment".  Feasible?  Of course even if 'artifactory.filtered=true' is added by default to a file newly deployed into that repository, it could be manually removed.

column1: Download of filtered resources should trigger 401 authentication
column39:
Scenario: I have deployed a gradle init script or maven settings.xml that contains ${security.getCurrentUsername()} variables to be filtered.  I have marked the files with "artifactory.filtered=true" metadata.

If the repository is readable by user anonymous, then filtering will never occur unless a user has explicitly authenticated themselves via the web before downloading.

Better would be to force a 401 challenge for all filtered files.  This allows for keeping the repository as open and discoverable as possible.  I actually want our internal users to see our 'gradle-init-scripts' repository, even if they aren't authenticated.  But if they try to grab one of the files (say, via wget), I don't want them to end up with unfiltered resources, which will just lead to confusion.

The workaround for now is to disallow anonymous read permissions to the entire repo.

column1: Push replication log entries should have more detail
column39:
Often when replication is happening with other activity, or especially when multiple replications are running concurrently, the intermediate messages between the start and the complete are ambiguous regarding which repo they are for. 

Also, other information would be useful:
 * All log entries should repeat the repo
 * The starting entry could also show the destination server/repo URL
 * The "Calculating changes..." could summarize the count of local and remote entries fetched.
 * The "Replicating changes..." could summarize the count of send and delete operations it will perform.

Here is a sample of our log:

column1: lost+found directory is not handled by backup service
column39:
When the backup is stored under separate partition (Unix/Linux), the following message is logged:

2011-12-20 06:25:39,096 [art-exec-792] [WARN ] (o.a.b.BackupServiceImpl:267) - Failed to remove old backup file or folder '/artifactory_backup/lost+found'.

Lost+found directory should be skipped, or better only backup directories should be handled during backup retention.

column1: Return authentication challenge for directory listings if "Hide Existence of Unauthorized Resource" is not selected
column39: Ivy does not use pre-emptive authentication by default and there doesn't appear to be a way to enable it without changing code.  As a result, if you configure Artifactory to allow anonymous access and do not enable the Hide Existence of Unauthorized Resource checkbox dynamic version matching will not work on protected repositories.  Artifactory will default to the "anonymous view" of a repository and return an empty directory listing rather than requesting authentication.  This is similar to RTFACT-3479 which was resolved by adding the Hide Existence... checkbox.  However, the same behavior does not seem to apply to directory listings and therefore I am unable to use dynamic version matching in my ivy clients _and_ enable anonymous access.  If directory listings could act the same as resources act per the RTFACT-3479 fix that would resolve the issue.  Alternatively another checkbox could be added for this scenario...

http://issues.gradle.org/browse/GRADLE-2968

column1: When using multiple search base a failure to search on one stops the loop
column39:
For example if the search base is ou=people|ou=users|ou=externals and ou=users does not exists in the LDAP server the ou=externals will never be used.
It cannot be done dynamically on user login, since it will keep trying for all login and slows down dramatically the login process.
It should be solve with an error message during LDAP configuration test and save.

column1: Add a flag to before/afterCreate to indicate if it is coming from a 'Move' action
column39: Give a way to prevent delete but allow move copy

column1: When task is stopped because configuration is saved log messages as warnings
With hierarchy LDAP Group the search base should be the one from the LDAP authentication settings
column39: For hierarchy group mapping the search base cannot be different than the one specified in authentication settings.

column1: The Move Action UI should allow moving files/dirs within the same repo
column39:
It is very nice that the web UI presents a simple path-preserving repo to repo move & copy.

But sometimes, it would be nice to be able to at least move artifact trees around within a repo. In our case, we could have used this to repair a funky partial import that dumped the artifacts at the root of the repo. But it might be useful in other cases to allow admins to fix botched uploads.

column1: The repo import should allow importing sub-trees of a repo backup
column39:
The process for restoring from backup assumes that a whole repo will be restored at a time.

I've tried to restore a sub-tree of a repo, just to restore one lost module. I can select the correct path from the backup via the UI, but then the module is imported into the root of the repo and not under the correct sub directory.

My feature request is that the Artifactory import code should compute the relative directory by looking at the input path and scanning for its repo-root. For example, if I am restoring from:

   /X/repositories/libs-releases-local/netflix/platform

into repo libs-releases-local, currently all the version directories end up a the top of the repo. The imported should figure out that they should really be placed under netflix/platform by computing that from: /X/repositories/<srcrepo>/<relativepath>.

column1: Configurable RPM setup parameters
column39:
Some aspects of the RPM installation should be made user-configurable; for example:
* Tomcat port.
* Artifactory user credentials.
* Artifactory installation directory.
* Artifactory home directory.
* MySQL database name (applicable to the MySQL helper script).

column1: Permanent saved searches
column39: Searches do not get saved after being logged out. I get timed out after some inactivity and it gets lost too. We would like to store some of these permanently. Can these be saved in the database instead of a cookie or however it works now?
column252:
10/May/11 1:16 AM;yoavl;The session timeout has been increased to 2 hours in version 2.3.3, so that should mitigate things a bit, I think.

BTW, saved searches are holding artifact references, so holding on to them for too long is probably not going to be a stable approach for a very active repository. We do have an open issue for dynamic search results (saving and replaying the actual search queries on first view), which I think will make sense to store permanently.

column1: Add line numbers to view source panels
Disallow users from logging into artifactory using encrypted passwords
column39:
Currently we are using Artifactory with the LDAP users and groups plugin. We have set the Password Encryption Policy to "Required". We have also enabled "Hide Existence of unauthorized resources". We also "disable internal passwords" for all normal users so that they only use their LDAP passwords. We are also planning to connect over artifactory to Atlassian Crowd for SSO with our Jira and Confluence, however we seem to have the following issue:

If one user gets hold of the encrypted password of another user, that user can potentially login into artifactory using the encrypted password of the other user and since the session would be an SSO session, they can potentially navigate to all the applications as the other user. 

They way user 1 can login using the encrypted password is by going to a repo url directly like
{code}
http://maven.ourdomain.com/artifactory/some-repo
{code}

If you navigate to the above url, then artifactory prompts for a username and encrypted password. Once entered, the user is completely logged in instead of just being able to browse the repository.

For an SSO enabled artifactory, this means the user can navigate to any other SSO enabled application.

column1: Artifactory needs a link to JFrog's JIRA server
column39:
Was trying to file a bug. It would be handy to have a link within each webpage that would have the page ID and the release information which would populate the JIRA issue.

Basically, lower the barrier to filing a defect and increase the quality.

Bonus would be for the server to send up a lightweight configuration and settings dump (if so configured of course).

Marking as a blocker because the link seems easy to do and would help with getting the release perfected.

13/Oct/10 9:29 AM;yoavl;Setting to normal priority.
We tend to classify blockers less sparingly ;)

There should be more visibility into what Artifactory is storing.  Graphs or charts might communicate this information well.  Some ideas include:

1. Graph of the number of Artifacts over time 
2. Chart of the top 10 largest artifacts.
3. Chart of the top n most recent artifacts.

column39: It would be nice if there was a "Copy" button allowing to copy the encrypted password into clipboard without having to select it with a mouse.

column1: Make the startup screen more informative
column39:
If you visit the UI while Artifactory is starting up, a screen comes up telling you that Artifactory is starting up, and the details are in the log file. Any reason the log file isn't tailed in that screen itself? 

If the reason is security, there could just be a toggle in the configuration to enable or disable showing the log.

column1: Deleting all children nodes still leaves the parent node, can cause clutter in bulk delete operations
Separate the permissions for overwriting and deleting
column39: The Delete permission controls both the deletion of artifacts through the web interface and the overwriting of artifacts during deployment.  I propose that these behaviors be governed with two different permissions to avoid mistakes.  A few times users of our repository have accidentally overwritten a previously-released version with a new release.  Revoking their delete permission would solve this problem, but create another.  Sometimes there are mistakes in deployment (especially when repackaging 3rd party libraries), and users need to be able to delete those artifacts and redeploy.
column252: 16/Oct/17 7:45 AM;benjamin.mack;any plans to implement this?

column1: Using ' in wiki article name may brake the URL sometimes
column39:
Hi,

Please, see the screenshot attached - since Wiki article contains a ', IDEA thinks it ends there.
May be not using ' in article names can prevent those cases.

column1: Always auto-remove old backups
column39:
If non-incremental backups fail, old backups are not auto-removed. I would much appreciate an options (check box) to auto-remove old backups anyhow.

We are using the Artifactory backup functionality to export data to central storage where our corporate backup facilities can incorporate the Artifactory backup into their nightly job. We use a 48 hour retention period to make sure that all our Artifactory backups are taken into our corporate backup, even in cases where one corporate backup fails, and thus skips one night.

If non-incremental backups fail, old backups now remain on central storage, pushing our quotas on central storage and also bloating the corporate backup, for no good reason, because these old backups can reasonably be expected to be in last night's corporate backup (and/or that of the night before) anyway.

column1: Make a focus on "GroupId" filed after deploying an artifact
column39: After deploying a new artifact and coming to Artifact Deployer page (see image attached) it would be nice to have a focus on "GroupId" field right away.

column1: Artifactory search fails if searching for an unmatched bracket ( "(" or ")" )
column39:
Hello,

I don't know if this is part of some advanced functionality, but this is not documented anywhere :)

Anyway, Artifactory allows searching for matching brackets: "(stuff)". However, when searching for something like "(stuff" or "stuff)", Artifactory throws an exception. I think this should be treated and it should be more obvious to the user what mistake he made (aka typo). This is not very clear:
"There was an error while searching: Could not execute search query (Error while executing query.)."

After seeing the logs you get a better idea, but this is as admin:
"Caused by: javax.jcr.RepositoryException: Exception building query: org.apache.lucene.queryParser.ParseException: Cannot parse '*stuff)*': Encountered " ")" ") "" at line 1, column 9.
Was expecting one of:
<EOF>
<AND> ...
<OR> ...
<NOT> ...
"+" ...
"-" ...
"(" ...
"*" ...
"^" ...
<QUOTED> ...
<TERM> ...
<FUZZY_SLOP> ...
<PREFIXTERM> ...
<WILDTERM> ...
"[" ...
"{" ...
<NUMBER> ..."

Anyway, this is not crucial, just useful.

column1: Maven settings should be generated with only external mirroring
column39:
When generating Maven settings with the mirror option enabled, Artifactory produces something like this:

{code}
  <mirrors>
    <mirror>
      <mirrorOf>*</mirrorOf>
      <name>remote-repos</name>
      <url>http://MYSERVER:8081/artifactory/remote-repos</url>
      <id>remote-repos</id>
    </mirror>
  </mirrors>
{code}

The way the mirrorOf part is defined breaks one approach we use for project-specific libraries that are not available in a repository. We sometimes create a local repository in a library folder inside the project and then declare this as a repository using a file URL. This means we can manage the dependency both via Maven and as a part of the project.

The fix for this is to mirror only external repository (excluding localhost and file URLs), i.e. the segment above should read:

{code}
  <mirrors>
    <mirror>
      <mirrorOf>external:*</mirrorOf>
      <name>remote-repos</name>
      <url>http://MYSERVER:8081/artifactory/remote-repos</url>
      <id>remote-repos</id>
    </mirror>
  </mirrors>
{code}

Since this should only affect localhost and file URLs (see http://maven.apache.org/guides/mini/guide-mirror-settings.html ) it seems the better option for all scenarios.

Allow encripted password on proxy settings

column1: artadmin should be able to read password from file via --passwordfile=name_of_password_file
column39:
when accessing artadmin from a script it is a potential security risk to place the password for artadmin in the script that calls artadmin, because it will occur in the process-list.
We propose a solution, which has been realized by other tools, such as ldapsearch from openldap:
With a separate option "--passwordfile=name_of_password_file " the password could be read from a file.
column252:
25/Apr/13 2:54 AM;danliston;When executing ldapsearch -h, the "-y" option is described as "read password from file".  It is now late April 2013, and I have yet to see this feature work as designed.  I have seen errors/complaints if the file's permissions are too relaxed, otherwise all I see is "ldap_bind: Invalid credentials (49)".  As others have proven, my file is sound, because I can change -y to -w and put a $(cat ) wrapper around my filename with success.  I consider this to be a lame work-around.  If -y is not going to be fixed, it should be documented.

I should also mention, this problem only seems to exist with openldap tools.

column1: artadmin - support a "delete" command
column39:
Hello,

I think it would be nice if [*artadmin*|http://wiki.jfrog.org/confluence/display/RTF/The+artadmin+Command+Line+Tool] would be able to support a "delete" command as well. We would use it then for periodic cleanups of all snapshots - see http://www.nabble.com/REST-API-for-cleanin-up-snapshots-td24987104.html

Thank you!
column252:
17/Dec/09 12:45 PM;jedioetzi;I agree, with a cleanup options like the ones implemented in continuum: snapshots older than xxx or keep max versions of an artifact.
this will help to make faster artifactory: less cache to keep, smaller index, less unuseful result matches in searches.

column1: The need for configuring indexer sheduler for each repository
column39:
Currently there's only one setting that allows to set indexer shedule for all repositories and it's impossible to set different values for different repositories.
For example, I want central repository index to be refreshed every 5 hours, while for local repositories I'd like to set the value of 10 minutes e.g.

BTW Currently, as far as I understand, index is not build for virtual repositories.
column252: 17/Jun/09 8:43 AM;yoavl;2.1 already has support for virtual repository level indexes.

column1: Use unix-maven-plugin to create rpm, deb and pkg packages?
column39:
While the setup for installing Artifactory on Linux kinda works, it is very complex and error-prone. And Solaris is not supported. 
Have you considered using unix-maven-plugin and appassembler-maven-plugin instead? 


See http://wiki.community.objectware.no/display/smidigtonull/RPM+Deployment+with+Java+Service+Wrapper for and example on how to set this up. The example only shows rpm, but the plugin also supports deb and pkg. 

Keywords: generate Java Service wrapper start scripts, automated installation with rpm, run as non-root user and privs are set correctly during installation, correct run levels with synlinks.
column252: 28/Jan/15 6:12 PM;denebeim;The last project I was on I used maven to build the RPM.  I'll investigate doing the same thing here except for .deb files.  (we can port our rpm build functionality to here as well, basically you end up putting bits of the spec file into your pom.  It takes the version number and other data directly from the pom and generates the spec file on the fly.  Works pretty nicely.)

column39: It will be very useful for me if release notes will be distributed together with WAR file. Now release notes are not quickly available. Only one way I have found to get release notes is to create JIRA account and generate release notes manually.

column1: Please reconsider support for scp
column39:
Please reconsider your disinterest in scp as opposed to http.

The need to put passwords into settings.xml is really a big problem for those of us who care about security. scp allows the use of SSH public keying.

column1: Execute command on successful backup
column39: An option to run a shell command/script when a backup is completed, ideally with a success/failure status, and the file name of the backup available. For instance to trigger a remote copy of the backup to a remote backup server, or send an email to notify if the backup system starts failing.
column252: 16/Jan/12 9:23 PM;cquinn;This would be handy for us so that we could move the backup off to S3.

column1: Handling of long-running task, such as imports and exports
column39:
Long-running tasks, such as imports, should be handled as background tasks in separate threads. A status screen should provide information on the current progress.

It would also be a good idea to provide a command-line interface for such jobs.

column1: Restrict Repository Contents
column39:
In a corporate environment, the use of open source dependencies is encouraged (to avoid recreating the wheel), but a dependency will still need to be _approved_. The approval process gives management an opportunity to validate that the license is compatible, to question its role, and to question whether it is the best solution to adopt compared to alternatives. Once approved, it is added to the corporate Maven repository and is then available to developers. 
 
Artifactory would be useful in managing the corporate Maven repository. However, the proxy needs to be restricted such that certain projects (preferably by version number) are available, and not just anything from ibiblio, for example, is available.

The process is like:
# Developer requests that open source project XYZ is added to the Corporate Maven Repository.
# Development Manager will approve the open source project, and so enables Artifactory to proxy this particular project (and its dependencies) from its source repository.  I think the following would need to be specified:
#* Source Repository:  _Default Maven (Ibiblio)_ [http://www.ibiblio.org/maven2]
#* groupId, artifactId
#* version range (optional).  For example:  \[1.5,)  specifies that versions prior to 1.5 are not accepted.
# Developer updates the pom.xml with the new dependency, and Artifactory proxies it.

This process might seem annoying, but if you are in an environment subject to internal audits, auditors like to see a process with procedures in place chock-full of safeguards.
